I would never say this is the best representation of Szechuanese cuisine in the western world, but it is damn good and satisfying. Yes, part of its attraction for me is reminiscing about the past, and they do need to use more peppercorns to capture the numbing elements of what I like most, but unless I want to travel to China to satisfy my yearnings, Szechuan House is about as good as it gets for the gestalt I seek. 

PS. Yes, Philly has some very strong candidates - Han Dynasty, Chili Szechuan, Chengdu Famous, Four Rivers and Ermi, among the best - they are not appreciably superior to S.H., although I love them all.

I returned to Szechuan House, the hidden treasure of a restaurant found on Rt. 33 in Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey, for another mouth numbing meal last week.  The last time I was there I underwent a root canal the next day without need of additional anesthesia.  It was that good! 

Yes. This is a joke, but you might not think it funny if you don't take the warning seriously. If you are thinking "Mexican" spicy, you are in for a rude awakening.  Szechuan spicy is an entirely different dimension of heat.  I love Jalapenos and Habaneros, and even Ghost Peppers, and you can pile them onto my Flautas without me blinking.  Put an equivalent amount of Szechuan peppercorns, hot chili oil, and those cute little red Chinese peppers into a dish, and your review goes from 5 Star to 5 Alarm.
  
I love it, but it is an acquired taste. As someone said about this style food, "Numb is a flavor."
 
Last week, I was surrounded by Dan Dan Noodles with Minced Pork and Chili Vinaigrette, Steamed Dumplings with Chili Vinaigrette, Amazing Eggplant (that's the name), and Hunan Beef.  

The Dan Dan's were spaghetti diameter, and had a nice ground pork sauce with a mild spicy quotient.  Very tasty and a nice start to the meal. (4 Star/3 Alarm)

The Steamed Dumplings with Chili Vinaigrette was found in the Szechuan Delicacies part of the menu toward the back page.  Six fairly large, hand stuffed and pinched, with the red chili oil and vinegar for a bath. There was a pleasant sweetness that I experienced before the heat arrived. Not sure how that was done, but it played well on my tongue. (5 Star/4 Alarm)

The Amazing Eggplant came on a large plate piled with the thin Chinese Eggplant, in a brown, spicy sauce with a light meat base.  This was delicious and stole the show. Tender, medium heat, and addictive. (5 Star/3 Alarm)

Hunan Beef came with an equal supply of broccoli in a shining brown Hunanese sauce.  The beef was thin sliced and very tender.  The Chinese chilies swam in the sauce at the bottom of the serving bowl.  Solid choice, if not completely inspiring.
(4 Star/ 3 Alarm).

This was a totally satisfying meal, reminding me of my Chengdu daze.  The 5 Alarm dishes were not selected this time as my friends were not accustomed to Szechuan cuisine, and they needed to be broken in slowly.  But, if you are ready for the HEAT, I suggest the Fish Fillet in Hot & Spicy Sauce, the Diced Rabbit with Szechuan Peppercorn Vinaigrette (a cold dish with serious hot), or the Beef in Hot & Spicy Sauce to begin your Vulcan adventure.

Just added two new dishes to the excellent heat profile provided by Szechuan House.

The Chongqing Chicken is a first cousin to the Spicy Chicken Dry Pot Style I have had in the past. High burn with every crunchy morsel. Just below numb on the volcanic scale, perhaps not reaching conflagration due to the meager presence of Szechuan black peppercorns and reliance on red chillies to cover for their absence, but still excellent. 

The Crispy Fish Fillets Sweet & Sour was a large deep platter full of lightly fried fish and loads of orangey thick sauce. More Cantonese, but a strong interpretation. Really liked it in the face of all the other flames. 

The few other plates were good, but not worth taking up more space here in light of all the other fireball delights found in this still surprisingly authentic Chengdu palace.

When my last order of locally roasted coffee beans was about to run out, I looked around online for other bean purveyors to sample. Liberty City Roasters in Bristol, PA, jumped out with a website that exuded passion for their craft. Last Friday I ordered Yirgacheffe and Peruvian 8 oz. bags, drip grind, @ $8.95 per, plus a reasonable shipping charge. They were on my doorstep Saturday afternoon, and brewing in our autodrip Sunday morning. This was quite amazing for a small company, and I suspect that someone in management drove it over to us on his way home from work. 

Gotta love that level of personal service! 

We regularly buy fresh roasted beans, and have adapted our pantry to hold the coffee in our own containers for longer storage. We customize each by cutting and affixing the labels from the roaster to our jars when received so we always know what we are drinking and take pride in our handiwork. 

I've now sipped mugs of both, and can report on my experience. Yirgacheffe is a smaller bean (a/k/a Peaberry), from south central Ethiopia in a micro region of the Sidamo area. The hot days/cool nights at 7,000 feet above sea level are perfect conditions for producing mellow java. This coffee is great in a light to medium roast. It is mildly acidic and gentle on the tongue. It taste clean with a flavor of berries, lemon and perhaps, sweet peanut. Some say a hint of coconut emerges under certain roasting, but I don't know about that. Still, this is my favorite coffee overall, and our beans are an excellent example from the birthplace of coffee. 

These Peruvian beans are similarly expertly roasted to allow peak enjoyment of its java. Its juice is more acidic that the Yirgacheffe, and has a stronger taste, but remains smooth and soft on the pallet. It has a light flavor of  fig, cherry and maybe a touch of peach undertone. It was balanced and lithe. My first encounter was fun and memorable. 

At $8.95 for 8oz, the price was reasonable and only a small premium over mass produced coffee, even those bagged variants with well known names that still roast by the ton, not small batch. 

Very impressive first take.

From its straight ahead name, to its gimmicky "Club" orientation, to the free coffee, and its semi-secret spot along the Delaware River in New Hope, Pa., Fred's Breakfast has it going on! 
It took me long enough to get there and check it out, but now that I've been, I have to say, I really like their style (or lack of it).  

There are no signs out front announcing its presence, yet the place was full on this Saturday morning at 9 am.  The front door was locked for non-members, but everyone knew that the world was invited.  Just wait for someone to open the door and go in.  Put your first name on the legal pad in the foyer and wait for it to be called.  In the meantime, pour yourself a mug of hot coffee (on the house), and look around.  There's a bakery in the corner with good looking housemade goodies, and T Shirts for sale with their logo House Labrador Retriever.  Check out the wood burning stove, and look out the large windows at the Mighty Delaware and Lambertville, NJ across the narrow truss bridge.  Plenty to keep you entertained while you wait for one of the 31 stools around the large room to become available.  Even on this crowded morn, we had adjoining spinners in about 20 minutes.  That's just the first act.

The menu is pretty much standard morning fare, with the major exception that everything is made in house.  Very tempting to try old standards and see what Fred's does with them.  So, we ordered Scrambled Eggs & Corned Beef Hash, and a Ham, Egg & Cheese on English Muffin.  The second came with a side of Hash Browns.  This is more or less a French kitchen, where everything is prepared in front of you.  It is easy to watch the staff do its thing, from making pancake batter, to buttering the toast.  Everyone knows their job and there is constant movement and teamwork.

My Corned Beef Hash was far more colorful than the normal variants.  This one had multi-colored peppers sliced into the mix, along with onion, potato and the meat.  The freshness was outstanding, and the taste a delight to my taste buds.  The scrambled were nothing special, but with a splash of hot sauce they were fine.  The English muffin was supersized and full of nooks and crannies.  It held its contents well, despite the load of sliced grilled ham, fried egg and American cheese.  Strong flavor along with the crunch.  Thomas's could learn a thing or two about improving their product.  The hash browns were plentiful and well cooked, with enough dark nibs and tenderness to be a textural as well as a tasteful side. 

The house closes at 11.  Plan accordingly.

Imli (Tamarind) Indian Kitchen sits on Passyunk Avenue just a few blocks north of Washington.  It is in one of the few strips along this diagonal thoroughfare that is not very commercially developed.  The upside is there is usually street parking to be found nearby.  The down, is that Imli does not benefit from being around other choices for potential customers.  It stands on its own, an excellent South Indian house that is very worth finding. If you live in the neighborhood you have the best of both worlds; the relative quietude of living in a gentrifying residential area, and a great place to walk to for a superior South Asian repast.  Lucky you!

Early Sunday evening there was only one couple dining when we entered.  First impressions were very favorable, with odd angles due to its placement on a narrow point of the star caused by transecting streets; dark wooden and slate hues on walls and floors offering a cool vibe to chill the heat coming from the curry kitchen, and large storefront windows on the urban world, made shade from mature street trees. Two young women approached with smiles and menus in hand, and invited us to sit anywhere. We selected the front corner table with a view of the streetscape without, and the whole room within.  These ladies were definitely sisters, and they admitted to kinship with the owners.  

As firsttimers, we ordered a cross section of the offerings: Chicken 65 for an app; Began Bhurta (veggie curry dish), and Chicken Korma (mildly sweet and loudly hot at the same time). The house put down a plate with Papadum and two dipping sauces, which was a nice gesture. Garlic Naan, Mango Lassi and Chai completed the symphony. The "65" dish came out deep red and slightly crispy.  It was a delicious opening gambit. It was expertly grilled so the tops and edges were near-black, making it visually stunning.  The eggplant (Began Bhurta) came in a deep silver dish and thick curry sauce.  It mixed well with the Basmati Rice and was great for sopping with the Naan.  The Korma arrived in a yogurt/creamy/nutty champagne-colored curry with a nice amount of fresh cut chicken.  Everything was ordered, "hot," and was true to its word.  The lassi and chai helped to reduce the heat as needed, and allowed us to continue through to the end of the meal with calling the fire department.  The Garlic Naan was served flat on a wooden board rather than in a basket (nice touch), and the bowls of rice were more the enough to cover our main dishes.  

I have not been to every other Indian kitchen in Philly, but of the many I have tried in the region, Imli is right up there with the best of them.  It offers a pleasing combination of cool atmosphere, warm, efficient service, and excellent cuisine. It may not be strictly South Indian (who cares), but it certainly knows how to create an unforgettable meal.  

Try to get there soon.

Sunday Brunch UYE Review -

Sorry folks. You'll have to read the other reviews of this Am-azie-ing brunch venue.

I need to take a nap first.

Dredge Harbor sounds like the name of a Stephen King novel, all spooked out for sleepless nights.

 It isn't. Rather, it is a small marina on the Jersey side of the Mighty Delaware in Delran, just south of Riverside. The entrance is a bit obscure, and there is a long driveway to be taken until reaching the water. Once the river is before you, hang a left past the huge hanger drydock, being careful to avoid the heavy forklift moving boats in and out. The cafe is the building on the right next to the ramp leading down to the docks. It is an active marina and it is easy to be distracted by the beautiful boats plying the water among the berths.

This experience is all about outdoor dining. While there is an inside dining area, it has little atmosphere compared to the wide open vistas up and down the river from the overhung patio.  We arrived shortly before 9 am, and were seated at a table within ten minutes.  Coffee flowed, and the menus consisted of traditional breakfast fare from top to bottom.  We opted for a fresh poured and ironed waffle with bacon and a sausage & feta omelet with the home fries thrown inside.  While we waited, we watched the power boats cruising the river and slowly moving around the marina.  It made for a very relaxed and dreamy morning. 

This is one of those adventures where the surroundings trumped the food.  The meals were good, but not more.  My omelet was absolutely loaded with meat, cheese and potatoes, but the sausage links were dry from over-frying, and the eggs could have used a little water in mixing to make them light and fluffy.  The waffle was fine, but would have been so much better with a maple syrup option, rather than the Smucker's corn syrup cheap substitute.  

Still, we really didn't mind the food quality as we mellowed in the moment on the water's edge.  They certainly have the business humming, and don't need to upgrade if they choose not to.  I would come back again regardless, because the environment was so pleasant.  

"... Summer breeze makes me feel fine.  Blowing through the jasmine in my mind..."

Richard Thorton was the original owner of this historic structure on the corner of State and Centre in the heart of Newtown Borough. While he would be proud that his home still stands sentinel after more than 250 years, his allegiance now would be to the nation he witnessed being born and to the Black Horse Tavern that occupies the premises and warms his ghost as he sits at the bar after hours, enjoying the many tales his compatriots tell as the town sleeps.

You know you are in for a treat when the chef/owner comes to your table to discuss what you want for dinner. 

Lucky for me, my dining buddy was a good friend of DeAnna.  When he mentioned to our server that he should ask her how she prepared a certain pasta dish, the next thing I knew she was standing next to us and embracing my friend.  See photo.  She asked me what I was looking for, and I gave a soft description of something I hoped sounded like Pasta Oglio Olio with Sautéed Spinach.  She smiled, offered me a job as relief bartender, and retreated to the kitchen without another word.  Pleasant suspense.  

While we waited our Eggplant Marinade app arrived for sharing.  App?  It was enough for a meal in itself.  It was a delicious rendition of thin sliced Eggplant with a rich Red Sauce, and mild taste of Plum Tomato, Rosemary, and Balsamic Vinegar.  Tender, subtle, and nearly melt in my mouth.  Auspicious beginning. 

When the pasta arrived in its two large white bowls it was not merely the pasta and green I envisioned.  Rather, it was a Star Shaped Profiled Pasta with a Garlic and Oil based sauce that also included the Spinach, Tomato, Green Beans, Crumbled Sweet Italian Sausage, Aged Cheese and maybe a few other things I did not recognize.  

Oh, My!  The first bite launched me on a cruise down the Tiber River.  The pasta was soft but its super fresh state deconstructed upon chewing into its constituent elements.  I had seldom experienced pasta so delicate and complex.  The garlic was present, but not overbearing, allowing the Veggies, and Mellow Cheese to harmonize with the textured Sausage and still snappy Beans.  The Tomato provided a tart note.  It was visually stunning to match the celebration of eating. 

DeAnna and staff took turns stopping by to see how we were doing. Even the bartender inquired. Quite remarkably, thank you.  

We shared both dishes, and it was the reasonable thing to do given the volume of each.  The glutton in me had different ideas, but was contented to know it would be easy to return for more.

All reviews are in the end subjective.  Sometimes all the variables are evaluated, but in other instances one aspect so dominates that the other pieces are minimized by comparison.  For me, when the atmosphere of a restaurant so overcomes me with a sense of comfort and well being that the food or service tends to fade quickly, I react emotionally and start to fall in love with the entire experience.  I can't help it. I'm a hopeless romantic. 

So it was with Coffee Cup Café on Bellevue Avenue, just off one of the ugly parts of business Route 1. I had seen the place for years, but was never tempted to stop and frisk the joint until reading the Yelp reviews.  It seemed like a decent place for breakfast, so I set aside a morning when not too busy to stop in.  

Stepping inside after parking on the street in front, I immediately felt the effect of time warping taking me to circa 1980.  An old counter with about 6 or 7 spinners, and large kitchen service window in the wall behind, and more classic coffee mugs hanging on the walls than I could count. There was a nice size dining room to the side, and another tiny one right in front of the building.  Everything white with blue trim.  

Then Beth approached from behind the counter and asked if I wanted coffee.  "Yes, Mam," as I took in her vivacious eyes and well-tatted skin.  Well, all right!  This woman had a story to tell, and I hoped she would share it.  After mentioning this was my first visit, she gave me the history of Coffee Cup Café back through the early 1970's.  She was second generation ownership, and her son, Jesse, working the kitchen grill would be the third.  She was proud and loud, and she was a groove. She welcomed me to look around, and even step into the galley for a photo. 

The food?  It was just fine.  Coffee hot and fresh.  Breakfast sandwich loaded on a Kaiser roll and able to fill my happy stomach.  I could have hung out there all morning. I felt like a friend and guest of the house.  Some places are just that way.

How many coffee mugs are found in Coffee Cup Café?  

I'll never tell.

The owners of Pin Wei Chinese Restaurant on S. Henderson Road, King of Prussia, PA, may be Taiwanese, but they have taken the time to understand and produce first quality Szechuanese cuisine in the heart of Montgomery County. They have mastered the mysteries of extremely spicy sauces and cooking techniques that create the unique numbing style that finds its source in the history of Chengdu and Chongqing, China.  There aren't many of these authentic houses around, and when one is found it automatically shoots to the top of the list of great dinner spots.  From the size of the crowd waiting for tables last night, the secret is out. 

This was our first visit, after looking mostly in vain for a Szechuan chili joint that knew what it was doing.  There are a few in Philly, and a couple in nearby Jersey, but by and large, the art of flamethrower dishes is a lost art.  We were very happily impressed with Pin Wei. 

We ordered more than we could finish in one sitting, so we would have enough to take home and enjoy a second time.  Our choices consisted of: Scallion Oil Cucumber as an appetizer, and entrees of Chicken Dry Chili Peppers, Lamb Dry Pot, Twice Cooked Fish, and Deep Fried Longhots. 

In a word; FIRE! 

The cucumbers were served cold and marinating in the clear scallion oil.  Crisp, cool, mildly hot and a great introduction.  The platters arrived as they were finished in the kitchen, not all at once, in the traditional Chinese custom.  The longhots arrived next.  They were beautiful to behold - like dark green snakes coiled on themselves waiting for someone to bite them to release their venom.  Awesome, as each chew released more toxin, burning the gums and walls of the mouth, and bringing tears to the eyes.  Eventually, the scald tempered, and the underlying flavor of these peppers emerged transcendent. 

The chicken dry pepper was a sight to behold, with a huge amount of small red Szechuan chilies, garlic, ginger, onion and small pieces of breaded and twice deep fried chicken mixed throughout.  The chili powder on the morsels was a powerful, sinus clearing, blast.  With every wonderful crunch more capsaicin was released, bringing the mouth to near full numbness.  Got to love that feeling to appreciate its otherworldliness. The lamb dry pot arrived next, and we were thankful for a little relief from the conflagration.  The meat was tender with a gentle sweetness beneath the cumin and other stimulants.  Plenty of mushrooms to absorb the dark sauce at the bottom of the heated metal bowl.  Excellent.

Finally, the twice cooked fish arrived. There was a small glitch when after waiting a while, the wrong dish came to the table - twice cooked pork (belly), which looked good, but, alas, was not what we ordered. Ten more minutes to get the right platter.  It was terrific, saving best for last.  Fish fillets, slightly crisp, yet also soft within, with a dark sauce that hinted of vinegar in addition to the less dominant burning powders.  I had to ask our server what that unusual taste was, but he just smiled and demurred.

Inscrutable. 

The secrets of Pin Wei were safe with him. After all, he was the owner, and he didn't want us trying to replicate his magic elixirs at home. He didn't want to be responsible for what might happen.

HOT Damn, people! 

PRO TIP - How does Pin Wei compare with Han Dynasty in Old City?  Food wise, it is a very close call.  Both are excellent, and there is no point in picking one over the other based on the kitchen.  Where there is some separation is in the atmospherics.  Pin Wei is a small place compared to Chestnut Street.  The dining room is very crowded and thus quite loud.  It is a bit distracting. HanDynasty is in an old bank building, and although busy, possesses more nooks and crannies where it is possible to feel some level of  privacy, even in the crowd. The front of Pin Wei was packed with people waiting for tables, and we almost had to fight our way out after dinner. The bar area was SRO, while Han has a larger bar zone, which seldom feels overwhelmed with people.

It is obvious than the success of Pin Wei, is also its shortcoming.  It needs a much bigger space.  Whether it wants it or not is a separate question.

Cryo Spa Natural Healing Center in the Holland Shopping Center, Holland, PA, is a holistic alternative health services center at the intersection of Holland and Buck Roads. It can be a little challenging to reach if coming down Buck Road, but with patience the traffic and red lights can be overcome.  It is well worth your effort to find your way there. 

Although cryotherapy (exposing your body to extremely cold temperature for a short period of time to deal with autoimmune conditions through the release of endorphins and anti-inflammatory proteins) is the main attraction, I was there on a first visit for a full body massage to address lingering lower back issues. I was greeted promptly by the front desk person, who asked me to complete three pages of information regarding my medical history and reason for coming. Before I was finished, my masseuse Marla was introducing herself with warm smile and firm handshake.
 
Before starting the massage, I was also introduced to Lucy, the owner of the facility.  She offered to give me a quick tour.  She showed me the cryotherapy equipment, shiatsu and mediation rooms, and finally the massage chamber where Marla would attempt to loosen my lumbar/sacral spine and take my discomfort away.  The place is bigger than it looks from the outside, and Lucy was very knowledgeable about all the modalities offered. 
 
When it was time to start my massage, Marla directed me to disrobe and get under the sheets on the table, face down on the headrest. She left the room while I did so. Upon returning, she asked a few questions about the strength of the massage desired (strong), and instructed me to tell her if I was experiencing pain (Don't worry. I don't deal with pain in silence.) She explained that she would be doing a combination of stretches, deep tissue, pressure point and Swedish techniques which she labeled as, "Sports Massage."  

She was amazing.  Her hands intuitively found the discomfort in my back and legs, and dug, kneaded, lifted/stretched my joints, and actually moved the muscles, tendons and ligaments around to release their tension and help them find their proper place in my body alignment. She had incredible strength, and was able to lift each leg, pull it further upward, while manipulating the musculature and joints. All the while, we conversed quietly about how I was feeling, giving me directions to help her, and informing me about her experience in massage and healthcare.  Fascinating woman.  Excellent healer. 

After my hour, I arose slowly.  I felt looser and longer.  More significantly, a sense of wellbeing and mild euphoria surrounded me. I was extremely relaxed and felt a limberness and flexibility that had been absent for a long while. I slept very well last night. 

This morning, even as I write this review, my body feels like it is glowing. I know I will return to CryoSpa regularly to maintain and improve this sensation of health, strength and vitality. 

Marla did great work. I also want to give the Shiatsu a try, and if brave enough, go into the cryospa itself to see what that can do. 

Totally positive first impression.

This Jahan Kabob is the sister ship to a joint by the same name on Oxford Valley Road in Langhorne.  Yeah! That's right. The place tucked into the corner of a craft beer store just behind the Super Wawa.  But, the similarity ends with the name.  

Abdul the owner and chef remembered me from the other place and gave me a smile.  His daughter sat by the register taking orders and making friendlies with the customers.  While waiting in line and perusing the take out menu, I took a look around this brand new Afghani/Middle Eastern establishment.  The bright neon beckoned all who find Morrisville an interesting, if offbeat, destination.  The floors were covered with oriental rug runners giving the space a feel of ethnicity, and in the rear stood a low platform with 6 meditation pillows for the Believers who felt the demand to pray before dining.

 Ah Salaam Ahlaikum, my brothers and sisters. 

When I entered I had intended to pick up and go, but the vibe (and aroma) was so unusual, that I decided to find a table to enjoy my meal right there.  When I reached the front of the line I had not decided what I wanted.  I asked Kadrianne what she recommended.  Abdul heard me, and turned from the grill to answer, "Chicken Curry is what you want." 

Obediently, I agreed. Sometimes, Kismet takes a hand. 

He was totally right.  A few minutes later a plate full of thick yellow golden gravied Chicken chunks and a large pile of Long Grain "Dirty" Rice was placed before me. The flavors came through my nose first almost bringing me to tears. My tongue joined the festival a second later.  It is amazing how different curry tastes around the world, because this was neither Indian, nor Thai curry, but something in between.  Cooler and more subtle than it Indian brothers, and suggesting a tartness that its Thai cousins have mastered.  It was unique and savory; smooth and expressive.  The Rice was wonderfully mildly sweet in contradistinction to the Chicken. It seemed the obvious thing to do was mix them together.  That was a moment to remember as my oral senses rejoiced. 

The green Afghani Tea was a good astringent between shoveling the delectables into my mouth.  The Sesame Cookie at the end of the meal, a kind token of appreciation.  

The other reviews are on target in 5 Starring Jahan Kabob.  This is a special place that will get even better with time, and become a landmark helping put Morrisville back on the cuisinery map where it belongs.

It's great to have a high end Napolitan pizza house in Newtown!  It's even better that the enterprise is owned by Pasquale and Anna, the proprietors of Osteria Vecchia, the excellent casa Italiana right down the street. This shop is for the daughter and son-in-law.  Thus, begin empires. 

The building is on the site of the former Minuteman Press.  That old structure was taken down to the foundation, and a new Euro-Country Casual establishment arose.  Attention to detail is obvious, as the space is beautiful, with quality stone, wood, glass and a "just off the boat" wood burning hive oven covered in red glazed tile and contrasting white ceramic lettering that shouts, "Pasquale & Anna/Acqua e Farina!"  

We were greeted by Sal, the maestro de la casa, who sat my son and I at the corner table where we could see the whole operation.  We ordered a Siciliana pie, and as we waited, other servers brought thin slices of red sauced bread, and a small plate of Brussel sprouts that were soft and delicious from their time swimming in olive oil and spices.  I was even offered a glass of red wine on the house. Very cool touch!

The pie arrived with steam shimmering above it, on a large white platter.  It was cut in quarters, and covered in mozza, afterburn peccorino and chunks of eggplant.  Truly, a work of art with the bubbled crust and scorched undercarriage.  The special deal with these ovens is that they hold extremely high heat, such that the raw pie is placed in the oven for less than three minutes, while baking everything quickly and capturing all the flavor of the ingredients before they burn off and escape. The result is a wonderfully textured and tasty crust that is flavored by the ingredients you choose.  It is all about the dough (thus, the name, Water & Flour), and secondarily about the toppings.  Quite different than the better known pizza experience provided by most joints. 

So it was here. A beauty to behold, and a pleasure to consume.  Of course, there is a downside to this approach to baking.  While the crust is excellent, the more ingredients you put on top, the wetter the center of the pie will be on the plate, because it is not possible to fully cook the veggies and meats in such a short time, and as a result of the lack of evaporation in the oven, the finished product will be softer that normal, and the drip from the collected moisture under the hood will be noticeable, and require care to avoid making a mess. 

The secret is to order a simple pie with minimal topside accessories, so that the crust, cheese and sauce have the maximum opportunity to vent off the moisture.  This provides a drier bottom and optimal crustiness. 

Dining at Acqua & Farina is very different than eating at pizza parlors.  It is designed as a feast for the senses.  There are more moving parts, and the resulting cost enhancement is noticeable. There is a time when "two slices and a soda," is what you want, but there are also times when although you yearn for pizza, you want a more rousing experience.  

At those moments, Acqua e Farina will be calling your name.

In evaluating Akiko Sushi it is difficult to separate its quality fish from the environment in which it is served, especially should you choose to eat in the cramped and dirty dining area of the Newtown Farmers' Market.  While it makes little difference for some of the other vendors' products in the too small building, sushi is an art form as well as a food product.  How it is prepared, presented and eaten makes a difference to the Zen experience that so enhances Sushi-Do. 

It is like watching a master at work when the sharp knives flash, the sticky rice is molded into seaweed wraps, and out of the efficient motions of the chef emerges a work of art that you hate to disturb by eating.  It is quite a dilemma.  How much better it would be if you could sit along side a gurgling stream and listen to the songbirds as each morsel was praised before eating. (Sounds a bit like Oishi). 

But, that isn't happening here, so the best you can do is take it home and devour it quickly to capture its fresh essence before it slips away, or just "damn the torpedoes," and find a couple of empty chairs and enjoy it while everyone around you jostles for a place to sit, or scrape their tables and chairs to get in or out.  

If you have a Zen mind none of this will matter as you just shut it all out while you contemplate the exchange of energy from fish to you, and back again.

When my son was in his early years, we were members of the Academy of Natural Sciences on Logan Circle, Philadelphia.  Our membership entitled us to free entrance into the museum, and discount tickets to the special exhibits they always had coming in.  Too, we received some kind of courtesy from the gift shop.  

It was well worth the drive from Bucks County to explore the dinosaur permanent exhibit, as well as the few interactive corners and events that were available throughout the three story hall.  Digging for dinosaur fossils, and touching live reptiles and small mammals, had a profound effect on his young mind, and very likely explains why he now excels in high school science and math.  He went from wanting to be a paleontologist when he grew up, to a geologist, once he discovered there was something beyond huge skeletons in the ground.  

The diorama halls were persuasive in suggesting how various species lived in the wild, and had him imagining he was standing on the savannas of South Africa, watching wildebeests run in a panic from hunting lions. In truth, it wasn't just the kid having these thoughts. It brought that child out of his father, too. 

We explored the butterfly exhibit before it became permanent, and the frog rooms while available. We watched the nature movies in the theater and encouraged each other to dream big when contemplating our planet and universe.  

In truth, we were also members of the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, and went there as often as possible. It was much bigger and better in many ways, but lacked the convenience and crowd management that made the Academy so accessible.  No "Night in the Museum," here, unless you were lucky enough to get a cub scout sleepover.  

If you scored that, anything was possible.

Minuteman Press on Sycamore Street, Newtown, PA, has been under new ownership for the past couple of years, and the change in management has definitely been good for business. 

I stopped in last week to see if they could produce a professional sign for the law office I was opening in town. It was a slat sign to be mounted on a larger directory sign in the front yard of this old converted 19th Century house.  I spoke with Scott Woron, who quickly looked at the old signs and explained to me that it was a thin vinyl sheet over the wood base that would carry the print, and not directly onto the planks.  He said it would be easy to do, and the cost would be very reasonable. 

I stopped back in today to pick up the signs.  They were ready and looked great! Cost less than the estimate I received from another sign company that specialized in only that one thing. Happy to save a few bucks and miles.  

Now, I applied for the borough permit to put up the sign. Once that is secured and the office is inspected for the Use & Occupancy permit, I will have the signs put in place, and be open for business. 

It was great to have it done correctly, on time, and at cost by the local Minuteman Press. 

Local business scores again!

I had my second sports massage with Marla Solarski yesterday at Cryo Spa in Holland, PA. It was in a different room, but still with Asian atmosphere and nice background music. 

Once again, she asked a few questions about how I was feeling and where I was feeling it. She was most interested in how I had responded to the first massage two weeks before. In fact, my lower back, legs and shoulders responded well last time, and I was ready for another strong stretching and deep tissue therapeutic hour. 

This time, except when I had to interact with her by resisting her pushing/pulling, I was more relaxed and was able to zone out and go somewhere within while she worked her magic. Marla dug deeper into my thighs which had absorbed the result of two herniated discs. Painful, but necessary to relieve stress and increase flexibility. Torquing my hips and legs to open space between my discs. Leaning her weight into my folded knees to help loosen the perpetual tightness in my lumbar spine. 

The time passed quickly, but at its end I felt great, and almost intoxicated from the work done. The spa allowed me to sit in a quiet room for a few minutes until that sensation ended. 

Slept like a baby last night.

PRO TIP - Marla actually works in several locations, just call her to find where is most convenient for you.

In my Trenton Days, Halo Farms and the Trenton Farmers' Market on Spruce Street were regular stops on my weekly provisioning list.  I loved the ability to buy fresh dairy products at everyday good prices, and to support a worthy institution.  It is great to know it survived without my business these many years.  When I stopped in again on a cold Sunday afternoon, it was like visiting an old friend.  

The store looks basically the same, with bins for milk at ground level, open refrigeration units for ice cream, and wire shelves for bread, donuts and snacks.  It is still rather dark and dingy, but the fun of finding quality local products at below market prices is what is most important.  

Yesterday I purchased 2% Milk @ $1.49/half gallon, and 3 pint cups of their private label ice cream @ "Buy 2, get one free @ $6." When the ice cream is comparable to the high end labels at twice or thrice the price, you have a great deal.  What flavors, you ask?  Tahitian Vanilla, Raspberry and Butter Pecan.  

With snow still deep, and ice still creep, the actual tasting will wait for a warmer moment or a burning fireplace.

If you want to go "Back to the Future", then you must stop in to Dairy Delite on Woodbourne Road in Levittown.  

It is one of those time warp places where if you step up to the window and order one of their great soft sweet thick ice cream flavors in a cone or cup, or a extra thick shake, you can actually feel the strands of time pulling you into a vortex that lands you somewhere around 1957.  Look in the mirror and you would swear the lines on your face are lighter, and the sparkle in your eyes brighter.  Return often enough and you realize that the real secret here is not just the old original recipe, but that it sits atop the Fountain of Youth, and mixes its ageless serum into every drop that flows from its ancient spouts.  Those beauties taking your order may look 18, but check their birth certificates, and you see they are really 78.

Powerful elixir that Vanilla Swirl!

While I wish they didn't use Styrofoam cups, there is no debate that the soft serve here is about as good as it gets.  The prices are ridiculous. The former "Cash Only" requirement not oppressive simply because credit cards weren't as prevalent 60 years ago. 

If only the Dollar was still worth what is was Back in the Day.

I just had the best sandwich I have eaten in recent memory. 

Hidden in plain sight at the rear of El Primo Mercado, the Mexican grocery store on Markley Street, Norristown, PA, is a moderate sized dining room and kitchen that cooks up amazing, authentic, wholesome, heavy plates of terrific comida Mexicana. Take a walk on the wild side past the bakery and chilis aisle, around the canned goods and wall of packaged tortillas, and finally humbly by the multitude of Madre Maria statuary looking down from the high shelves, into the eating area. Pull out a chair at a small table and await the friendly bilingual servers to present the large menu and take your drink order from the homemade fruit drinks and rice horchata. 

I picked the Torta Milanesa de Pollo (fried breaded chicken sandwich) thinking it was a good way to introduce myself to the chef's skills. What I got was a gigantic sandwich on fresh super roll, loaded with delicious thin chicken breast, spicy mayo, lettuce, soft queso fresca (string cheese) and avocado. I could only eat half, and brought the rest home, where my 19 year old son devoured it in seconds, uttering only a muffled "Wow, this IS good," as he came up for air.

It was the second best thing I had consumed this year, after the Greek dessert I ate last week in Princeton. Just amazing, and worth the hour long drive back to Norristown from Bucks County just to see what else this cocina can turn out as remarkable as that Torta.

The Grange Fair is a traditional country fair run annually at this site in Wrightstown, Pa. It has all the attributes you would expect from a cultural events that has run for more than a century.  Livestock displays and competitions, 4H halls full of pies, pickled foods, flower arrangements, and art, with colored ribbons for the winners. 

In addition, you can buy a tractor, arrange for a home visit by a landscaper or stone mason, and indulge yourself in carney food to your heart's content. For the kids (in each of us), there is a ride area with enough spinning, dipping and diving to upset your stomach for a week. My advice, ride before you eat, or better yet, come twice, once to ride and another visit to eat. The food is what you expect from a greasy country joint. Burgers, Sausage, Franks, Pizza, Ice Cream, and Kettle Korn (my fave). There is usually a beer wagon around that pours out a local brew and leaves a wet trail of suds on the ground. Beware the drunken bees that congregate there. Man, would I love to have some of the Beer Honey that hive puts out! 

Yes, there are a fair share of Carney barkers and hucksters to enjoy with vigilance, and the local politicians trying hard to find votes by giving out balloons to kids. But, you can ignore that degradation and enjoy everything else. 

The place is crowded at night when the cooler air invites families to come out for a night of old fashioned entertainment.  There is something special about a country fair at night. But, if you prefer to avoid the bigger crowds, arriving in the afternoon allows you a clearer view, and the ability to park and walk through the tents and sheds at an easy pace, when everyone who works there has more time to pay attention to you.

Be sure to make time to come up here. The roads around it are jammed in the evening, so give yourself time to wait in line.  If you know the roads, it is easier to approach from the north or west. Take out your GPS or paper maps and figure out how to do that. You could save yourself an hour of more in the queue.  

The Grange Fair is definitely a child memory maker, so be sure to start your kids early and allow them to carry on this wonderful All American tradition.

Cafe Madison Holland sits in the Pheasant Valley Center at the bottom of Buck Road where a Chinese restaurant used to be. They have done a great renovation to the space and turned it into an attractive, comfortable room full of photos of customers. There are about a half dozen tables and small 6/7 stool counter for lone travellers. I grabbed a spinner so as not to take up a table and be able to chat with the staff. Turned out that Dean the owner was in the house, and we ended up in a long conversation about the trials and tribulations of opening a food business in Northampton. Let's just say his experience was not a business friendly welcome. 

Glad he saw it through, because he has created an excellent place for an Americana breakfast. It is warm and feels quickly like home. The menu is extensive for the morning and afternoon meals and prices are fair. I opted to sample their french toast and homemade sausage patty with coffee. At $8.75, it was a deal and a half! 

The toast was expertly turned. Amply saturated with egg/sugar/vanilla mix, the bread was thin and the right texture to absorb to its core. The edges were nicely caramelized to a mild crisp. The sausage was a freeform patty with very good flavor. I was glad I asked my server to help me choose among the alternatives. She was dead on that I should go with it. I appreciated that while they didn't have maple syrup, they at least had Log Cabin, rather than those corn syrup sweeteners. Lastly, the coffee was a Bunn drip that was hot and strong. 

I have a feeling that Madison Cafe Holland is going to be a big hit where there are few good choices for a decent breakfast and lunch. It isn't that far from Newtown nor Feasterville that it won't draw from those communities as well. It will help put this corner of Northampton Township back on the map, something that has been missing since the passing of the Mill Race Inn. With Two Ladies Bakery Cafe, Johnny Apples, and Salvo's Pizza and a few other restaurants nearby, it is beginning to be a worthy destination again. 

I, for one, am very excited to see this happening.

I really enjoy adaptive reuse of old buildings that bring old and new sensibilities to the fore. When done well, they are both attractive and useful in ways unforeseen when the structure was first constructed, and bring new uses into old packages, calling the imagination of the new occupant forward in wonderment. The Johnson Hall Coffee House is a great example. It offers a shop unimagined in 1890 when it was build, yet as redesigned, it provides a functioning java house that could have existed at that time, but has emerged due to the evolving cultural affections of our modern day. It looks old, but isn't. 

It is a  warm, light and airy high ceilinged first floor retail outlet for excellent coffee products and breakfast, brunch and lunch options. Although limited by the kitchen equipment available to prepare meals, it still provides enough variety to make a stop very worthwhile. I loved the large windows, dropped period lighting, white ceramic tile, wood plank floors, and the friendliness of the staff. 

I ordered an egg and cheese breakfast sandwich on croissant, with mug o' joe. It came in at about $8, and while ordering was at the counter in back, the servers brought the sandwich to my table. They would be wise to advertise the coffee roaster more dominantly both in the store and online, as I am sure I was not the only one curious about who produced the quality beans. The croissant was not quite French boulangerie, but still large and tasty enough to be satisfying. 

Still, the atmosphere here is the star of the show. It is a great place for both solitary and collective pleasures.

All good things come to an end, so when my 13 year old war horse Infiniti finally went to the junkyard in metal heaven, I was sad, but not really surprised. Over 200,000 miles is a long life. It didn't owe me anything, and I had beaten the crap out of it.

I began a search for a replacement by checking with Car Gurus, an internet site that had been successful for me in the past. I thought I wanted to stick with the Infiniti brand, but find something newer in a quality used car. Compared to Lexus there were amazingly few oldies but goodies around. That was precisely why I chose Infiniti to begin with. Just didn't want the most popular in school, but that hidden understated gem. 

On the second search I found a newer M 35x with low mileage on the lot at Holman Infiniti over in Maple Shade, New Jersey, about 25 miles away. 

I gave them a call to find out if it was still there, and spoke with Mario Pinardo in their sales department. He went out to check and came back enthusiastic about how good the vehicle looked - Pearl White with light leather interior. I expected him to try to sell it, but he seemed naturally excited by what he saw. I asked him to hold it for me until tomorrow. He said he could only do so until 11:00 AM Tuesday. 

I was there at 10:00. 

This M 35x was worth being excited about. Perfect body. Not a scratch, dent nor ding. Immaculate within, with beautiful wood trim, sleek and sexy front and back. Well detailed to a perfect glowing leather, wood and metal trim. The drive was strong, responsive, with throaty exhaust and acceleration that offered no apologies for being six cylinders, 3.5 liters, as opposed to the eight 4.5 L the old boy threw around. Better gas mileage, too. And, the price for all that was very reasonable, and made it nearly impossible to walk away from. 

Yup! An hour later it was mine and I drove it home. 
The experience at Holman was excellent from beginning to end. The dealership is large, but they kept everything at a comfortable human scale. Mario was great. He was genuine, engaged and led us through the process with precise guidance. Even the minutes with the finance manager were decent. I didn't mind that he was a Cowboys fan.

Comes a time when those small trees taking root in the gutters of my home had to be dealt with, my sons didn't want to do it and climbing 30 feet up and down a ladder was a fool's errand for me. Had to bite the bullet and look for someone with the equipment and ability to do the job and stop it from being an annual problem. 

After doing research and connecting with both local handymen, contractors and those professional gutter protection companies, I came to the conclusion that the only way to have the work done right, with warranty and acceptable prices was to go with the guys who specialize in this business. I chose LeafFilter Gutter Protection, a franchise located in Sharon Hill, PA. 

I contacted them through their website and had a call back the next day. We met at my home a few days later, when I met Dan, their sales representative. He had a routine to go through, but he was genuine and made honest eye contact. He measured the gutters and explained their process and materials to me. I liked him, and found their technology to make sense compared to the competition. They have their pricing technique like the other solicitors for this service, which is always a put off, but ultimately we worked something out that was good for me on price, including 12 month interest-free financing. 

Their crew arrived a day later with all they needed to complete the job. They power cleaned the existing gutters, anchored them firmly into the fascia with long screws and new braces, and them installed their vinyl covers and micro screens into the covers' frames. They finished about 5 hours later, cleaned up their mess completely and spoke with me about what they had seen up there that might need attention in the future. I signed off on the work order and sent them on their way. 

We are expecting heavy weather this week, so the new LeafFilter will get an early workout. Given how much trouble the gutters were in past storms, I am looking forward to seeing how well the system works, and beyond that putting aside the worry I have felt wondering whether the next heavy rain would completely overwhelm the old aluminum runnels and knock them to the ground. 

If this works as expected, I will put this anxiety behind, and become a convert to LeafFilter. If it doesn't hold up as advertised and warranted, there will be an addendum to this review. 

For now, 5 STARS and a lot of anticipation.

Just finished an excellent breakfast at Lancer's Diner in Horsham, PA. I sat at the counter with a couple of other dudes and engaged in interesting conversation with my neighbor to the left and the owner of the establishment, while I enjoyed a Veggie Omelet, Rye toast and Coffee.

The three egger filled the plate from rim to rim, and was loaded with broccoli, spinach, onion, tomato, mushrooms and the home fried potatoes, I requested be placed inside the omelet. A few splashes of Tobasco and I was hot to trot. Very filling, tasty and satisfying, with plenty of refills of my coffee mug. 

Our discussions covered many issues of the day, including mask wearing for school children (some initial disagreement, but we found common ground), the U.S. Constitution (I received free copies from the owner, which he distributes to everyone), the CCP (Chinese Communist Party - all opposed) and illegal opioid black market sales by pharmaceutical companies (put the bastards in jail). We clearly came from different perspectives and had desperate sources of information, but reached some consensus due to our calm, respecting demeanor and good grub. It was the best exchange I have had with strangers in a long time. 

For that alone a fifth star is awarded in appreciation.

Grapevine has been anchoring North State Street in Ntown for years, and Chuck takes his position as organic food and nutrient provided to the community very seriously.  If he doesn't have it, he will get it for you quickly. Amazing how much fits into his small shop. 

My primary purposes for visiting are to buy the vitamins and supplements that generally can't be found in the supermarkets of the area in organic form.  Too, he now carries Lynn's Coffees, bean or ground, and local roast coffee tastes best to me. 

Thinking globally and buying locally is important if we are to maintain Main Streets that are economically viable.  Thankfully, Grapevine is a pleasure to frequent, as  Chuck and his people are knowledgeable and super friendly. It just feels good when I walk into his shop and he calls out my name in greeting.  I don't get that kind of reception in big boxes.  

One of the coolest things about Grapevine is that in Spring and Summer the storefront is one giant hanging flower garden shop.  The riot of colors from the solid wall of hanging petunias and other flora is overflowing in abundance.  It is hard to find the front door from the foliage around it.  But, so much fun searching for it.

For a coffee lover there is nothing as satisfying as quality raw coffee beans, freshly roasted, ground and brewed by a favorite method to create the perfect cuppa joe. Once introduced to apex java brew there is just no going back to Maxwell House or Folgers. 

There are a number of excellent local roasters that provide the materials to produce this great way to greet the day. Covered Bridge in Feasterville is now one of my favorites. Housed in a rear out building behind an industrial garage, they have established a small shop loaded with all the paraphernalia needed to reproduce your coffee at home, with heavy duty roaster in back that produces enough customized volume to keep their growing list of consumers satisfied within a few days of ordering. In our case, we ordered directly from their website on Friday night and received an email that our beans were ready for pickup Saturday morning. The "born on" date stamped on the back of the resealable brown bag was actually the previous Monday.  

That's pretty darn fresh. 

Ordered were Ethiopian Natural Kembata Grade 1 and The Bee's Knees Breakfast Blend (Ethiopia & Brasil). Over years of java drinking I learned that the valleys and mountainsides of Ethiopia grew the best coffee beans on the planet. Mild, yet richly textured taste, I am willing to hunt for and pay more for it, rather than settle for mass produced coffee from Columbia and the like. So, I opened that bag this morning and inhaled deeply. 

Its powerful aroma was overwhelming. 

I waited a moment to let that snort settle in. It was decadent, yet innocent. I decided on a pour over of an individual mug, rather than brewing a full pot. When the filtered water was boiling in the whistle teapot, I began to slowly pour it through the cone filter and grounds sitting in our glass mug top funnel.  

The result was near euphoria. First sip of the jet black suspension was intense, steamy, perfectly delicious coffee, that disclosed its lithe muscular body and subtle undertones of cocoa, strawberry and orange as it played on my tongue. It was as interesting as a fine glass of wine, without the alcohol, but with a similar intoxicating affect. 

At $15/lb., it isn't cheap, but given how deprived we have all been in this lockdown quarantine Year of Covid, a little decadence at home is likely a good thing.

Ray's Café & Teahouse on North 9th Street on the eastern end of Chinatown, has been brewing incredible coffee since the mid-90s.  The ambiance is def Taiwanese old school, with Grace and son working the Hario syphon butane java makers with aplomb and verve.  The best locally roasted beans are used to make single cups of joe, that are delivered to the table on a small tray, with doily and excellent butter cookie aboard. Little spout of milk on the side. 

The Ethiopian Yirgacheffe beans from Main Line Coffee Roasters, were freshly ground the moment before their boiling bath and syphoning through the beautiful glass system, producing a superb cuppa joe. Not to put too fine a point on it, but this was among the very best coffee I have ever enjoyed. To watch Grace make my cup from grinding through pouring, was to see an artist at work. Perfect temperature. Perfectly balanced acidity.  A pleasure to imbibe. Easy to become addicted.  The Hario equipment was lined up on her counter, and the butane burner emitted a cool blue flame that brought the filtered water to a boil and flushed it up the tube and down through the coffee against a cloth filter.  Pure alchemy! 

Even the butter cookie with the colorful sprinkles was a winner. Hard and crisp, the way it should be. 

Yes. At $5 a cup, this is not for the faint hearted. But, for coffee lovers and mavens, going to Ray's is a trip to the mountaintop to sit at the feet of the javamaster.

Lily is the heart and soul of the Chocolate Paradise over which she holds expert dominion. Her friendliness and genuine interest in her customers matches perfectly with the homemade candy she creates. She explains that she is a first generation American of Chinese heritage who worked in a law office before discovering her true calling as a chocolateer. 

Her small shop in the Pheasant Valley Center on Buck Road, Holland, PA, feels a bit enchanted upon walking in. There is a wall of shelves holding most of the milk, semi sweet and dark chocolate offerings, seductively packaged and fairly priced. They grab your attention until Lily's voice calls you across the room to where she sits packaging her goods and overseeing the operation. She asks what you like, makes suggestions, and offers samples to help convince you to take a deep dive into her cacao universe. 

Just follow her lead. She won't disappoint. 

I purchased a box of peanut butter cups and buckeyes, and sampled sea salt caramel chocolate covered cashews (sultry), sriracha honey peanuts (mildly sweet with a chili bite), and a German waffle cookie (Stroopwafel) dipped in milk chocolate with caramel center(nice crisp base for the creamy brown blanket and that sticky caramel kick). The peanut butter was high quality (way better than Skippy), creamy smooth that melded wonderfully with the equally soft and sexy chocolate casing. Made me wonder how anyone introduced to these babies could ever go back to Reece's!? (Rhetorical question - They can't.) 

Well, maybe for Halloween, but otherwise I'd rather go for Lily's best - eat fewer, but kvell so much more. 

Lily's Chocolate Paradise is where to go for your chocolate fix. Yes. There other a few other custom chocolate shops around, but none with Lily's exceptional personality, nor at such affordablilty. 

This is rich indulgence for the people!

First a bit of housekeeping - Winckler's Ribs is hard to find.  It is located in a small space on Washington Street, immediately to the rear of Anthony's Pizza. It is north of Bridge Street and difficult to see until you are right on top of it. Look for the red awning. Your perseverance will be rewarded.

Walking in, I immediately met Mike Winckler, owner and rib chef extraordinaire.  He was sitting on the only seating available inside his shop; a small bench for take out customers (and resting top chefs) to chill while waiting for the next wave.  He looked up at me with a smile as I apologized for ending his moment of peace. He was wearing a white chef's pants, jacket and high hat.

As I was the only buyer I took the opportunity to talk with him and look around as he stood over the grill working my order of a half rack of ribs. The sizzle and smoke arose in energetic clouds as it was sucked up by the exhaust fans.  Some of it escaped to my nose where my brain immediately went into hyperdrive as the sauce molecules slammed into my sensory filters.  

Oh My!  Involuntary salivation. Gulp.

I saw his shelf of hot sauces from around the world, and those cans of mysterious powders in shades of orange, red and yellow like you find in huge piles in old markets in India or Pakistan. Not curries, but something more esoteric. The ribs were now showing black streaks where the meat was completely cauterized and the sugars from the marinade and basting sauces were caramelizing into a crunchy sealant. As the final step, Mike poured the red amber finishing sauce over the ribs, turning them a glossy orange-red. Loved that tint. 

He packed the finished ribs in an aluminum foil bottomed styro box, accompanied by a small cup of his Cole Slaw and a chunk of Corn Bread.  Afterwards, we watched the video commercial for his ribs through You Tube on his HDTV above a refrigerator.  It was fun and further built my anticipation.  I drove home excited. 

This prelude would be meaningless unless his ribs backed up all this build up.  

They did.

The meat willingly parted from the bone. The first bite was a surprise.  Rather than the sweet, tart BBQ explosion I expected, I was confronted with something more subtle.  The taste was complex; both mildly sweet and hot, with undertones of other spices I could not identify.  Nutmeg?  Something sort of nutty?  Not sure, but I loved it.  The texture of the meat remained intact. Softly chewy and sticky.  The glaze and shards of meat that were left on the bone were sucked off with relish.  

The Cole Slaw was sweet.  The Corn Bread was really more like Corn Cake - moist and sweet.  

I loved these ribs, although they were different than what I had eaten before.  It was obvious that a lot of thought, study and preparation went into their creation.  

I will return, and may have found a buried treasure in the droning leftoverness of Morrisville, in the shadows of Trenton, alongside the mighty Delaware flow.

This adaptive reuse of the former NASA centrifuge where our astronauts were trained before heading for the Moon, is a model of excellence in concept, design and performance.  It is worth a look just to see the once state of the art space technology now sitting above your head in a large circular room, bathed in warm blues, reds and greens.  Where once science reigned supreme, now houses one of the most interesting and comfortable banquet halls imaginable.  

That we just attended a wonderful event honoring terrific people who helped make our Council Rock School District one of the best in Pennsylvania, if not nationwide, is very nice, but that it was held in this amazing "space," makes the moment unforgettable. 

Wonder what they could do with a great rock band here?

It had been more than a year since my last visit to Marty's Place. Time flies! 

I was driving by this morning after court, having skipped breakfast at home in order to get a jump on traffic going into the city.  I saw a new sign out front on a Bud Light white board that breakfast was now being served 7 days a week!  

Hot diggity!

I parked out back and walked in to a mostly empty bar (2 customers who looked like they were regulars).  The bartender approached and we engaged about their breakfast menu.  It was pretty wide open if my desires had anything to do with eggs.  They did. I opted for a sausage, egg and cheese on Kaiser roll, and mug of java.  While it was being created in the kitchen I watched a show about exotic car auctions.  A Borgati opening at a cool million bucks was an eye opener.  Another black transport used by John Lennon around London was also put up and sold.  Pretty cool entertainment. 

The sandwich was great!  Double patty, fried egg, American cheese and a fresh, quality roll, made for a tasty and fun meal.  The side of homefries was likewise excellent - hot, crisp and spicy with sautéed onions in the mix. Coffee, strong and kicking. The only shortcomings were the lack of a joe refill offering, and lack of utensils. Luckily, I had a spoon from the coffee, which was fine as a shovel.  

Afterall, Marty's is still a wonderful corner dive.  It was made for comfort, not for speed, nor etiquette.

My fourth visit overall to Café Chorba, and the first in over 6 months.  It was nice to return to the friendly, comfy confines of this fine house. 

This morning, I was the only patron at the counter and Marie was my attentive server. She was solicitous and informative, keeping my coffee mug full, and providing a glass of milk for the coffee rather than the ubiquitous tiny creamers.  I finally had the strength to move beyond the excellent French Toast and try something new.  

Today I moved on to the Greek Omelet.  It was spectacular with a pile of crunchy edged Home Fries, and Rye Toast.  The 3 egg platter was loaded with peppers, onions, tomatoes, Italian sausage, and feta cheese. They blended together well on the tongue, and with a little black pepper on top was terrific.  The taters could not be finished as they occupied nearly half the large plate.  Still, they were the right combo of crunch and tender properly spiced with a hint of butter to sweeten the palate. 

It was a huge and hugely successful breakfast complete with good service and lots of fresh coffee.  

It is not hyperbole to say that Café Chorba is as good as it gets for breakfast in the area and beyond. 

Time for an upgrade to 5 Stars.

First impressions - Warm, rich, dark red...umbrella-high ceilings, and Buddha smiling quietly... waiting on the Pad Thai.
And, it gets better from there.
A deep red glow accents the atmosphere in Aroi Thai & Asian Bistro.  The service is timely, friendly, and efficient.  The lunch menu was still in play although I walked in at 3:02. Only one other table occupied, and a couple at the bar.  Snow starting to fall. It felt like a Dashell Hamett novel. 
First visit and I went for the Pad Thai.  It was excellent!  Hot, attractively presented with cool sprouts, and lime to bring out the tamarind and peanut undertones. Impressive portion for a lunch.  Jasmin tea chaser. 
Wonderful lunch.
Is it as "good as it gets?"  I won't know until I go back for more...soon.

10.27.13 - Returned for the fourth time last night and was again totally impressed with the atmosphere, service and cuisine.  I have ordered off the menu and from the specials, and each dish has been unusually flavorful, interesting and satisfying.  Last night I had Singapore Laksa Curry Noodle, a thick rich Coconut Curry Soup, loaded with a variety of shellfish, chicken, tofu, whole egg and veggies.  The coconut curry was subtle, yet spicy enough to warrant some caution.  I could not finish.  At $12. I was pleased.  Along with Jasmine Tea, I was a sated and happy man.  

I think 5 Stars is warranted for Aroi Thai & Asian Bistro.  Aside from some amazing places I have visited in Bangkok and Pattaya, this is as good as I have had in the USA.
Still a great morning wake up! Strong java. Well made breakfasts. Friendly, homey, service.

A new generation of "comfy casual" dining is sprouting around the nation, and its seeds have germinated in Mt. Holly.  Kitchen 87 has taken root and its flowers are blooming even in the depth of winter.  While most diners, luncheonettes and cafés are second or third generation owned and operated, or simply maintaining the status quo under new management, this creekside establishment is going in a new direction.  Young owners with fresh ideas and fine execution bring streetlife and adventurous palates to once bucolic Mt. Holly.  

Don't get me wrong, I love the traditional places making good food and reminding me of home.  Yet, there is plenty of room for a joint using the same ingredients, but reconstructing the menu into something unique and totally enjoyable, while keeping the sense of hearth and home through their use of most of the same tools and kitchenware with which we are all familiar.

From the vantage point of a counter stool, a spin around shows a wall lined with booths, a bunch of tables mid-floor, and a swinging kitchen door through which very friendly and gregarious servers come and go.  They are obviously proud of what they are doing, and want to share their confidence and happiness at being part of this enterprise.  I had good conversations with two women who were interested in more than just light pleasantries.  They really wanted to know what I thought about their place, and a slice of my worldview.  I was pleased to share.  

My breakfast was on par with everything else that was happening inside Kitchen 87.  I had the "Which Came First" Sandwich - Breaded Chicken Patty, Swiss, Fried Egg, on a Brioche Roll, with Home Fries on the side.  It was a hot, happy, delicious, mess.   Knife and fork were mandatory, as it was too big and slick to be handled.  Everything melded well together, with drippy egg running through everything and giving its blessing to the rest.  The taters were dark grilled and spiced just right.  I really enjoyed every bite, although I could not finish the side.  The Coffee was brewed strong and the pot returned to me several times. 

In the mood for a great breakfast that challenges you preconceptions about what can be done with eggs, cheese, bread, meat and potatoes?  

You are ready for Kitchen 87.

El Rey de Oros (The King of Diamonds) is another excellent Mexican/Salvadoran restaurant in the heart of Bucks County, PA. It sits in a small commercial strip on West Moreland Avenue, Hatboro; the last storefront, farthest from Blair Mill Road. 

Once inside, you find about ten tables with the counter and kitchen in the back of the house. I was greeted warmly by one of the owners, who guided me to a corner table and handed me their menu. Most of the offerings were Mexican, with a few Salvadoran specialties. I selected the chili rellenos (stuffed chili) dinner, which included rice, beans and a basket of four hot tortillas. 

It took a while for my meal to arrive, but when it did, I immediately saw how big the poblano pepper was, and was advised by la senora that the dish was made from scratch for me. I could taste the difference. The queso stuffing was plentiful; the egg wrap completely encased the pepper, and the red salsa on top was fresh and piquant. A totally delicious take on this standard. This was one of my favorite Mexican dishes taken to a new level of satisfaction. Yes. It was worth the wait. 

I also appreciated the old school approach to the chips and salsa gracing my table gratis. In the new world where many restaurants now charge for this table snack, it was very nice to have them placed in front of me with just a smile. In that regard, the chips were served warm and crunchy. The salsa was placed on the table in plastic rockets for squirting into small black bowls. They were smooth versions of hot sauce, and at first I missed the chunks of tomato, pepper and onion. The taste was the same, it just lacked the thickness I normally associate with salsa. I'll give them a pass on that. 

This King of Diamonds is a full house of Mexican/Salvadoran cuisine. Definitely, worth a stop on your visits south of the border.

Step into history with a visit to Newtown Hardware House. 
This impeccably maintained old fashioned hardware store is a museum of Americana in screws, nails, tools, plumbing, electrical supplies, and even Flexible Flyer sleds and snow shovels.  
The amazing and virtuous Dave C., the owner of the NHH for many years recently sold it to a local family to keep the operation open, so head in to buy the light bulbs and faucets you need for your fix-it projects.  Bring your kids so they can experience a slice of America that is almost extinct. While in the area, visit the other shops on State Street to support the community and the businesses that keep Newtown, Newtown.

If you are fortunate enough to remember when drug stores were primarily pharmacies where the expertise of the pharmacist and the family doctor were responsible for the health of the community, then you can appreciate Bear Apothecary in Lambertville, NJ. 

Walking in is a step back in time, but where it matters - customer/medicine accountability - it is completely up to date. Mort wears the long white coat from 1960, signifying his deep roots in patient care and his long distance perspective on the evolution of drugs and illness. The generations of families that have relied on that knowledge testify to the commitment made by the owners since its founding. 

True, Bear is not a contemporary super-pharmacy, but, isn't that a good thing? I really don't care if I can buy snacks, drinks or books when I need a prescription filled for my kid. Knowing that the pharmacist has seen it all before, and staked his career on the wellness of my community is paramount. Such knowledge (and wisdom) cannot be duplicated.

If your looking for a big breakfast 24/7, plus a full lunch and dinner menu, then Amy's Omelette House is singing your siren song. 

312 varieties of omelet at last count, plus, pancakes, French toast, sandwiches, muffins, quesadillas, burritos, and enough coffee to drown your sorrows - all presented in a large but cozy converted diner at the intersection of Rt. 130 and High Street in Burlington City, NJ.  Those of us who remember when this was the old Burlington Diner find it all the more remarkable, because it took so long for the BD to finally die that most of us forgot there could be good food at that location.  

And, good it is.  The signature omelets are 3 eggers full of whatever you want.  Wet or dry, potatoes in or out, the result is a belly busting, can't stop myself, corker of a meal. The service is right in line with the product; fresh and swaggering. I haven't made it past the omelets, French Toast, breakfast sandwiches and a Quesadilla, but all have been at the very least, very good.  

PRO TIP - Try to sit in the old original boxcar dining room.  It is so well maintained it feels like you are chowing down in a museum.  It makes everything taste even better.

Debbie's Deli on Liberty Street in Hamilton, NJ, has been in business for thirty years in the same location.  The sandwich emporium is as small as your master bedroom closet, but managed to turn out excellent breakfasts and lunches within its miniscule confines.  

It is a Boar's Head joint, but with the license to roast the turkey, ham and roast beef on its own when delivered there by this provider.  That extra touch of freshness and originality shows that it is trusted to do excellent work to maintain the brand, and that they succeed in doing so.  Impressive.

Today, I ordered a blackboard special - a cup of Potato Leek Soup, and a third of a Roast Turkey & Swiss Hoagie.  The price; $5.95.  While waiting, I spoke to "Debbie," who is really her former partner after she left the business many years ago.  He is proud of his shop, and it shows in the clean, cozy atmosphere, and the outstanding quality of his products.  

The Potato Leek Soup was heavily chunked with spuds and leek in a rich, creamy base.  Delicious.  Obviously, made with love that very day.  The sandwich came on fresh, light Italian loaf.  The home baked gobbler was cool, tasty and a pleasure to consume, with a couple slices of Swiss nuttiness to complement the more savory turkey.  A delight.  

If Debbie's gets too famous, it will have to move to larger quarters, as there is room for at most ten standing people in there.  Nice problem to have.  It is somewhat surprising that these guys haven't run into this situation before.  

Street parking can be a challenge on the narrow one-way streets in that neighborhood. But, worth the effort.

Rhodes Newtown Flower & Gift Shop on South State Street, is an old fashioned florist that packs a lot of petals and stems into a tiny space in historic Newtown Borough. House plants, beautiful flower arrangements,  gifts of all stripes are in every available nook and cranny, except for the narrow path left open to get around. In the heart of the retail area is an old refrigerated display case with the more delicate flora, mostly roses, lilies and orchids. 

There in the back, on the top shelf I saw a bouquet of peach roses with baby's breath and lavender in a green glass vase. It drew me to it despite the red long stems shouting for attention. There was something about the soft understated elegance of these young opening buds that called me. After years of buying on line, I had forgotten how sensual it was to buy flowers with my eyes, nose and hands engaged. Intoxicating. 

It was my own private party as a prelude to the extra satisfaction of carrying them out of the shop and walking down the street with them in hand. It was noticed by those on the sidewalk, and I could have sworn that the women looked at me a bit more attentively. Nice! 

All these extra fun dimensions for slightly more than the price to point and click. Plus, a warm human being answering questions and making suggestions.

So glad I rediscovered the classic way to get ready for Valentine's Day! Surely, the special atmosphere in Rhodes had a lot to do with it.

Cattani Catering & Kitchen on Parkway Avenue, Ewing, NJ, is an exceptional Italian house with small dining room and five stool counter, turning out creative and delicious dishes for those lucky enough to know it is there. 

I stopped in for a late lunch last week, grabbing a spinner overlooking the kitchen. Only one table was occupied by women in bonnets, although a few people came in to pick up take out orders. Sherry was running the floor, and cheerily brought me the clipboard menu along with a cool copper mule mug of water and lemon. Prices were on the high side, but given the description of the food and Sherry's enthusiasm for each of them, I accepted that this was a "budget be damned" moment. I ordered the chicken milanese sandwich with side salad. The order in, I then saw Ms. Cattani herself putting my meal together. She waved and said hello while cheffing for me. 

Turns out she is basically a self taught uber foodie, who decided to open her open shop after working for other restaurants for several years. She is self taught and obviously a great student of her craft. 

My lunch arrived on a thin wood plank. Minimalist, but strikingly presented. A feast for the eyes, and ultimately, the stomach. The chicken breast was pounded into a thin steak, lightly breaded in Italian crumbs and pan fried, with marinated peperonata, parmesan and aged balsamic drip on a crusty seeded "rustic" torpedo roll. It was delicious. No one off, this. Each element made a contribution to the overall work of art. I like milanese dishes, and even prepare them at home. Still, none are as interesting and tasty as this, and it was just a sandwich! What would it have been as a stand alone fully plated dinner? Don't know, but a week later I am still thinking of when to find out. 

All the while, Sherry was seeing to the incoming phone orders and refilling my water mug during the gaps in the calls. Service was friendly and informative. I was well cared for. 

This was a superior lunch from an unexpected source.

 Surprise was perhaps the tastiest part of the dish.

I feel healthier already!
