A morning fast breaker of Blueberry Smoothie and Egg Salad Toast was all I needed to put the pep back in my step and have my digestive tract shouting, "Hip Hip Hooray!" Dubious? Don't knock it till you try it.

Never a lover of egg salad, I am game when told it is from neighboring chickens and mixed with goodness and a little vegan mayo. This work of art, spread atop excellent multi grain toast and garnished with greens and petunia petals, was likely the best of breed. It was delicious, while providing superlative flavor and crunchable texture. Just stupendous! 

The suck down smoothie called "Blueberry Wake Up," was all that, too. It was richly blueberried, and blended with other ingredients (see menu photo) that were almost addictive. Semisweet, darkly indigo, thick and creamy, and loaded with energy, it was hard to take the straw out of my mouth. And, combined with the egg salad, made for a surprisingly memorable morning meal. 

Service was friendly, informative, impeccable and attractive. The small shop full of magical foods and additives to help you live a more healthy and essential life. Just check out the wire egg basket. Those uber fresh hard shells were right from the nest, without even a stop for a bath. 

I'm a believer.

Just attended a private party in one of Piccolo Trattoria's side rooms in their Newtown store. It went very well. 

We were about 20 people celebrating a successful election season in town. The victorious candidates, their families and the campaign team came together with our own wine and beer, and a pre-selected menu of three entree choices (chicken francaise, eggplant parmesan and grilled tilapia) side salad, penne vodka, bread and tomato based dipping sauce. We had two servers assigned to us who did a great job of keeping everything moving. 

I split the chicken and eggplant with someone, and both were excellent. The egg/lemon/white wine reduction was tart and played well with the pan sauteed tender bird and was ample enough to allow sipping up with the fresh homemade bread. The eggplant was likewise thin sliced and pan fried before going into the oven to meld with the tomato sauce and mozzarella. Delicious. 

With a few glasses of Cabernet Sauvignon, a final sweet bite of chocolate chip mini cannolli and friendly conversation about gearing up for a more successful 2020 presidential election, we were on our way out the door in two hours. 

Hope we weren't too boisterous. We will need the other diners to support our people next year.

Part of the Pennsylvania Community College System, Bucks County Community College has three campuses. The largest is the 200 acre preserve in Newtown, sitting at the edge of Tyler State Park. The Tyler Mansion anchors the northern edge of the campus, and provides some administrative office space to the school, as well as a facility for the many catered events that take place there. The park and the manse offer the institution an expanse and historic dignity seldom found in our new public schools of higher education. 

The tuition is approximately $10,000 per year, but most students qualify for some financial aid, bringing the average expense closer to $7,200. So, it is a good deal compared to double that cost for other state schools in the Commonwealth. Many of my son's friends start at BCCC and transfer to a four year college after graduation, thus saving money in the interim so they can more easily afford reaching a complete university education. 

Recently, I drove over to the school to receive my two Covid vaccinations (Pfizer). Bucks Department of Health had transformed the student center into a large injection site. With online registration and email reminders, it was a convenient and efficient place to take care of this important community health care responsibility. The staff was professional and humane, with easy directions to proceed through the process. No long lines. Little fuss. No muss. 

I was impressed with how smoothly everything went, and how well the school cooperated with the county government and the thousands people who chose to visit the school to take care of their important business.

This old pre-Revolutionary War building has been well restored into an excellent interactive museum of the colonial period of New Jersey history. Given how poorly the other landmarks have fared in this capital city, the condition of this one is all the more remarkable and very worthy of a visit or two by history buffs. 
It was built in 1758 to house British soldiers during the French & Indian War. Colonists objected to being required to quarter Redcoats in their homes, as even at that time tension was high between people who identified as Jerseyites more than English subjects and resented the control the King had over their lives. The colonial government built five of these barracks around the colony, although this one in Trenton is the only survivor. 
There were Hessians and a few British officers housed here in December, 1776, when General Washington crossed the Delaware River on Christmas Day eve and surprised the enemy with an early morning cannon barrage and brief fighting, leading to a rapid collapse of any defense and the surrender of Colonel Rall and his 1,200 men. There was more fighting to be done the following week at the Second Battle of Trenton (Assunpink Creek Bridge) on January 2, 1777, and the Battle of Princeton on the 3rd, but this quick victory set the tone for the success to come, and convinced the Continental Army, Continental Congress and the American colonists that this insurrection could be won and that George Washington was the man to do it.
The barracks became an army hospital thereafter, and it was here that army physicians conducted the first inoculations of small pox to protect the troops from the deadly pox. This was the first attempt at inoculations anywhere in the modern world. In more recent times, the buildings were reduced to what remains today to make way for Front Street to reach the New Jersey Statehouse. What we see now was privately owned for a time and used for housing, until purchased by a few revolutionary war memorial groups who wanted to preserve and protect it for posterity. 
These days it is a surprisingly excellent museum of the revolutionary period, restored authentically to look like active soldiers living quarters, with workers/guides dressed in appropriate period costume. It is very easy to imagine what it was like to be alive in those days, and to participate in such important historic events 
Take a tour and see how amazing it all is (and was)!

If you remember your childhood ice cream experiences with wistful images of hanging out at the old shack where the sweetest, creamiest, drippiest, crispest cone crunch, brought the timeless taste of the best childhood memories dancing back to your tongue, then Jo-Jo's is your magic carpet ride. Homemade 'scream so potent and cooly fresh, that a single lick transports you to that first moment you tasted these awesome American flavors of life. 

This 1950's summer pleasuredome is a full monty.  The whitewashed walls, the elbow lighting, the sliding windows for orders and pick up.  The young faces of high school kids with their first summer jobs.  The old, wizened eyes of the master ice cream maker; watching intently as the next generation of innocence both inside the shop and outside on the winding line, take their turn on the carousel.  The pristine ecstasy of your child's first taste; a drippy spot on her nose.  

All this happens effortlessly at Jo-Jo's.  So glad I found it. 

My Peanut Butter Vanilla and Salted Caramel Pretzel scoops were as good as I have eaten anywhere.  Richness in flavor, texture and human interaction. My tastebuds rejoiced.  I sat with my cup of joy and watched as everyone else "kvelled" with this luscious pleasure.  

How great to be there on a warm mid-March evening, before the crowds of summer demand delayed gratification, and I can be the first on line.  

Simple.  Sweet Life.

Down at the bottom of Walton Road, Warwick Township, Bucks County, PA, lies perhaps the most enchanted spot in all of Pennsylvania. Ross Mill Farm has been a secret haven since originally started before the Revolutionary War in 1740. 

The lane is narrow and full of dips and rough riding, but so very worth the effort to find, especially if you love adaptive reuse of an historic property turned into a rescue home and boarding facility exclusively for Vietnamese Pot Belly Pigs. 

180+ residents live there now, either from broken homes or as paying customers, housed there because it is simply the best place on the planet for happy, healthy PBPs. The 30 acres are idyllic for humans, too, but the facilities are designed by the owner from the perspective of an intelligent animal that stands little more that 18 inches from the ground. To truly interact with the residents you really have to get down on your knees, because these cuties lack the ability to look up at you. So, the world is very short, but expansive at Ross Mill Farm. The green lawns and gardens are perfectly suited for a pig. 

And, for people who love them. 

This amazing patch of heaven on the Little Neshaminy Creek is as magic as you want it to be. I found it easy to get lost in the peaceful magic of the moment. Make a donation and help it last forever.

Liv & Charlie Real Food on North Union Street, Lambertville, NJ, is a morning/afternoon shop serving healthy and tasty meals on treadle tabletops in this beautiful river city. The people are friendly and confident in the quality of their menu.

I stopped in last week for breakfast and totally enjoyed the experience. Their french toast made with fresh challah was excellent. The egg/vanilla/sugar/cinnamon mix soaked in well and the hot grill caramelized the edges just right. Most important, the house used pure maple syrup and cold butter to allow me to doctor the slices the way I like best. I sipped my strong coffee (with fresh whole milk) as the beurre melted and the syrup eddied and swirled on the plate. 

It was delicious. I kept cutting the toast into smaller pieces to maximize absorbency and stretch out the pleasure. 

It was a quiet morning with only one other table occupied. The music track was alternative rock that suited the atmosphere of the house. 

Liv & Charlie know what they are doing. 

5 Stars all the way!

If you enjoy narrow gauge vertical lift truss bridges from the early part of the 20th Century, the Burlington-Bristol Bridge is for you.  I cross it several times a month on my way to Mt. Holly, NJ from Bucks County, Pa, but I keep both hands on the wheel to be able to drive in the single lane across the Delaware River, and can't "check in" often on Yelp.  Take my word for this.  

While true that the drive is challenging, it is also somewhat exhilarating.  From the apex the view up and down the Mighty Delaware is large. The waterfronts of historic Bristol and Burlington are in full sight.  Burlington Island to the north sits midstream with the ruins of a 19th Century amusement park slumbering in the shade, its once proud roller coaster a skeleton after a fire destroyed the park.  To the south the rust of other Industrial Age factories likewise lie in ruin, or continue to operate and belch waste out of decayed smokestacks.  

The engineering involved in the design of the lift mechanisms was invented by the Romans, but is still the height of expertise two thousand years later.  Watching the megaton slabs of concrete lower from the twin towers, and cause the lift of the central roadway with pulleys and cable, is also an amazement.  If I wasn't in such a rush to get to court I might really marvel at this human feat.  As it is, it is a very cool way to be delayed by forces beyond my control.  

If time is not an insurmountable issue, there are great places in both towns that gave their names to this span, where meal and drink can be secured in its very shadow.

Arriving at 3:30, I learned Ban Bamboo closed for two hours on Saturday afternoon and reopened at 4. So, I had a little time to wander along Ridge Avenue and take in the beautiful Spring day and the local color. The street scene was active with outdoor seating at the brewery and many open doors allowing the kitchen aromas to waft out to we pedestrians. Definitely created the aura of being a neighborhood. 

When BB's "Open" sign lit, I went in to discover a small dining area with lovely Buddha shrine front and center, and heavy southeast Asian decor all around. A cafe in Vientiane or Pattaya would look as good. I ordered Tom Kha Soup (veggie), Beef Satay, Red Curry (veggie), Drunken Noodles (chicken), and Kai Soi (beef), to go. It was 40 minutes to readiness, so I continued my exploration of the area while waiting, and thought about what I remembered about Lao and Thai cuisine. 

While both are very regionalized so that there are many distinctions even in different parts of each country. Still, there are a few generalities that hold true. Where Thai uses coconut milk in many dishes making it sweet, often counterbalanced by the heat of chili peppers and bitterness of lemongrass; Lao kitchens lack coconuts, and use more lime and fermented fish sauces for flavor. Lao is a lot saltier than Thai. 

So, it was easy to know which was which in my package. The Tom Kha Soup came on strong on sweetness from its coconut milk/galangal base, followed immediately by a lemongrass bite. It could have used more variety of veggies in the bowl, but the taste profile set off a riot in my mouth. The Red Curry was similar in sweetness, but lit a fire from the chili paste used to turn the color crimson. The veggies were still semi firm, adding to the texture, along with the bell pepper, bamboo shoots and Thai basil. The Beef Satay was lean meat with excellent BBQ type sauce, and on the sweeter side. Drunken Noodles were definitely from Thailand in flavor and plenty spicy from roasted chili sauce. Kai Soi, on the other hand, was more a hybrid, using thin sliced beef in a coconut milk broth, mixed with egg noodles, red onion, cabbage and lemon/lime juices. It reminded of Indian curry with its sweet/sour profile. 

Although travel time neutralized the higher taste amplitudes to reduce the delicate intricacies that exited the kitchen, it was still a wonderfully entertaining meal that is well worth revisiting, along with this Ridge Avenue neighborhood.

Ratchada is a district in Bangkok known for less bustle while very entertaining. This Thai/Laotian house takes its name and atmosphere from this more mellow part of a very intense big city.  It is apt, as when walking in off of S. 11th Street (a half block off Washington), you immediately feel a sense of decompression and culture shift from urban hubbub to Asian serenity.  The dark wood tones, silks, and wall art invite you to leave the outside world behind, and wade into a secret jasmine scented pool of tranquility. 

Hyperbole? Perhaps. But, after the week I just finished, it felt so to me. 

We were seated immediately and on time by Jib, the diminutive whirlwind who seemed to be everywhere at once.  She was graceful, smiling, communicative and clearly loved what she was doing.  The menu was quickly explained and we were given ample time to peruse and select.  Tom Yum Nam Khon (Creamy Lemongrass Soup) and Tom Kha (Coconut Soup) to begin.  Fried Calamari to appetize.  Ratchata Duck (a Chef Special) to share.  

The soups were hot, spicy, loaded with veggies, and a great way to commence.  My taste buds were on alert to the complexity of each spoonful.  The Calamari had a beer batter that seemed a little off for the dish as it created a coating around the calamari rings that easily separated from the crustacean and made the eating a bit disjointed.  Still, it was very fresh and the Sriracha/sweet&sour peanut sauce was good enough to eat by itself. Nothing was left behind.

The star of the show was the Duck.  Its skin was crispy and the meat perfectly tender and moist.  The Mango/Tamarind mix that created the sauce that covered the bottom of the platter was simply exquisite.  So glad for the rice to absorb every drop after the duck was gone. Sweet/tart/creamy. There was ample sliced canard on the plate for two, and even a drumstick bone underneath for me to pick up and gnaw off the slim morsels.  

This was a thoroughly enjoyable and memorable dinner.  It put me in an excellent frame of mind to such an extent that we decided to have their Thai Tea Ice Cream for dessert.  It too, was revelatory.  How many times have I had Thai Iced Tea and never considered taking it the next step?  So glad someone around here had done so.  I mite expensive at $6. for a big scoop, but a great way to end a wonderful meal. 

Revisiting Ratchada is as desirable as it is inevitable.

Perhaps the most beautiful urban park in the USA, Fairmount captures both the historic grandeur of Philadelphia, as well as its awesome potential. And, of all the great buildings and events that have taken place there, the one most strategically placed and incredibly majestic vista is seen when standing on the Belmont Plateau overlooking Center City. 

While living in the neighborhoods near the Art Museum (Brown St.), West Philly (UPenn) and in West Center City (25th & Delancey), I was always close enough to walk, bike or drive to the Plateau for a softball game, holiday picnic or sleigh ride in the snow. It remains my favorite single spot in the City to relax, breathe deep and capture the essence of what makes this town great. 

Sure, it's the people, but looking down into its urban core gives a sense of human potential and unique possibilities. 

In short, the view is inspirational.

Bunn's Natural Foods on Street Road, Southampton, PA, is one of the original organic foods, vitamin and supplement outposts in Bucks County. If you're looking for some zinc to enhance immunity, or K2 to offset possible bone density loss due to the extra D2 taken in this Age of Covid, or just stocking up on healthy frozen food, Bunn's is your little slice of heaven. 

The staff is very knowledgeable about their inventory and will gladly walk you to the part of the store where your needs are answered, and provide explanations for the available choices. I found them particularly useful while attempting to purchase the correct dosage of a mineral recommended in reading I had done on the subject of enhanced immunity, and learned that a low dose would be more effective than a higher one of one element due to side effects. Always good to know.

Bunn's does enough volume to carry their own label vitamins at a excellent discount to the national brands. They built a new center for their business several years ago, which while still small by comparison to other retail spots, is expansive enough to carry what most people want in a clean and friendly environment. 

In a difficult economy where many of these small local shops are closing, Bunn's is surviving fairly well and will hopefully continue to do so.

Excellent bagel joint in Doylestown Borough. Small customer area, with room in back for ovens, preparation, storage and display case. The rounders have a crisp biting crust, while the inside has enough air pockets to keep it fairly light enough to allow the flavor of the topping (roast onion flakes) or whatever is added in the prep(butter & Swiss) to come through strongly. 

I appreciate the bagel baker who knows not to knead the dough too long, which hardens the bread and makes it too dense. Too, here they are boiled and then baked in the right proportion to create the optimal bagel. 

Having La Colombe and Ellis Coffee in house is also a big plus, as they are both top shelf Philadelphia roasters that have found success nationally and internationally.

 These Borough guys are not fooling around. They give their customers quality bagels and first class java for a fair price. It wouldn't surprise me if their success was assured and they grew their enterprise as far as they wanted to take it.

This was my third visit in so many months, and this time I ordered the Eggplant Parm Grinder (finished with a visit to the over to plasmatize everything).  It was great.  Thin sliced, sautéed, Eggplant, chunky Tomato Sauce, and fresh tasting Mozza on a large Italian Loaf; all brought to a sizzling climax with a brief visit to the pizza oven before serving.

For totally satisfying and delicious lunches, Tina gets 5 BIG ONES!

Now I remember why it is best to seek treatment at a world class teaching hospital, than to accept second best from suburban medical providers. They just know more and practice at the highest level of competence and integrity. 

So, when I sought a second opinion before agreeing to a lithotripsy, I scheduled an appointment with Victor Carpiniello, M.D., on the 19th floor of Penn Medicine Washington Square, this week. Impressive offices and even more impressive people there, from reception through Dr. Carpiniello, and everyone in between. There was little wait to see the doctor after completing the standard forms/questionnaires.  He came into the examination room with a warm smile and years of experience. He knew what I was dealing with and the treatment options. If I wanted, he could take care of the condition later in the week on an outpatient surgical basis. I liked the way he talked to me, and his calm demeanor throughout. 

We agreed to take care of business when suggested, but he wanted me to first have a cardiac clearance as a precaution because of my medical history. That was scheduled for two days later. Turned out, before undergoing general anesthesia for kidney stones, I would need a stress test (which I was due for anyway). That takes place tomorrow. 

Given the unexpected twists and turns this situation has already taken, my decision to seek more information from a higher authority was the right one.  It is difficult to express the increased concern knowing the extra steps that are required to protect my health, while balanced by the sense of confidence and relief I also feel knowing I am in the best hands possible. No knock on my regular urologist who has tended to me for many years, but knowing I am being treated by a leading authority on these conditions; someone who is teaching other doctors how to do these procedures, offers a security blanket that makes going through all this much easier to accept, and sleep at night. 

Will update this review as all the steps take place and I come out the other end.

I don't like to date myself, but some of us remember the amazing burgers that downtown Trenton was famous for back in the day. Neon on Hanover Street, Tremont  Lounge on East State, The Famous also on East State closer to Montgomery.  These establishments' handmade patties and local Colonial Bakery rolls were the stuff of legend. Not even the original Rossi's in the Burg could hold a candle to these masterpieces, unless you valued immense size over eye rolling OMG juicy substance. (It was Neon that introduced me to horseradish to perfect a burger.)

Those vaunted halls have gone to Valhalla to feed the gods.  Lucky deities. 

What generated these meat puck reveries was lunch today at Checkers, the dive bar/resto on S. Warren Street. The reviews spoke glowingly about the open grill kitchen and in hushed tones about the burgers. Would I be fortunate enough to séance with the burger-essence of yesteryear? The First Bite would tell the tale.

I took a big one and broke into a smile.  Excellent fresh ground beef, hand shaped, grilled to the desired medium finish, nicely sautéed sweet onion on top, well melted American cheese in between, and light local bakery roll holding it all together.  The taste was so pleasurable that I closed my eyes for a moment to savor it completely.  Just the right amount of grease to assure proper digestion.  The side red potato salad was homemade and without too much mayo. 

While it wouldn't be fair to directly compare a Checker's Burger with those of its Trenton ancestors which have attained divine status, the fact that this experience brought those sainted heroes to mind is serious praise, indeed. Next time I'll request horseradish and see if the reality comes closer to the blessed memory.

Sometimes, the sun shines a little brighter, and a public employee is so on the ball as to provide great information that saves time and restores faith in humankind.  

It was time to renew my Pa. Drivers License; not the funnest task in a bureaucratic world.  I had already done the online work and received the document needed to submit to the PennDot office in order to qualify for a new photo license.  When I arrived at the Bensalem Service Center and beheld the multitudes waiting to be helped, I momentarily lost buoyancy.  How long would this take?  

Luckily, I asked the security officer at the information desk about how to proceed.  She was in total command.  She asked if I knew where Fairless Hills was.  I did.  She advised that there was a Photo License Center on Oxford Valley Road, that had no waiting most of the time.  She estimated it would be at least 30 minutes before anyone would talk to me in Bensalem, and recommended I drive right over to Fairless and take care of business.  

I did so.  It was on my way to work, and a great place to know about.  I was there in 15 minutes.  I was the only person in the storefront when I entered.  The photo person beckoned me to her.  I handed her the document.  She asked a few simple questions about organ donations.  She offered to take a second shot when the first made me look like a gorilla.  I was out in under 5 minutes.  

Amazing!  That PennDot should be efficient enough to delegate photo license renewal to its own space, demonstrates planning beyond what most public bureaucracies are able to contemplate.  Thanks to everyone who made this possible, and who carried it off so smoothly.  

You guys deserve a raise.

I never noticed this tiny pizza parlor nestled at the end of a small strip center with only 4 shops, but my never ending search for the perfect tomato pie brought me here late last week as the clouds gathered beckoning rain. 

Although small in stature, the menu is large with the usual suspects to be found in an Italianesque joint that has to move fast and be creative to complete in a universe full of larger predators. When I walked in, I was greeted by a short man (from central casting), wearing a backward baseball cap and speaking with a warm Spanish accent.  I asked if there were any slices of tomato pie available.  He apologized for not having any at the ready, but immediately offered to make a personal size TP for me if I had 10 minutes to wait.  Of course I did. 

I watched as he retrieved an aluminum dough container, peeled out the slowing rising mass and slapped it onto his cool granite countertop.  Fingering, spreading, stretching, spinning, tossing it just enough to get it to the right size without over-manipulating it to toughen the finished product.  He laid out the mozza neatly around the disk, and then flicked globs of chunky tomato sauce on top like he was Michelangelo in his abstract period. Satisfied, he slid his wooden long handled pizza mover underneath, turned, and gently shook it off onto the hot oven floor.  

About 8 minutes later he was walking toward my table with a steaming large plate on which sat my personal Tomato Pie.  It was beautiful and its heat wave struck my nose and eyes at the same instant, causing me to catch my breath and shed a small tear.  

I picked up the first wedge and held it for a moment.  It was straight and true, never wavering nor bending under the weight of the topside.  The under carriage was beautifully scorched, but not burnt.  First bite was amazing. My teeth cut through the tomato and cheese and felt the heat on my upper palate. My lower jaw clamped down, closing mid slice on a crisp firm crackery crust.  

Magnificent!

I had intended to eat half and bring home the rest, but it was so perfectly balanced between taste, texture and eye-rolling excellence, that I knew it would lose something essential if I did not eat the whole thing at that moment.  So, I did, and skipped dinner that night. 

It's hard to tell if this experience could be duplicated, or if I had just stumbled into a apex moment that was beyond everyone's ability to recreate.  Regardless, this time was mine, and I offered thanks for having lived this one.

At the end of January, leaking into February, the largest gem, rock and mineral show in the world opens in Tucson.  It takes over the entire city, and very much like a gathering of gypsies it turns this high desert town into an amazing display of every of stone imaginable (and quite a few you never thought of).  For rock hounds this is the pilgrimage you yearn to make at least once in your life.  

For those of us with businesses in gems and jewelry, it is nearly a "must go" if you want to see what is being taken out of the ground around the planet, and what very creative people are doing with them.  I have been on both ends of this experience, both buying and selling what I believed others would find attractive and workable.  My focus has been colored gems and stones (aquamarine, peridot, spinel, tourmaline, topaz, varieties of agate), while offering pieces that I found on buying trips to Mexico and Asia, both natural and antique.  

It is a wonderful high to surround myself with these beauties of nature for a week, and allow their glow to filter into the mindspace where new ideas generate.  And, when not exploring the multitude of temporary shops set up in motels, or campgrounds around town, Tucson itself offers excellent diversions via great restaurants, parks, and hotels.  At first I went alone and rushed back after a few days, but seeing how extremely overwhelming the show was I began bringing my family to make a vacation of it.  It has become the place we most enjoy hanging out, especially when the winter drears on and on.

The first thing noticed entering Coffee House Too was how the people working there embrace your presence. From Josh the manager, to Channelle (#5) our server, right to the guy bussing the tables, everyone made a nearly superhuman effort to welcome us and show something of their personalities. Under some circumstances that could have felt cloying, but with these folk it was totally genuine and not overdone. 

The dining area was up a narrow steep flight of stairs with the names of Philly neighborhoods written on the risers.  Good idea for keep our eyes where we were walking to avoid missteps.  The second story was bright with windows facing east, and yellow/gold painted walls all around. Lots of chachkas and potted plants. Channelle was to us in a blink, offering great coffee and mimosas/bloodies/orange juice.  The breakfast menu was a large page with their signature dishes - Hangover Sandwiches, Regular Breakfast Egg Sandies, Omelets, Waffles, etc. Even before ordering a Pastrami Omelet and Original Hangover creation, we received two homemade muffins compliments of the house.  Alcohol and bakery sweets gratis, just because...and, Josh stopped by to introduce himself and inquire where we were from and how we knew about CH2. Pleasant conversation.

I'm not a pastrami guy, but my companion sure loved the load of smoked beef, Swiss cheese and sautéed onions that filled her 3 egg plate.  My Original Breakfast Hangover Sandwich was a glorious monstrosity of 3 more eggs, garlic buttered sesame seed loaf, cheddar, sausage and their hash browns all in the mix.  Put hash browns inside my eggs and you know one of the keys to my soul.  With the first bite, my eyes involuntarily rolled to the back of my head, and I am told I emitted a low yowl. My inner wolf was free for a moment. Don't remember, but it was that good.  Don't think I bit anyone.

Doubtless, we will return to this or the other Coffee House Too in the near future.  We liked it a lot!

Second Street Bagels is under new management and working hard to up the quality of the rounders exiting their backroom oven. From my first bite this late September morning it seems they are succeeding. 

I was fortunate enough to ask the owner where the bagels were made, and he was happy to take me on an impromptu tour of the operation. I followed him behind the counter and through the kitchen door. The large boiling pot was full of brine and the rack was full of aluminum trays with bagels just out of their bath and chilling before going into the oven for finishing. I knew that the boil helped set the crust's consistency, and that lye or sugar/molasses water were traditionally the elixir of choice, but didn't know that brine was an option. 

It certainly worked to produce a excellent bagel. Thin crust. Nice bite. Pleasant mildly salty malty dense texture within. With sweet butter and nutty Swiss slices, it was an enjoyable bagel. Decent java, too. 

Wish Second Street Bagels well with its new ownership team.

PIZZA REVIEW:

Bacco Centro is a three store Italian chain in Bucks and Montgomery Counties specializing in fast casual pizza, salads, sandwiches and larger dishes in an attractive, comfortable environment. Their Richboro shop is the latest addition in the new commercial core of town on Second Street Pike. We stopped in for a late lunch after visiting Tanner's Farmers Market for our supply of fruits and veggies. Cat was our server.

The menu was interesting, but given the first time there and the hour of the day, we opted for their Brooklyn Pie with Meatballs, figuring we would have a small sample in house and take the rest home for the boys. As we waited, Cat brought us a small plate of cheese garlic bread. It was a pleasant forespice made from their pizza dough, but without plenty a garlicky pecorino. 
 
The square Brooklyn arrived on a thin wood server and was settled on a wire basket stand mid table. It looked great in red, white, green and brown. First bite impression was crisp, firm and flavorful. Cut into twelve squares the edges were firm and easily held their weight without equivocation. The red sauce was nicely done with strong hints of garlic, basil and salt, counterbalanced by the basil and mozzarella. It was outstanding! The reheat job at home this evening was nearly as good according to the accounts by our sons. 

Bacco deserves our pizza business given the paucity of quality tomato pie in Newtown (aside from Vince's). If their sandwiches and entrees are as good, they will have a long line of loyal customers.

The oldest movie theater in the USA, and a registered historic landmark and non-profit, the Newtown Theatre is a community treasure, playing current movies in an environment that brings you to the 1950's.  
The physical layout is as old as this suggests, with a tiny ticket booth and refreshment area that would fit in your closet.  Climb the narrow stairs to the balcony, and feel what it was like when your grandparents and great grandparents went on dates, and could only be alone in the dark with a chaperone between them.
A great old place, well worth the trip. 

PS. Check their website to see a photo in the snow in the New York Times. www.newtowntheatre.com.

Aside from the final battle of Yorktown, Virginia, where Lord Cornwallis surrendered the British Army to General Washington and marked the end of our colonization by the British Empire, the most important battles of the American Revolution were fought within 50 miles of this hollowed ground.  The two Battles of Trenton,  Battle of Princeton, and the crucial and tide turning Battle of Monmouth (NJ), determined whether we would be a failed rebellion or a new nation. 

When the smoke cleared, our banner still waved.

But, this place was where Washington showed his desperate genius, preparing for a night river crossing ten miles north of where the Hessian garrison in Trenton lay; hoping for a surprise attack on Christmas morning.  It did not go off as planned.  His generals south of Trenton in Bristol, Pa., were unable to cross the icy river and abandoned their attack.  The river spirits attempted to swamp, drown, and freeze our soldiers with a sleet onslaught that almost completely blinded the Massachusetts boatmen who repeatedly forded the river carrying men, horses, cannon and supplies to the Jersey side, using 18 foot oars and iron tipped spike poles to row and push the Durham Boats across and back.  Somehow, where the others failed, Washington and his ragtag army succeeded.  

The rest is now known as OUR history.   

It does not take a huge imagination to feel that this moment is still with us when fully present in Washington Crossing.  Most prefer to join the crowds for the reenactment of the crossings, but for me the true essence of history is most strongly felt in quiet moments in the early dawn or at dusk, when it is only me and the River.  Standing still on a cold winter eve or morn, facing the Delaware and closing my eyes, I can feel the weight of the moment that lay on Washington's shoulders.  Sleet in his eyes and dripping from his hat, he had only his faith in providence and his grim determination to comfort him.  If he failed, the grand notion of a free nation died in these frozen waters.  If he succeeded, he hoped to fight another day. 

It is in his success that we can acknowledge that our collective fate hung in the balance.

Formerly the Carversville General Store and Post Office, the Kitchen is a beautiful reuse of this early 19th Century structure in the enchanted Village of Carversville, Solebury Township, PA. Although only 20 miles from home as the crow flies, the trip back in time is considerably further. With its aging stone and wood and surrounding pre & post revolutionary ambiance, this is a travel destination accessable only by fantasy and time machine. It lies in the heart of what makes Bucks County so magical. 

Orders are taken at the cashier with options of fresh bakery goods, morning sandwiches and local roasted coffee from nearby Upper Black Eddy. You remember him, right?! Their Kenya mild roast was a superb blend that went down easy with a spot of milk. Kim worked the register and took ordered for the kitchen to fill. I went light with a fresh everything bagel and cream cheese to accompany the java. She delivered it to me at the small sitting shelve under the large paneled window. It was a decent bagel that allowed me to sit, munch and daydream about the days of Moses Doan and his clan of outlaws who lived in these parts as horse thieves and highwaymen at the time of the Revolution. Aside from the paved roads and iron horses, nothing much had changed. 

Everyone was very friendly and eager to talk to this stranger about the timeless life in this hamlet. I was equally eager to listen. Never know when you may meet someone who will change your life. 

This is just the place to pause and reflect on important things. Time and the creek passing through the center of this burg flow slowly and silently here, with an invitation to dive deep into its wellspring and avoid evanescence.

COVID-19 TAKEOUT REVIEW

These are the times that try our souls.

To grab a break from constant at home dining, at least two or three times a week we pick up takeout meals from either a place we haven't tried before, but has been bookmarked for a long time, or an old reliable that for some inexplicable reason had dropped out of the rotation. So it was with Primo Hoagies in the Glen Roc Center near Trenton-Mercer Airport in Ewing, NJ.
Nothing like a premium submarine sandwich on a fresh sesame seeded torpedo roll to pleasure and comfort a weary heart. And, Primo, the former Italian deli out of Philly that is now an expansive regional franchise, knows how to bring that iconic satisfying experience home. 

We ordered over the phone for curbside pickup and sent the 19 year old who is spending the rest of his college freshman year at home out to secure it. Ordering a Turkey Schwartzie (sliced roast turkey, Swiss, lettuce, tomato, sweet pepper relish and mayo),  Corned Beef Schwartzie, and traditional Roast Beef & Provo Hoagalone, at $10 per, we actually had enough for two meals after cutting them into quarters and mix/match sharing. Our separately purchased bag of uber crisp & spicy Herr's Jalapeno Potato Chips were the perfect counterpoint to the soft semi sweetness of the sandwiches. 

And, an outstanding mention is demanded for the wonderful bread encapsulating the quality ingredients. Those babies were so delicious with sesame seeds generously spread atop each creation that I could easily have been happy with just them and a shmear of butter. So good!

As we sat devouring dinner at the kitchen table we were able to forget the seeming war zone coronavirus had turned out peaceful community into for a few minutes and talk of normal things like before this disease ended our innocence. In times such as these, we must fully appreciate such moments together.

I didn't expect that I would be dealing five big ones for this cheesesteak, wings and burger joint in the Richboro Shopping Center. After all, this building had housed a few other restaurants over the past few years, none of them worthy of more than a passing taste test. Yet, D & M Philly Cheesesteaks and Wings, despite its longish and uninspired name, actually provided me with the best steak sandwich I have had in a while, and a very good burger, too. 

The dining room is barebones, with half a dozen tables, and Philly sports teams logos on the walls. I was doing take out, so the clean room was noted, but not utilized. I discovered there was a discrepancy between the printed and online menus, because when I ordered their Three Pepper Steak sandwich and Special Burger that I had seen online, I was being given the right steak, but a different burger. This led to a discussion with the woman taking my order and the chef about what was said and what was heard. The chef was unaware of the online version of the menu, and had not heard of the Special Burger. They both apologized for the confusion. It worked out fine. A new burger was prepared as I wanted it, and the original burger was given to me as well, without charge. That's the right way to handle the situation, and I appreciated their easy willingness to make things right and treat me well.

So, when I broke open the styro package and unwrapped the burgers, I beheld three beautiful sandwiches. They used brioche style rolls that were rich and tasty, with excellent texture. The Three Pepper (hot, sweet and green) were mixed into a large load of chopped steak, along with onions and mushrooms.  It was excellent. I could only eat half. The Special Burger was a 6 ouncer, grilled to the requested medium finish, and topped with lettuce, tomato, American cheese and Thousand Island dressing. Although not the grass fed/open range beef, it was still juicy and delicious. The rolls really added to the experience with their subtle sweetness and ability to hold together under the stress of huge bites. 

As a family with two sons who make cheesesteaks, burgers and wings a standard part of their diets, it was very good fortune to find this place not too far from home, that was so expert with a grill. No doubt, the wings will be sampled sooner than later, and D & M Philly Cheesesteaks and Wings will be toward the top of the list of places to go when that large itch must be scratched. 

Just hope they come up with a shorter name for their family enterprise.  Isn't "D & M," enough?

Great Jersey tomato pie comes to Levittown, PA.! 

You don't need to love DeLorenzos pizza and T pie cousin stores originally from Trenton, NJ, to appreciate the arrival of those delicious creations on the western banks of the Delaware. In fact, it is even better if you never heard of them and discover this new pizza parlor on New Falls Road on your own. 

When you do and wait the 30 to 60 minutes outside the entrance for a table to clear, and finally order a pie from a server in black and white, wait again to have it custom made just for you, and then climactically take your first bite, your will know this is something different than any slice you have had before.

The just right mix of flour, water and salt. The chunky tomato sauce with basil and a pinch of sugar. The high quality mozza that hides beneath the sauce that melts to a soft mellow. All this combined to offer a perfect chew that explodes on the palate like nothing you have experienced before from a "pizza."

Now, THAT is tomato pie! Not the upside down thing found in many joints. Not the pizza covered in heavy red gravy without any cheese. No. This is the real McCoy from Jersey that has finally arrived in Bucks to show pizza lovers how tomato pie is supposed to be done. 

Bring beer or wine and mange bien! 

You deserve it.

Happy Fourth of July, Yelpers!!!

MyThai Kitchen recently opened on Brownsville Road, Trevose, PA. It is in an old tiny strip with a narrow parking field right in front. Easy enough to get in, but a bit challenging when departing. Don't let that deter you, because once inside you enter a simple dining room with about a half dozen wood topped tables, and honest to goodness Thai dishes prepared with love and attention by folks who came naturally by their skills - they lived them from birth. No Thai pretenders here.

I was there for a late lunch, arriving just short of 3:00 to an empty house. I was greeted warmly by two women, one the chef and the other working the front room. They thanked me for coming, directed me to a table in the front corner and handed me their small double sided menu. I was in time for the lunch special. I ordered a small bowl of tom yum soup, drunken noodles with beef and an iced tea. I asked them to bring the heat. 

The soup was strongly spiced with lemongrass and loaded with veggies, including fresh mushrooms. The first spoonful took my breath away, but I adjusted to the spicy boil and enjoyed it the rest of the way. I asked for high flames and that was what I got. I was pleased they did not make any "cultural adjustment" for a presumed western pallette. The noodles were broad and mixed with peppers and other multicolored vegetables. Thin slices of grilled beef finished the plate, along with an excellent opulent brown sauce. Loved all of it. The 10% grand opening discount was another nice touch (without asking).

Service was attentive and attractive from the orange apron woman. She stopped by often to see how I was doing and to answer my questions. On my way out I asked to take a photo to memorialize my visit. My wish was granted. 

Take a look and tell me you wouldn't return as soon as possible for more authentic Thai cuisine!

The 5 Stars are not just for the style cut, but for the overall experience after stepping over the threshold of Artiva Salon.  

First, I was in Chinatown, which always has a slightly exotic (if also decrepit) atmosphere, especially on those narrow side streets between the numbers. Second, the door was tricky to open, requiring a grasp of the latch and hard tug on the knob.  Third, once inside the space seems rather small, with a row of numbered doors along the wall.  Fourth, there is a lot of art on the walls, some quite good.  Finally, there is Ying, the proprietress of the salon and its creative force.  She has a staff of a few people providing massage in the tiny rooms behind the doors, as well as a space for shampooing and scalp massage after the haircut.  

Ying has an interesting story to tell.  She began as a television reporter in China, and travelled extensively; somehow ending up in Philadelphia.  She has her art, and decided that cutting hair was a way to express her creativity and meet people.  

Upon assuming the throne I was handed a page of photos of the backs of men's heads and asked which style I liked.  This was my first attempt at a cut outside of a strictly American barbershop or salon, and with my tricky locks I was apprehensive that she could do more than just a generic shaping.  She assured me she knew what she was doing.  In made no difference as I was already draped with no place to run.  Okay.  I wanted an adventure, and I was about to suffer the consequences, or so my imagination suggested.  

Fear not!   Ying did a fine job while talking about many things.  Interestingly, she washed my hair after the cut, and massaged my scalp.  Very nice.  She knew how to handle this guy's longish wavies.  The damage?  $10 for the cut, wash and massage.  That is a deal and a half! 

Next time, I will plan for a foot massage as part of the spa treatment.   

Low budget? Definitely!  High entertainment and relaxation value?  No question!

I stepped back onto the dimming streets around 7:30, and headed over to Dim Sum Garden for a totally in character dinner.  But, that is another review.

For a Bucks County vineyard, Crossing Vineyards is as good as it gets in terms of beautiful scenery, comfortable surroundings and quality of wines available for tasting and purchase. It reminds of the wineries in Napa and Sonoma with small acreage producing some of the best vintages. It is easy to relax , sample the wares and at least for a few moments be transported to the left coast. 

This hacienda has been in the family for two generations, and the colonial home they live in looks the same as it did 200+ years ago (with better plumbing, electricity and fresh paint). Take a free tour of the grounds and production facilities, followed by a sit down on the patio in good weather to sip their award winning reds, whites and blushes. 

The most engaging choice is the dark rouge and somewhat sweet and dusky Chocolate Cherry Truffle. The Viognier white, Cabernet and Merlot also merit consideration. While head on comparisons with California wines may not grade out well in every instance, they are competitive, and save the time and treasure of traveling west. Sometimes a pleasant afternoon is all you need to get away. 

If you enjoy Crossing Vineyards it can be just the start of a magical mystery tour of the other Bucks County wineries that can make for a great weekend.

This 12 table Thai restaurant on Easton Road, Abington, PA, is a lovely well appointed dining room, cozy enough to feel slightly enchanted, and authentic enough to leave you satisfied that you just got your money's worth of delicious northern Thai cuisine. 

I was there for Saturday lunch. Finding their parking lot behind the building after cruising by the storefront, I walked in to a warm smile from the owner/server, who directed me to a deuce along the wall, a discreet distance from the two occupied tables. She went to the rear cashier area and returned moments later with a glass of water and the two menus available for dinner and lunch specials. She quietly explained the two lists and left me again to give me time to consider my choices. 

I went with the afternoon combo - a small cup of coconut lemongrass soup (Tom Ka) veggied up with fresh mushroom on top, a bisected spring roll with dark orange dipping sauce, and a fairly large plate of Pad Kee Mao (Drunken Noodles). Liking spicy food, I opted for the "Thai Spicy" end of the heat spectrum. It did not disappoint. It added burn sufficient to make my tongue sweat and nose run, stopping just short of numbing my gums. Certainly no compromise for this western pallette. Loved every morsel of the thick noodles, chicken, green & red pepper, onion and green beans. 

By the time I finished I was alone but for the pleasant owner. We talked for a few minutes about her business and our experience in Thailand. It was a genuine and interesting exchange, and an unexpectedly provocative dessert.

If you love old school urban street corner restaurants, you are going to think you died and went to heaven when you step inside Pete's Clown House, at the corner of Frankfort Avenue and Pike Street, in the Port Richmond neighborhood of Philadelphia. It is a tight squeeze going through the front door and passing along the counter, but I found a spinner right there, and had the exalted pleasure of watching the action of the cooks, assistants and servers, as they danced around each other taking care of the hot steel grill and the crush of phone take out orders, while always finding time to chat with those around them with a quip and a smile. 

This is definitely a greasy spoon dive, but in the best way possible. If you are entertained by fast hands and flying knives and spatulas, then there is no better theater in the City of Brotherly Love than a orchestra seat in the Clown House. You watch the action up close and personal, as take out orders are written directly on the white bags that will contain the food once cooked. No need for an order pad. And, if close enough to the grill, the occasional spattering of oil or home fries, or spitting bacon, will reach out to touch you gently, and remind you that there is no extra charge for the grease stains on your clothes. That iron is so full of food waiting to be off loaded onto plates or takeout boxes, that its amazing that the kitchen hasn't caught fire in the 66 years it has been slinging hash to the appreciative masses who have been scarfing their incredibly tasty dishes all this time. 

 "Delicious," is the right word for the food produced here. That grill is so well seasoned from decades of eggs, meats, potatoes, peppers and cooking oil, that it might be edible. The prices are cheap enough to be downright ridiculous. My sausage, egg and cheese sandwich on Kaiser roll, with a side of excellent home fries topped with sautéed onions and green peppers, all the hot java I could drink, came to less than $7. 

ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!

So, I had an incredible breakfast, a month's worth of local color, and full bore entertainment from the totally engaging staff, non-stop for the half hour or so I was indulging myself. Although a rookie, I felt at home and one of the regulars. I really didn't want to leave, but I finished eating, and the next customer was waiting to take my stool. 

Pete's Clown House - One of those places that defines what is so special about Philadelphia.

 Definitely, a must see.

It is time to bump up the stars for Bagel Stop to 5 Big Ones! In fact, it is long passed time to do so. Please forgive my absent mindedness. 

How do I know this is a supermax experience? 

Because I find myself thinking about their excellent bagels even when I don't plan to be there that day, and excited when I know it is my destination. These babies have addicted me. They are my opioids. 

The shop is still in the same location, and too small for tables and chairs. Yet, the master baker and his crew have perfected the onion bagel I prefer - firm skin, soft airy interior, and ample roasted onion flakes all around. When fresh from their ovens, they are plenty good enough to eat just as they come from the bin. If you time your visit just right, you can get them still warm from baking; nothing short of a completely memorable experience. Yet, even on the normal day when they have cooled and wait for your order in their bins, like puppies in the window of a pet store, they are simply a joy to consume with a heavy smear of favorite cream cheese (veggie, please!). 

I stopped in today for my weekly fix, and picked up a bag full for the family this weekend. I figured it's time to share the bagel bounty with those I love. 

They do muffins and breakfast sandwiches, too. They look zoftig, but I am more the purest, preferring my bagels the traditional way. Just slice, smear and get out of the way!

Cheesesteak Review -

Dino's is primarily a take out pizza joint on Street Road in Warrington, PA. We wanted to eat while the food was prime, and opted to mange at one of the three tables in the front of the house. Son and I were in the mood for steak sandwiches, although the pizza looked appealing.
 
This Saturday night they had a three person operation in the kitchen, with Dino on the grill. The room was a bit chilly on an early December night, even with the little space heater. Still, hunger and strong aroma of the beef being chopped and tossed by the chef overcame any temporary discomfort.  

The sandwiches were excellent. Fresh crusty rolls, huge load of grilled beef made in house and sliced just before touching hot steel to guarantee juiciness and surprisingly good flavor. A work of culinary art. 

We congratulated Dino for hitting the cheesesteak sweet spot, and assured him we would return. Never too far to go for a great Philly steak sammy. And, if the pizza is as good, the beginning of a long delicious relationship.

Apparently, this is the latest incarnation of a series of Banh Mi shops at this location, as a quick YelpCheck shows this place has had several names over the years, while working with the same people and offering substantially the same menu.  As Robert Burns wrote so well, "A rose by any other name would smell as sweet."

And, so it is for this small store on S. 8th Street just off Washington.  The space is clean, with about 7 tables, and a warm staff that is attentive, yet unobtrusive.  I had plenty of time to peruse the double sided laminated menu, but I really knew what I wanted coming in.  The rep here is about authentic Vietnamese Sandwiches, Banh Mi, although they also provide Pho, Vermicelli and Broken Rice dishes, along with a long list of VN Coffee and other beverages. 

The fresh ingredients are on display in the glass enclosed refrigerator that separated the customers from the food prep area.  The work on my meal was in plain view.  It arrived a few minutes after ordering on a white plate covered in sandwich paper.  The Baguette was fresh with crunchy crust and soft airy inners. The Grilled Pork was plentiful and cut into small pieces at the bottom of the sandwich valley.  Daikon Radish, Cucumber, Carrot, and Cilantro were piled on top and overflowing.  

I took a bite to start the proceedings, and was met with each of the components as they lustily exploded in my mouth.  Really a great first bite!  I added a squirt of Hoisin and Sriracha to bring up the volume a bit and to experiment to see how they would change the experience.  The Banh Mi was fine as it was, but I can be excessive when it comes to flavor, so the addition of both more BBQ flavor and Chili heat was pleasing. 

Café Tranh Truc also has a few HDTVs on the wall, so I was able to enjoy a rewatching of The Hurt Locker during dinner.  

The entertainment was free.

This Asian grocery, butcher, fishmonger, green grocer has been open right off Roosevelt Blvd @ St. Vincent Street for several years, having purchased the former 1st NE International Market in 2015. It is very similar to the supermarket at 6th and Washington in South Philly. It has just about everything you need for the complete Chinese kitchen, including pigs feet to fat green frogs, and dozens of vinegars and soy sauces for any dish imaginable. 

True, the odor of fish on ice and tanks full of lobster and talapia can be pungent, but that is part of the experience and brings me back to the street markets all across Southeast Asia. 

If you need it, they likely have it. If they don't have it, think twice whether it is really necessary. 

Even found those Japanese versions of KitKat Bars in strawberry and green tea flavors!

The diversity of opinion on the Yardley Inn & Bar reflect that there is some inconsistency in the delivery of the product here.  Luckily for me, I caught it on a great night when everything came together as the creators must have envisioned it.  

This was a business dinner for four.  As such, I had to be less obvious about my intention to write a review with my dinner mates, and kept my mobile phone in my pocket except for when the Tiers of Taste I ordered arrived.  Three plates placed vertically before me on a stainless steel frame that was tall enough to block my view of the person across the table.  We all exclaimed delightful surprise and I felt justified in taking a photo of this unexpected presentation.  That was just the beginning. 

The Decoy red from Buckthorn was a great pick by Tom.  I am not a wine expert, but my palate is sensitive enough to know when it is being seduced by gentle tanins. Gotta get me a case of that!  

The Marguerita Salad with Candied Walnuts, fresh Blue Cheese, and Tomato Vinaigrette was a cool sweet tart enjoyment.  My Tiers of Taste choices were Calamari with a Vinegar Pepper marinade/sauce, Pierogies and Stuffed Dates.  The squid was well fried, and the sauce was sweetly hot.  Pierogies with Onions and Sour Cream were softly pliant and offered a mild divergence from the stronger statement made by the calamari.  Finally, the Devils on Horseback (that's right), Chlorizo Stuffed into large Dates and Wrapped in Bacon, were a first that combined the luxurious flavor of excellent dates with finely ground Mexican Chorizo, girdled with well done Bacon.  I am not a bacon fan, but this was an exceptional experience.  It came together very well.  I was sated by this meal, and realized I had just come through a magic door that only a very extraordinary meal can open.  

Winnie, Jeff and Tom all seemed quite satisfied, but because we were having a serious conversation while we ate, I could not bring myself to ask to taste their food.  But, the Crabcakes, Lemon Chicken and Berkshire Pork Tenderloin all disappeared with sounds of satisfaction.  As we walked out we all commented on the exceptionality of the dinner.  

Yardley Inn sits at the bottom of Afton Avenue, directly across River Road from the Delaware River.  It has suffered repeated flooding, and now has an inflatable berm that can hold off all but the most ravaging floods.  Sure hope it works, even when patrons cannot reach it without a boat.  It is a sterling restaurant when the stars align and reflect deeply off the flowing river. 

Last night I saw a constellation of 5 stars.

Dealing with jewelers can be intimidating.  You seldom know what you are looking at, let alone a fair price for it, unless you are in the business.  

Harry Merrill & Son, a third generation enterprise on South 8th Street in Jewelers' Row, does its best to make the experience of shopping and buying from them as informative and relaxing as possible (Let's face it, when spending a lot of money some anxiety is bound to creep in).  They are in no rush to sell you anything.  They ask plenty of questions to understand what you want, and are willing to show you many alternatives on the way to honing in on the bauble you seek. And, if they don't have exactly what you want, they can probably find it quickly and still make a good deal. 

I have visited them a lot of late for a variety of reasons, and discovered that Rob Schwartz (Don't blame him for his predecessors choosing an Anglicized name for the family shop) is open and genuine; that his mother is still hard at work and has an amazing knowledge of the Philadelphia gem scene over many generations, and that the rest of his staff is well trained in people skills.  They make the jewelry purchase experience as transparent and no-pressure as possible. 

Always comparison shop, but when you are ready to buy, be sure to visit Merrill.  You may find yourself wishing that you went there first.

I stopped into Euro Delights while visiting the various tasting rooms around Skippack on the Winter Wine Fest on a sunny, but cold Saturday afternoon in January.  There was a vineyard sharing its wares in a back room, but with the people two and three deep waiting for a pour, I knew the better move was to take a comfortable seat at a small window table away from the crowd, and to order one of Euro's exceptionally delicious bakery gem.  

I settled in, but decided to walk into the retail section of the old converted home to se what was under glass.  One of the owners/sisters remembered me from the earlier visit, and introduced me to her partner in the biz. After a nice chat about their success and desire to expand, I selected a square of Washington Cake and Coffee to be brought to my table.  

The cake was loaded with nicely spiced apples and a vanilla cake-like mix.  The texture was pleasantly chunky and mildly sweet with brown sugar and cinnamon accents.  The top was a Lemon Crème icing-one of my favorite flavors for pastry.  The overall impact was fun and totally satisfying.  I ate it as slowly as possible to stretch out my enjoyment. Luckily, the front dining room was not too crowded, and I did not feel rushed.  

This stop at Euro Delights confirmed what I experienced the first time.  This is a fine bakery and café where the creativity of the baker and the warmth of the environment the proprietresses evoke mark Euro Delights as a one of a kind establishment where goodness translates directly to the taste buds.

One door closes and another opens...Such is the Circle of Life.

Giovanni's Custom Tailoring has opened in the space formerly occupied by its predecessor, Frank DeRito Men's Clothier.  Dino continues to tailor expertly and bring his warm, cosmopolitan charm and gifted abilities to the same location where he has worked for more than a decade.  

I recently ordered a suit (S. Cohen of Montreal) and had Dino make the necessary fine tuning adjustments for my long arms and legs.  All done at a very reasonable price.  He is truly a master of the needle and thread, and knows before I do what will look good on me.  

Hopefully, Giovanni's will carry the same quality clothing as Frank DeRito, and will likewise have the great sales when exceptional suits, jackets, coats, sweaters, shirts and ties can be purchased at prices not normally associated with high end Newtown. 

At least, I can pray that happens.

When Lynn's was open, and Leo was scooping out wisdom along with his personally roasted coffee beans, this shop had to be one of the best places in the region to pick up a bag of beans after discussing you tastes with the Man. It was from Leo I discovered Tanzanian Teaberry, and some of his own mystical blends. 

Sadly, the storefront is now closed.

But, all is not lost.  The Grapevine on North State Street, just one block away now has Lynn's coffee for sale with many of the most popular varieties still in large burlap bags for sampling.  Chuck, the owner of Grapevine is more than happy to fill your order.  While his book of knowledge is quite different than Leo's, he has more than his share of great tales to tell.  

By all means, buy your coffee here, and while you're at it, pick up some organic veggies, and your nutritional supplement needs.  Very cool store if you can find the front door behind the wall of hanging potted plants surrounding it.

Walking back through Skippack Village after Winetober Fest and a Brasserie 73 dinner, we came across a bakery café looking place in another old house on the main drag.  I wanted coffee to accompany us back home, and approached the front door to have a better look through the windows.  I saw a display case full of attractive pastries and wanted a closer look and sniff. 

Turned out that Euro Delights is run by two sisters from Finland who have been here for many years, but still possess a delightful accent and a old world sense of comfort and taste.  The kitchen in the back is visible from the retail shop, and with the ovens just recently turned off for the evening, the aroma of cake and hot fruit and sugars wafted throughout.  Coffee alone would not be enough. 

We shared a fresh miniature Apple Pie topped with Whipped Cream and a dusting of Cinnamon.  A personal pie scaled down to the size of a huge muffin.  Locally sourced ingredients made this an exceptional taste experience. The apple was sweet and surrounded by its juices. The brown sugar crumble on top was fun and firm to the bite.  The crust was excellent.  With the whipped cream adding a softness and subtle undertone, the entire desert was perfect.  

With the rage over cupcakes in full bloom, it was only a matter of time before a creative baker would take it to the next level - personal sized pies. Maybe this is already being done, but it is new for me. 

We ate alone in the dining area across the center hall from the shop.  It was full of small tables, colorful walls and curtains.  It felt like we had stepped into a time capsule as the décor was mid-nineteenth century. 

Definitely worth a drive to Skippack for Brunch and Pie, or one of the other tempting delights under the Euro sign.  Euro Design has only been open for 5 weeks, but their future is bright if they keep producing wonderful pies and cakes.

I admit that I am a late convert to the value of a shop that specializes in olive oil and balsamic vinaigrette.  I never thought they offered enough of what shoppers wanted and would pay premium prices for.  I was wrong. 

Tubby Olive has graced State Street in Newtown Borough for a few years, and has even opened another shop in Doylestown.  Walking in, the aroma of spices greets you, suggesting a casbah in Marrakesh or old Italian deli off Washington in Philly.  Large bottles and metal containers surround the room on shelves, everything labeled.  The staff is very friendly and informative, and takes pleasure in turning a customer on to new flavor sensations.  

The garlic infused oils with secondary spices are amazingly subtle, and have your palette engaged as if drinking fine wine.  My fave are the fruity balsamics, especially the Black Cherry and Raspberry, which just surprise the taste buds with their soft sweet tartness.  On a fresh salad they are outstanding. 

I inadvertently visited recently when hungry, and found myself dipping the offered bread repeatedly into one of the many samples and eating them until I was nearly full.  I am sure I was obvious, but no one complained nor hovered near to deter me.  That was one of the finest and unusual meals I have had in a long while.  

After that, I had to buy some of what I had tasted, just so I didn't lose face.  It was well worth it, although at those prices I couldn't do it often.

So glad I finally made it here to sample the heat of Chili Szechuan. 

My friends from Chengdu are living in New York for several months, and this was their first visit to Philadelphia. After showing them around the shut down historic sites in Old City (Carpenters' Hall was open), they wanted to see the Penn campus. They were hungry, and Chili Szechuan jumped to mind. Why not give them some home cooking?  They would tell me how authentic the cuisine was.

Driving up Baltimore Avenue for the first time since living at 48th and Baltimore back in the day, I was impressed with the changes on the street.  So much positive street life. And, right in the middle of the 4600 block sat Chili Szechuan.  Parking right across the street. We were in luck!

We started with Dumplings with Chili Oil and Dan Dan Noodles with Ground Pork. Both were as good as I have ever had. Spicy, succulent, and about 3 Alarm on the Volcano Scale.  We followed with Shredded Pork with Green Pepper (5 Alarm), Lotus Root with Pickled Garlic (3 Alarm) and BenBen Chicken (4 Alarm).  All varied as to heat, texture, and undertone. The BenBen is served cold and in skin.  All enjoyable.  But, I wanted to know what my friends thought of the dishes. 

They devoured almost everything on the table covered with dishes. They are both small people, so I was amazed how they managed to eat more than I did.  Halfway through the meal they asked the waiter where the chef was from.  When he said, Chengdu, they said they were also from the city. A minute later he exited the kitchen and sat down with us to talk about home.  They switched from Mandarin to Chengduese (a subdialect of Szechuanese), and I was lost.  But, through their animated conversation I knew they were comparing notes about their lives here and in China. My friends clearly loved the food.  They exchanged business cards, and hoped to see each other again next time in Philadelphia. 

As we walked out, and the owner/chef said goodbye again, my friends thanked him for the best meal they had eaten in the USA.  It was like being home in their own kitchen.  I took that to mean that they were very happy with the meal. 

Seeing their enjoyment, and tasting the authenticity of the dishes, Chili Szechuan is as good as it gets for real Szechuan cuisine in this city.  Some might find the small confines of the shop more suitable for take out, and the single unisex bathroom a bit unpleasant, but if you are looking for the real deal in hot, spicy, numbing food, this is your Shangri-La.

10.27.13 - Ok. Here's the skinny on a comparison with Han Dynasty.  There really is none. While both have quality Szechuan style cuisine, the similarities stop there.  Han D is an upscale attractive forum for taking a date to an impressive dinner.  It is pricey and self aware of the experience it is creating.  Chili S could care less about that. It is in business for one reason - to turn out totally authentic hot numbing dishes that leave you in tears, and wondering when your tongue will come back online.  The atmosphere is basic Chengdu heat, as you find on every street and alley in the burgs of Szechuan Province.  It is small and unassuming.  There is only one bathroom.  You can hear the cooks arguing in the kitchen and the woks and pans banging on the stove.  But, if food is what you care about, and you are lucky enough to be with someone who really enjoys unpretentiousness and loves you for your own, then you can save a bundle tonight, and impress her next week with HanD. Both provide a REAL experience on the opposite ends of the lux scale.

The best way to experience the Battleship New Jersey is to arrange an overnight stay on the ship.  You sleep in a seaman's coffin-sized bunk in the bowels of the leviathan, eat in the original mess halls, climb and descend the steep stairs, and tour almost every aspect of the operations from the huge 16" gun turrets to the bridge where its captains directed naval warfare against enemies from World War II through Vietnam and Lebanon. 

My son and I had this privilege when he was a cub scout a few years ago.  While he and his mates had no idea what this warship accomplished in its gloried history, and they were just having fun in an amazingly different reality, we dads who came along looked long and hard at the steel blue gray surrounding us.  We knew where this battle wagon had been since 1942; we listened to the number of engagements in which it had participated, the Presidents who had come aboard, and the death dealing it had dished out and absorbed in the cause of our freedom.  It was humbling and at the same time, prideful. 

When they talk of, "Jersey Strong," this is what they really mean.  "Don't Tread on Me?"  That used to mean something. "Don't F**k With New Jersey," now, that still means exactly that. Asleep on the Camden Waterfront is the beast that helped turn the War in the Pacific into one of our greatest triumphs. 

Visit this hero with your family and say, "Thank You!"

"We're not authentic...But, we keep it real..." 

Amen, Brothers!

Real is what it is, and authentic is not required when the creativity and downright fun quotient is so high in what these dudes turn out.  

We showed up Saturday afternoon when the place was nearly deserted and took a table in the corner nearest the bar.  The place was sunny and as colorful as a Chinese carnival.  Cues of Asian influences abounded, but did not carry the final impression, which was far more idiosyncratic.  Our server fit her part perfectly.  She was alert, funny, cool and ready to engage.  

We were here for a quick stop before other errands.  We ordered only three small plates: Pork Soup Dumplings, Roast Pork Bao and Turnip Cake.  The Happy Buddha and Narragansett Beers were worthy companions.  Each dish was distinctive.  It suggested Chinese cuisine, while tasting quite different.  The Dumplings were tasty and fun.  Once the top knot was bitten off and the Miso Ramen Broth sucked out, the Ginger Vinegar was poured in through the vent, making the Pork Filling tart and a joy to eat.  It was a hybrid taste of slightly thick dumpling skin and Japanese infused innards.  Very nice. 

The Roast Pork Bao was large and golden on top.  The consistency was right for a bun, but it also strongly suggested Kreplach to this Jewish palette. If my grandmother had been Chinese and Jewish, she might have created this masterwork.  It was like putting together a taste puzzle figuring out what this hollow doughball reminded of.  The Long Hots, Spinach and Provolone offered the possibility that someone's Italian aunt had a finger in this recipe.  

Finally, the Turnip Cake was the biggest surprise.  It was made from Matzo Meal, Maple and Bonito, with a Fried Egg on top.  Again, my Polish/Jewish grandmother could not have done better.  It played with my tongue; teasing me to decide what it was all about.  It was delicious, but decided not Chinese.  

"...a Willing Mind and a Willing Stomach," 

Yeah! You got that right.

After a second stop in for a few more slices to find out if Gabriel's pies were as good as first impressions, I am very happy to report that they are even better than remembered! 

Our Italian Sweet sausage and Fresh Mushroom reheaters were requested well done, and that super heated scorched bottom was just perfect. Rigid chassis. High point. Great crunching bite. Balanced sweet/salty sauce. Quality sausage and white thick slices shrooms. 

Loved it so much I thought I was across the Delaware River in Jersey. 

Gabriel come blow your horn.

The Benjamin Franklin Parkway (originally called the Fairmount Parkway until 1937) was designed as the centerpiece of the City Beautiful urban design movement of the late 19th Century.  Often compared to the Champs-Elysees in Paris because of its width and anchoring by key public monuments and edifices, in fact, it looks little like that famous roadway, but is truly an American take on European classical architecture and urban planning, talked about since the Civil War to signify a "model of an orderly, classical metropolis, crisscrossed by boulevards and dominated by stately groups of public buildings." And, true to that description, the buildings along its traverse from City Hall to the foot of the Art Museum, are what make this diagonal slash through Center City so dramatic, culturally worthwhile, and give the roadway its importance and stately beauty.  

The emergence of these structures began in 1864 when the Cathedral of Peter and Paul was completed at 18th and Logan Square. Thereafter, in 1876 The Academy of Natural Sciences opened at 19th and the Parkway. In 1901 Philadelphia City Hall was finished.  Ground for the actual roadway was not broken until 1907, although plans for it had gone through several iterations until then - delayed by political considerations.  The final design was not approved until 1917, when actual construction commenced. The Swann Memorial Fountain in the middle of Logan Square started flowing in 1924. The Free Library main branch began lending books in 1927, and the first part of the Pennsylvania Museum (later renamed the Philadelphia Museum of Art) admitted its first visitors in 1928. Rodin Museum followed in 1929 at 22nd and the Parkway, and The Franklin Institute opened at its current location at 20th and the Parkway in 1934. Moore College of Art & Design moved to its campus on 20th Street in 1959; the Barnes Foundation in 2012 between 20th and 21st Streets. There are many other buildings along the Parkways length contributing to its overall grandeur.  

Although Philadelphia is a city of neighborhoods, what gives this town its national and international identity (in addition to cheesesteaks and pretzels) are the Benjamin Franklin Parkway and all that is found along its length and breadth.
