From City Hall to the Art Museum, this space is where people meet for special events, from 4th of July concerts and fireworks, to the Papal visit and National Football League Draft.  It has a deserved reputation for a great party venue that has only improved with the new skyline in western Center City and the emergence of West Philly across the Schuylkill River as an educational and commercial center in view beyond the museum to the west.  It attracts pedestrians, bicyclists and motorists to survey its graceful imposing reality. It is a great place for people watching.  The addition of restaurants and cafes within a few blocks of the Parkway, make it also a cool place to find anything from a nosh to full dinner.  

The only place better to capture the essence of the city is to get up to the Belmont Plateau on a late afternoon and take in the panorama of Center City from that vantage point. You can do both spots as part of one excursion, then come back; find a place to park, and explore the great collections and histories that populate the Parkway.

The Singer One sewing machine purchased through Amazon was a beaut, but came without power cord and foot pedal. A mistake to buy sight unseen. But, these parts shouldn't be too hard to find. Right? Thus began an unexpected adventure in sourcing spare parts in the arcane world of sewing machines. 

The company didn't offer parts on their website, and recommended only their few dealers around the country. Too, they weren't pleased that their equipment appeared to have fallen off a truck somewhere to be scavenged for the missing parts. The old Philly warehouse shops dealt only in industrial strength sewing factory parts and couldn't help out, although they expressed understanding of this predicament. 

Next stop was a small sew & vac store in Northeast Philly, who took a $20 deposit promising to order the pieces and notify when they came in. When called 6 weeks later to check on the status, they hadn't received them yet, but left the distinct impression they hadn't done anything but stuffed the $20 in their pocket. (A review of that enterprise is upcoming after I return to get back the cash.)

Two weeks ago I noticed a small shop in Newtown that handled vacuums and sewing machines. Looked to be a recent addition to the business community. What the heck?! I stopped in to inquire. Greeted by Sandor, the owner, I explained the situation as he listened patiently. He advised I bring in the machine and his expert mechanic would check it out. I dropped off the still boxed machina a few days later. 

The following week Sandor called to say that he could order the new parts if I wished, or he could provide used cord and pedal already in his possession from another job. Sounded like a good idea, and yesterday I picked up the parts and happily paid his price. He actually dropped it a fin in support of the visit to the other dealer I was going to ask to refund the $20. He was sure, as I was, that those guys would have had the parts in hand if they had been ordered. 

It was great to do business with an honest man who went out of his way to get something done out of the ordinary purchase and repair services he routinely offered. 

Makes me wish I had gone to him before Amazon and experienced direct satisfaction.

It has been too long since I visited Barbie's for one of their exquisite pretzel dogs - all beef garlicy homemade weiner topped with jalapeño, sauteed onion and American cheese - all wrapped up in one of their freshly doughed, twisted, salted and baked pretzel skins. 

Eat'em while they're hot for peak actualization. 

Today their drink special was a Pumpkin Latte Shake. A good, cool, sweet gourdy slush that epitomizes Halloween. The small 6 ounce cup was $4.25, including a free hand twister. 

Pennsylvania Dutch comfort food par excellence.

If you have been cruising Mill Street over the past few decades you know that it has had better days, but also that a few brave urban pioneers have jumped into the breech and begun new businesses that seem to be taking root.  Calm Waters Coffee Roasters shows what dedication and imagination can do to turn around a main street in a struggling neighborhood. 

The room is well renovated to feel about 1969, with exposed brick walls, sanded and polished narrow slat wood floors, and a tin panel-looking ceiling, that may not be authentic, but sure adds to the great ambiance here.  

The coffee is roasted right in the middle of the house and served hot, fresh and new.  Guatemala seems to be the source of the beans, and the owner's TLC in producing a quality product is obvious.  The taste of the java is bright and subtle, and a pleasure to drink.  I will bring a bag home the next time I stop in before court.  

They call themselves 'coffee roasters' for a reason.  That is what they are here to do.  Yet, they know people want to sit and enjoy their Cuppa Joe, and the room is well suited for a quiet conversation at one of the deuce tables.  Still, it is not yet a café as the offered accompaniments are not as good as the coffee at this point.  There is no grill for breakfast or lunch plates.  They provide instead a few pre-packaged bakery things like muffins, and a decent microwave oatmeal that they will heat and serve. There is a Panini press that toasts and stripes one at a time. How much better Calm Waters will be when they are able to install a short order kitchen for early breakfast, late brunch and midday lunch.  

Regardless of what the future holds, the present is impressive enough (in a quiet way) to warrant high praise.  

It has been too long since a Mill Street morning provided good reason to return.

After a second stop in for a few more slices to find out if Gabriel's pies were as good as first impressions, I am very happy to report that they are even better than remembered! 

Our Italian Sweet sausage and Fresh Mushroom reheaters were requested well done, and that super heated scorched bottom was just perfect. Rigid chassis. High point. Great crunching bite. Balanced sweet/salty sauce. Quality sausage and white thick slices shrooms. 

Loved it so much I thought I was in Jersey. 

Gabriel come blow your horn.

Oh, Danny Boy....

Why so unassuming?  Why hidden in a forlorn strip of 20th Century retail excess?  

Why aren't you sharing your gift with the entire Tomato Pie craving world? 

The lights. The lights are calling...!

Your T. Pie is among the best I have sampled in my pizza-loving life.  It is in the local pantheon of greatness occupied only by a few other mozzarella souls - DeLo's, JoJo's, Ivy Tavern, Joey's, and a few others in the Mecca of the Pizza Universe, Brooklyn. 

Micro thin crust firm enough to hold the topside without a quiver.  Sauce, chunky and mildly sweet with a hint of basil. Cheese hidden beneath with a gentle saltiness to balance the smiling acidity above.  Not a single drop of oil on the aluminum tray despite a spritz of pressed olive applied as the final touch before reaching the oven.  And, the sweet Italian sausage, home grown, and crumbled around the disk amply, with a wonderful aroma and fresh textured taste.  

Though you labor in obscurity, Danny, your artistry is not lost on those who treasure the magic only a steamy right out of the oven slice of heaven can provide.

Just had a great breakfast at Bullard's American Cafe on Saturday morning. It took me by surprise that Warrington possessed what I enjoy most from a early day meal - old school charm, slightly worn yellow Formica counter, deeply involved husband and wife ownership with the former on the grill and later working the front of the house making customers feel like valued members of the family. And, let's not forget, exceptional food and warm friendly service.

We sat on a couple of spinners at the window end of the counter. Paige approached us with a bright smile, bobbed blond hair, and menus. She and the two other young women in black worked non-stop to keep up with the rush that seemed to follow us in and quickly filled up the booths, tables and stools. Luckily, we ordered ahead of the tidal wave, and received our platters in a few minutes. 

I went with a short stack of french toast covered in strawberries, bananas and blueberries (red, white & blue). A smear of butter and pour of syrup (maple?) and I was a happy guy. The taste of the egg/vanilla mix saturated the bread and was grilled to optimum; cooked through and through with caramelized edges. Loved it! 

Our other dish, Famished Farmer, was a special egg mix with potato, onion, ham and tomato, with a side of homefries; also solid and enjoyable. A black pepper shake or two brought up the flavor. We would ask for Tabasco next time to set it on fire. The homefries had great texture and taste. 

We learned Bullard's offered dinner Thursday and Friday evenings. Meatloaf? Yes! Be seeing you again soon!

Legend tells of a mythologic Blue Moose that traveled the spiritland and Doan hills around New Hope and the north river highlands. From time immemorial it was the guardian that helped those hurt by natural, supernatural and even manmade acts, survive and repair their damaged bodies and souls.  Its gifts to all were amazing strength, nurturing support and a supply of local foodstuff to aid in recovery. It was also known for dexterity on the mandolin.  It seldom took sides. It was only there to observe and assist with sustenance and music.  

Over the centuries Blue Moose has taken various forms animate and inanimate. An accomplished shape shifter, it appeared when the need was dire in a form acceptable in the current cultural milieu. It helped sustain our men during the Revolution, and helped build the longboats that made the Christmas eve crossing. Currently, it assumed the guise of a restaurant in a small old house on Mechanic Street in New Hope, Pa. Always brash, it has not bothered to hide its identity. 

It sits in plain sight.  Café Blue Moose welcomes all to rest within its aging walls and taste its well honed victuals at any of its tables. 

It was within these atmospherics that we arrived for an early dinner last Friday evening, climbed the stairs to the second floor and took control of the middle table overlooking the open space down to the front room.  Open paper umbrellas hung down gently spinning in the air currents.  Stars were painted on the exposed cathedral ceiling.  Period pieces on the walls completed the sense that we were encouraged to take leave of normalcy and enter the world of whimsy, where we could best appreciate the decompression from reality.  BYOB aided the transformation. 

Our servers were lighthearted and sincere.  The menu a prix fixe affair allowing choices in any combination of Apps/Salad/Soups, Entrees, and Desserts that added up to 2 or 3.  Our choices were to share a Warm Goat Cheese Salad; Braised Short Ribs and Sautéed Salmon; and a Apple Crisp finale. The salad was a nice green plate with local leaves, Hazelnuts, sliced tart Green Apple and Dried Cherries in Balsamic Vinaigrette .  A round fried Goat Cheese ball was indeed hot, smooth, and subtle.  The parts played very well together and was a delight.  

The Short Rib was already off bone having bathed a few hours in red wine and garlic.  The meat was sitting atop Garlic Mashed, and under a strong helping of Pickled Cabbage and Carrots.  The taste was mildly sweetly vinegar inspired, and completely pliant.  The Mashed and Rib sauces were blood brothers, bringing the best of both when combined.  Symbiotic to the max.

The Salmon was a reasonably sized steak on top of small grain White Rice Risotto.  It, too, had a pickled topside that tasted of onion/mango, but was likely something else.  It was finished well and easy to eat, although there with an unidentifiable aftertaste that was less enjoyable than the primary sensation.  A small nit in an otherwise inspired meal.  

Finally, the Warm Apple Crisp was a fun crunchy a la mode mess with an oat/brown sugar crumble that was a joyful indulgence.  

All the while, Blue Moose played his music in the background, completing a near-epic experience.  His mandolin put aside for a heavy bass line for rock melodies that soothed and awakened appreciation of meal and history.  

As we stepped out into the snowfall and gathered our memories of what had just transpired, the sense that Big Blue was with us in deed and spirit was palpable.  We thanked him for his faithfulness and skilled metamorphosis into a shelter that was exactly what was needed in this age of doubt and cynicism.

If Korean Fried Chicken & Wings are your desire, then Chicko Tako in the Market at the Fareway in Chestnut Hill should be high in your list of destinations. Not only do you receive the benefits of excellent double fried cluckers in amazing sauces, but also the added bonus of being in a multiverse street fair community market that includes a brewery/pizza outlet, bakery, cafe, sushi shack, green grocer and butcher. So, you can cobble together the meal of your choice with ease without moving more than 100 feet in any direction, and dine in a common eating area shared by all. Delicious and impressive. 

My 6 wing plate with sweet & spicy sauce took about 20 minutes to prepare. I was handed a buzzer to alert me when ready. In the meantime I secured a pint of pumpkin ale from Chestnut Hill Brewery as well as a seat at a long table with views overlooking an outdoor dining area. The place was crowded with folks doing more or less the same as me. When my buzzer started vibrating I asked the people next to me to watch my beer while I picked up the wings. They were happy to help me out. 

The wings were on a beautiful rectangular ceramic plate on top of a tray. They glistened a dark red amber glow from the perfectly pitched sauce covering them. Three small pieces of celery and tiny cup of sour cream completed the meal. Exchanging the buzzer for the tray, I returned to my seat. The six wings were crunchy and meaty enough to sate me. The sauce was indeed both sweet and hot, and twisted my taste buds playfully. The cool, pungent ale was an excellent chaser, cutting through the heaviness of the sauce just enough to enjoy it again with each piece devoured. 

Chiko Tako has both wings and half/whole cut up birds for sale, and they do primarily takeout from their stand in the market. The people there are friendly and efficient. They know they are a success, yet it has not gone to their heads. 

Especially in combination with the other possibilities in the market, Chicko Tako is a great place for a street food snack.

Gentrification hasn't made it to N. 9th Street in the Callowhill neighborhood of Philadelphia. If it had, places like New Town Restaurant would be a roaring success spreading its Greek kitchen tentacles throughout the city like so many others who have become household names. Instead, New Town has scuffled along the past thirty years, one family turning out incredible breakfasts and lunches for those who live nearby or are fortunate enough to have found this hidden in plain sight tattered glory of a luncheonette. 

Maria and Peter ("The best cook in Philadelphia."), are the front and back of the operation. She has the natural charm of your great aunt hostess, and he the stubbled smile and broad shoulders of a man who has been slinging hash for most of his life. The house looks like it was last renovated in the '90s, with Formica table tops and shiny plastic covered benches.

But, none of this would be worth imagining if the food exiting the kitchen wasn't equal to the narrative. Believe me, it is. 

Our breakfast exceeded expectations. My veggie omelet with added feta and home fries thrown in the 3 egg mix was homemade excellent, with rye toast and bottomless coffee for under $9. My partner in crime went with their lamb gyro sandwich with Maria's famous tzatziki sauce. It was among the best seasoned grilled lamb and white sauce I've tasted. With tip everything was $20. 

Yes, New Town Restaurant lacks pizzazz, nor any sexy millennial attractions. Developers may even tear it down when the next wave comes through, which would be a crying shame. But, what it has is all it needs. 24/7 authenticity, owners who have lived their lives within its walls for a generation, and real food that just doesn't quit.

The 800 block of South Broad Street, Trenton, NJ, has new life in the form of Finca Cafe, a Columbian coffee house standing where an old grocery store once did business. It is beautifully renovated with new floors and walls, but with well preserved tintype ceiling, painted black to fit into the overall tone of the shop.

There are small tables in the window wells in either side of the front door, a naugahyde love seat against the wall, and a few more deuces further back for those who prefer to drink their java right from the expresso machine before it cools. I chose a table facing front so to watch the world go by. I ordered a latte and panebouno, a fresh homemade cheese bread roll with excellent flavor and texture. 

The beans were roasted at Calm Waters, Mill Street, Bristol. Obviously high quality beans, roasted perfectly by the good folks at Calm Waters, where I have had the pleasure of the joe on several occasions. The roll was delicately sweet with light cheese flavor. Liked it muchly. 

It was very nice to see local residents with Columbian roots take control of their economic lives and become entrepreneurs in support of their families and community. They are proud of their success and happy to project their business acumen onto customers by extroverted behavior that made me feel very welcome. Their willingness to give the history of their enterprise and patiently answer questions, allowed their passion for their work shine through. 

I expect to become a regular customer of Finca Cafe as it is less than a mile from my Trenton office. It will be a great place to meet clients and plan meetings with a small group. 

May their coffee always be strong!

What a terrific natural and historic resource Tyler State Park is!
Looping trails traversing a hilly topography; good for hiking, biking, walking. Find the old homesteads in the park that reflect what this area looked like in 18th Century rural Pennsylvania, and occupied today by families renting them from Bucks County on long term leases. 

 Discover the beautifully rebuilt covered bridge over Neshaminy Creek, a great place for photos and dreams.  Rent a horse for a few hours.  Scramble up the foot trails along the narrow streams and get lost in time.  In July, find your own secret blackberry patch and pick your own, eating them and tasting their sweet essence.  Watch out for the thorns!

  Rent a canoe and paddle upstream and out of sight of civilization.  Jump in the water and cool down.  Watch kids swing out over the flow from a rope tied to a high overhanging branch, and Geronimo into the water.  Walk along the creek bank and find an arrowhead among the river rock.  

So much to do, so well utilized by we who know it.  

Take a deep breath and appreciate the moment.

It's funny how so many people state their bagel bona fides by proximity to New York City. You know, "I'm from the City, so I know bagels..." 

Sorry, I was born and raised there myself (Washington Heights), and I've had some great bagels in all 5 boroughs, but also sampled pretty bad ones in all corners of the Apple; often in the same neighborhood. True, soft water from old wooden water mains helps, but nothing takes the place of a great recipe and patience. So, the truth is there are awesome bagels to be had almost everywhere the proper ingredients and skills are present. That includes just about anywhere in the Eastern USA, and any bakery close to sea level. 

So, not sorry.

The Bagel Cafe in Delran, NJ, is but one example. It looks innocuous enough in a bland Rt.130 North shopping center in the middle of Burlington County. But, it would be a mistake to pass on it out of a mistaken assumption that nothing exceptional could come out of an oven there.

 Au contraire, Mon Frere. 

That Onion Bagel overlain with Veggie Cream Cheese was a true delight. Its texture was perfect - firm crunch on the outside; airy light texture within. Mild sour flavor perhaps from the brief bath in boiling water with brine or lye to toughen its skin, yet not too much kneading to harden its tender heart. Piquant spread to pull the varied elements together. 

True, I think I detected a soft Russian accent from the women behind the counter. That would give them an edge in understanding the cultural imperatives of a true bagel, but whatever their secret, their creation had me imagining old country roots in the villages outside Kiev. 

Outstanding work, my friends!

South Broad Street in Trenton, NJ, is always struggling with the birth pains of renewal. This capital city has had more false starts than a drunk runner waiting for the sound of the starter's pistol. Yet, there are signs of life springing up as a few pioneering entrepreneurs open shop amongst the crepitation of this down trodden burg. Look closely and you can find cafes, restaurants, and now an ice cream parlor flowering in the surrounding weeds. 

Trenton Ice Cream Parlor opened recently in this part of South Trenton. It brings color and verve to this forlorn street, with a three table curbside deck and sidewalk cafe feel, new sign and lighting around the front steps, door and windows of this converted row house. Inside, is more of the same stimulation, with the addition of friendly servers and cashiers who are genuinely happy to see you. 

The flavor choices are about a dozen, with Peanut Butter Swirl and Caramel Pretzel my choices in a three scoop cup. It's hard to explain the incongruity of finding creative flavors for cones, sundaes, and the like, where city grime has persisted for decades. Very happy that it is there, but somewhat disconcerting, nonetheless. 

I sampled my ice cream as I drove home to Bucks. It was quite good, even if falling short of spectacular. It was creamy sweet with plenty of ribbons of peanut butter and chunks of pretzel, mixed in a solid vanilla and caramel base. The price for this "small" cup of three scoops - $3 and change. That's about half what I paid recently for a similar quantity across the river. Clearly, the rent in Trenton is a serious consideration for folks looking for a place to start a retail business. 

My Trenton office is farther north in South Broad, but close enough to attract me when this viciously hot summer demands chill relief. Yes. I will be back.

Remarkable.

Some Italian places are really just about pizza and sandwiches, with a nod to traditional dishes to attract people who want more than a couple of slices or a cheesesteak. Others, have talent in the kitchen, and can turn a beautiful platter, but don't really do assembly line tomato pie. It is much rarer to find a restaurant that does both very well while housed in a ordinary looking pizza parlor for the past 30 years. So it is with Paul's Penndel Pizza on old Route 1. 

There was a steady line of pizza takeout orders on one side of the large room separated by half wall to create a cozy dining area on the other. Only two tables were occupied over here and the trifold menu didn't disclose all the hidden treasures possible in the kitchen. Photos on Yelp showed a good looking chicken francaise dish, but was it available? 

Yes, it was! All I had to do was ask, and our attentive server Robyn made all the arrangements. 

In addition to my request, we also chose chicken parmigiana and "Shrimp Our Way," a penne platter with lots of shrimp and a delicious pink sauce. Each dinner came with choice of soup or salad, and double bread baskets. 

The francaise was incredible. Butter lemon sauce and perfectly pan sauteed egged medallions. Tender, light and pleasantly tart. The best rendition I have enjoyed in many years. The Our Way was likewise exceptional, with knock out pink sauce over a dozen or more crustaceans and quality pasta. The parmigiana was a heavy load with spaghetti and copious red gravy. Substantial and tasty but a step down from the other meals. The side salads were large, but mostly iceberg, detracting from the other ingredients and house balsamic. Finally, the Italian loaves were the weakest link, with little crust, texture nor flavor. They really would do themselves a favor by finding a better bakery. 

The shortcomings were not enough to seriously detract from what was otherwise a fantastic and surprising dinner. Still, had they been eliminated, this could have been one of the best meals of the year. As it was, it was damn close. 

4.5 STARS

The Mann Center for the Performing Arts (full moniker) opened in 1976 in West Fairmount Park.  It is one of the finest outdoor music venues in the USA, with room for about 14,000 people, both inside under the roof, and outside on the grass knoll.  There is no question that it brings life to this part of the city, especially at night, when the sound from a loud band or orchestra can be heard well into the surrounding streets of West Philly. 

I was there the other night with my teenage son, who was attending his first concert. A right of passage from one generation to the next, I was transporting him to see/listen to Kid Cudi (Scott Ramon Seguro Mescudi), a rap, reggae, original actor and hipster, where I had previously gone to see Stevie Ray Vaughan, Roger Daltry and Robert Cray.  I was happy to be passing the baton. The venue hasn't changed much in the past 40 years.  It is still an awesome place to listen to music, and mix with like-minded heads.  The place was sold out and had the expected carnival atmosphere before, during and after the show.  There was enough haze generated to give everyone within a half mile a contact high.  Everyone inhaled.  

The show was great.  Kid Cudi is a first rate musician and showman.  He played for about 90 minutes, despite coming on stage about an hour late.  His band was tight, and all the singers, lights and stagecraft contributed to a first rate experience. Wasn't sure I would like his style, but he was way better in person than listening to him on recordings or watching his videos. He had everyone moving and shouting for more. 

Most of the main boulevards in the nearby park were closed to traffic, and it took a while to find our way to the parking area and the main entrance. There was a heavy police presence in the park just in case, but they did not interfere in any way with the happening. 

At the end of the evening, my son and his friend were exhausted from all their singing and dancing, not to mention the inebriants in the air. They had a great time, and scored Kid Cudi T-shirts as memorabilia. 

Just hope The Mann is around when my grandchildren are ready to boogie!

There are alot of great Mexican joints around Trenton these days, and Totopos up on Brunswick Avenue is one of them. True, it is tiny (2 tables inside and 2 more out front), and it is a dive (in the best sense of the word), but the skilled hands in la cocina tell a different tale.

When I parked on the street in front and walked in, a telenovela was playing on the HDTV high on the wall, and several people were working behind the counter. I approached to check their trifold menu and engaged the man who appeared to be the owner or manager. He was fluently bilingual making it easy to explain what was available and then how I wanted my Torta Milanesa de Pollo prepared.

I took a chair at one of the tables, and moments later my lunch was placed before me. It was an enormous sandwich on an oversized oblong roll, dressed in heavy foil at its waist and showing its internals at its edges. Just take a look at the photos. It was an amazing piece of working peoples culinary art.

I maneuvered my jaws for a first bite and attempted to compress the width of this monster to fit more in my mouth. I clamped down full force and cut through its many layers. The flavor of the breaded cutlet, spicy mayo, avocado, tomato, onion, queso and lettuce burst out and had a fiesta in my mouth complete with pinata. It was just an excellent sandwich. Eating half would have been enough for a satisfying meal, but I indulged and ate the whole thing right there. 

Totopos has been in business for about three years. The family running it is from Oaxaca in southern Mexico. They give this corner of North Trenton another reason to visit along with some of the other great hidden kitchens in the neighborhood. 
.

I've been to a few Mission BBQ houses in the past years. While they could all be more consistent, their overall product tends to be good to excellent, and their "mission," highly worthy. So happens that the experience yesterday at this store was about the best I've had. 

The place was almost empty at 3 in the afternoon. One or two tables occupied and a solitary customer at the register ordering a meal. We had plenty of attention from the friendly, dedicated staff. After ordering 8 oz of brisket for the spouse, I went with a combo of brisket, 2 ribs and sides of baked beans and Grandma's Mashed Sweet Potatoes.  Both came with a square of cornbread. 

As you can see from the photos, the brisket was the blue ribbon winner. It was moist with plenty of dark brown bark. Both plain and wet it was a joy to eat. Great taste and texture. The ribs were pull off the bone tender and juicy, although not as dynamic as the beef this day. A shot of their Memphis sauce helped bring out the sleeping flavors. It was basically pulled pork without the effort of shredding. The beans were full of meat with a strong savory spicy base. Liked them a lot. The Grandma Sweets were over the top sugary, with a topping of melting brown sugar over already insulin inducing tawny tater. Not intended for diabetics, so be forewarned. 

As we were finishing, the cashier who had originally seen us up front walked by with a whole tray of Freedom Fries for us to enjoy, on the house. Very generous gesture which we appreciated, but already stuffed, all we could do is take them home with the rest of the leftovers for later consumption. 

We felt loved at Mission, and we reciprocated the affection for the staff and all first responders and military folk everywhere.

The drive down Woodhill Road, Upper Makefield, from Highland Road, is a perfect example of the beauty of Bucks County. Forests, farms, valleys, rolling hills. As you go east toward the Delaware River, you come upon Ely Farm and its multigenerational pork products agribusiness on the left. Its long drive framed by white picket fence escorts you to the large barn processing facility, small retail store, and the old farmstead under aging trees. It is a quite the bucolic vista, worthy of photograph, or at least a deep breath of appreciation. 

Walking up to the shop we met several people waiting to pick up their freshly butchered deer. "Eat what you kill," has immediate meaning, as we saw a couple carrying out a large flat box full of neatly wrapped meat and a plastic bag holding a multi point antler rack deer head for mounting. 

Not something you see every day.

The retail space is very small, with display cases showing many of their items for sale, access to walk-in refrigerators, and buzzing workers (mostly family) attending to the customers. It takes a few minutes for a first timer to figure out the process. We did, and ordered Seasoned Pork Chops, Hickory Smoked Kielbasa, Honey Bologna and Ground Beef. There was a lot more tempting us, but we had to start somewhere. Everything was made on site and looked great. 

When we got home we quickly sampled the kielbasa and bologna. Both had rich taste and we're slightly addicting. I fried up thin slices of the bologna and scrambled in a couple of eggs, salt and pepper. Delicious! Will grill the chops later this week. Can't wait. 
They are lean cut with thin edges of fat. Nothing will go to waste.
 
If the seasoned pork chops are as tender and tasty as they look and the smoked meats have proven to be, we will become regular Ely customers.

Chestnut Hill Brewing Company had the foresight to be the anchor tenant in the Market at the Fareway on Germantown Avenue in the heart of Chestnut Hill. Already one of the most picturesque communities in greater Philadelphia, it has made itself a premier destination with the opening of the Market with the nano-brewery within. Now, it is possible to select from a broad variety of street food alternatives also housed within this adaptive reuse of an old warehouse, but also to wash it down with a decent beverage brewed on sight. They also have a pizza operation right there, with a Yelp deal that draws you a free pilsner with the purchase of one of their pies. These guys do everything right. 

My choices: Korean Double Fried Chicken Wings from Chicko Tako and Pumpkin Ale from CHBC. Doesn't get much better than this! 

The ale was rich with a nutmeg/allspice accent in a beautiful dark red amber liquid. Easy drinking, and a perfect washdown for the delicious wings with their crispy exterior under a thick gloopy sweet and spicy sauce. Cut through that like a hot knife through cool butter. 
The brew tanks were visible to all, and the folks working the taps seemed to thoroughly enjoy their craft. At $6.50 a pint, it was hard to find anything to complain about. Even found a seat at a community table to enjoy my snack. 

Kudos to Chestnut Hill Brewery for seeing the possibilities of producing and selling suds in this small market, and extra credit for the town council and mayor for letting it all happen to the betterment of the community. 
The creative energy here was palpable and greatly appreciated.

There are many Mexican restaurants of the mom and pop variety throughout Montgomery and Bucks Counties specializing is home country cuisine primarily for their own compatriots who miss the wonderful flavors of home. Plates are loaded and prices tend to be low. In recent years a cultural crossover has emerged that offer similar dishes, perhaps somewhat less spicy that provide most if the flavor of Mexico, but for a more Norte Americano palate. Shops like El Limon have very successfully filled that space with folks who want something more authentic than Chipotle, but need English menus to participate in the experience.

El Sarape is a third kind of casa Mexicana. It brings an element of haute cuisine to the South of the Border Cocina, wrapped in a more high end atmosphere that transcends cultural bounds we are used to. This spacious house, with high ceilings, plenty of polished marble and dark stained wood, and brown ropes (cuerdos) hanging down from the rafters, calls for a reminder that an integral part of Mexican history was its involvement with Napoleon III, who was Emperor of the French Empire in the Eighteenth Century, where Mexico was its western outpost in America del Norte. The empire didn't survive, but its influence on Mexican food continues to this day. It involves excellent sauces, delicate recipes and Mexican looking dishes with French sounding names and haunting tastes. It is truly Mexican, but with a captivating twist. 

This is where El Sarape stakes it claim, and it does an accurate rendition of this style of Mexican cooking. My Chile Relleno (stuffed pepper) was beautiful to behold in its sedate presentation. Neat, yet colorful. The same ingredients - poblano pepper, melted cheese, salsa verde, black beans and three tone rice - all on a white ceramic rectangular plate worthy of a more expensive restaurant. The flavor was full, yet more subtle than I've had in other places. The beans were moist without being dominated by lardiness often found in refried beans of all sorts. The rice was flaky, not clumpy. The twirled chip garnish atop the beans was a textural crispy counterpoint to the soft black semi mashed mound beneath. 

I was there for late lunch and wasn't thinking dinner. I sat at the bar and received excellent service from the bartender as he prepare for the evening crowd. I would certainly return for dinner if in the area, although the drive from Bucks approaches 45 minutes, which may be beyond my hunger tolerant distance. Prices are higher than at the other great tiendas, but recognizing the different experience that awaits makes it worthwhile.

One door closes and another door opens...

This has been an article of faith for most of my life, proved to be true once again when the restaurant I had driven to Palmyra, NJ, to try their Thai kitchen was closed l, and I scrambled to find an nearby alternative. My trusty Yelp showed me Franco's Cafe was only about a quarter mile away up Cinnaminson Avenue. 

Found it, parked in their side lot, and walked in. 

Franco's is a Small Mexican casa, with half dozen tables, fairly standard menu and specials on a blackboard near the cashier. Daniella was my server. She was exceptionally friendly and said she was part of family ownership. Made sense, because she was totally engaged in keeping me in fresh brew coffee and whatever else I needed. As a first timer, I went with something basic - steak quesadilla. 

It was excellent. Small strips of grilled beef, cheese and jalapeños, with small salad and sour cream, all crammed and flattened into a large tortilla cut in quarters. It was a healthy chew with just enough spice to keep my mouth fired up. The blackboard alerted to the presence of churros and ice cream as a special dessert. Love me some churros, and indulged. 

They were hot, crisp and fresh; filled with a ring of caramel inside each fried strip of dough. Hot! So hot they deserved a warning, but the burn was extinguished by the Java accompaniment. Yup. Delicious, too! 

There are full platter dinners available here, too. If you live in the area, it would be worth your effort to check them out along with their lunch and snack choices. 

Franco's is a casual and tasty 5 Star experience.

Village Pantry Deli sits on Bridgetown Pike, Trevose, PA., in the 1960s era commercial zone. It is a true mom & pop operation that specializes in fat hoagies and deli specials of the Eastern European variety. Prices are ridiculously low for 2021. So, if you're hungry and desiring a traditional stuffed sandwich, this is your huckleberry. 

I stopped in and walked to the back of the shop where a large refrigerated display case was full of smoke meats and tubes of salami, bologna, ham and trays of homemade salads and cultural delicacies like pierogi and stuffed cabbage. I ordered a chicken salad sub, with lettuce, tomato and hot peppers on a long roll, and watched as it was made, wrapped and bagged. With Snapple and Herr's Jalapeno Chips, the cost was under $10. That was a deal and a half, and I didn't have to pay for the ton of old world atmosphere that came with.  

As I waited, I looked around at all the accessories available. Awesome pound cakes, cookies, Cento pickles and sours, and a wall of cold drinks. Service was friendly, even for this stranger, and there were enough old-time regulars to make this place a hot stove center for local gossip. Very cool.

These neighborhood haunts remind of what America used to be when the first generations settled in and started life in the New World. Now, nearly a century later, they have generally aged well, although it has a hardscrabble feel to them with narrow streets, limited parking, and undersized stores and homes that are lovely, but feel somewhat dated. 

Lucky for me, I love this sort of thing. It provides a getaway from the continual hassles of modern life and Covid anxiety. And, the sandwiches are great!
There are 89 other reviews under, "Yardley Inn Restaurant and Bar."  If you find yourself looking at only these two reviews, you are in the wrong place.

Crash serendipity led me to DP Autobody after my M45 was rear ended last month on my way home from work.  Actually, the guy who hit me recommended I go there because his family knew them, and would give me (him) a better price.  I got three estimates, and I found that DP was the lowest. Too, the owner, Dave Miller, had a great personal touch with me as a customer, and I immediately had a sense of trust with him.  

So we went through the insurance formalities and car rental nuisances, but in the end, when the car was returned to me, I had a brand new looking chariot.  The dings and scrapes were gone, and the paint job was impeccable.  

I was so satisfied that I decided to have to car detailed there in a few weeks.  I will update the review after that.  

It is so nice to have a totally satisfying experience when it comes to auto repairs.  DP is now my only autobody shop.

Found my way to El Chapin for lunch yesterday.  It is located toward the bottom of Cass Street in Trenton, between the prison and Arm & Hammer Field.  It is not really on Lamberton Street, although it is possible there was once a door on that side of the building. 

"El Chapin," is slang for a Guatemalan, so although the menu has a certain Mexican flair, this is a house that specializes in cuisine from its southern neighbor.  And, it is very good.  The lady of the house was taking orders and cooking when I went in.  The menu is rather extensive and it took a while for me to decide what I wanted - everything was bilingually displayed with many photos.  Mamita was patient and when I finally selected the Chile Relleno she smiled and said it was one of the best dishes in the house. I bet she says that for whatever people want.  

But, she was right that it was special.  About ten minutes later, out came a large green Poblano Chili Pepper stuffed with spicy shredded Pork, Peas, Onion, Cheese, and a few things I could not define, all wrapped in a thin Egg Omelet.  Black Beans, Yellow Rice and a small Green Salad completed the platter.  It was delicioso. Every element of the dish could be tasted and the combination was a full pleasure to devour.  I also had a glass of Horchata, the Rice Milk and Cinnamon drink that is a national treasure.  As friend Marlyn describes, it tastes like liquid rice pudding.  When cold, I find it fun, tasty and thirst quenching.  

As with almost all the Latin shops in Trenton, they were once Italian joints or corner bars that had seen the neighborhoods change and adapt to the influx of new residents.  Unlike most, however, El Chapin has somehow removed the old rustiness of these places and made it feel fresh and energetic.  It was very comfortable to sit in one of its booths and watch people coming and going.  

While I have favored all the Mexican, Guatemalan, Salvadoran and Puerto Rican restaurants that I have sampled to date, I found El Chapin to be about the best of the lot.  

Thanks for a great lunch, Mamita.

Three generations of donuts have been baked and served from this Colmar, Pa. location.  It isn't an accident that they are considered among the best sweet rounders in this quadrant of the Universe.  And, now that the Great Pumpkin has arrived, Yum Yum is baking its amazing orange squash variant in many forms.  They are all great!

While we went in just for a small sample with coffee, the counterperson advised us that buying 6 would cost the same as 5, we were easily persuaded to go with the half doz and bring home whatever we didn't consume on premises.  A couple of Pumpkin Sugar Cinnamons, a pair of classic Glazed, and a deuce of Honey Dipped, and a coupla small Joes, and we retreated to a corner table to dive in.  

Each was excellent, but the Pumpkin stood out as large, authentically pumpkin tasting, and cake style.  Fresh and delicious.  The Glazed and Honey Dipped were less distinguishable from the competition, but still a sweet sticky mess.  

These guys do donuts right!

How many made it home?  Just two survived the initial onslaught.

Trenton Coffee House & Roaster is the epitome of a "Hidden Gem."  Housed in a second story walkup in an old brick industrial building on Cass Street in Trenton, NJ, it has only been open a few weeks, and already has a following of locals and the feel of a 1980's urban loft that has been designed for a community party.  

In fact, that is exactly what it is.  Abdul, the proprietor and coffee maven, explained that the space was shared with an East European social club that uses this room for its larger get -
togethers. The plan is to move the operation downstairs in the near future, to allow for more room and ease of access, especially for those who are challenged by climbing a narrow flight of stairs.  Of course, the added elevation adds something to the ambiance of the sun drenched room; making it feel more private and cozy than a direct walk in off the street.  Yet, from what I learned about the philosophy behind the joint - its local punk rock/street life orientation - moving into an old barroom will not cause any real loss of spatial/emotive relationship. 

As for the Java, it is very good, if house roasted, hand brewed Joe is your cup of tea.  Abdul makes each order as received from his personal stock of prepared beans.  He has overseen every aspect of preparation other than the actual growing of the coffee bushes.  His love and attention to his trade is patent, as he will tell you his coffee story and provide a play by play of how he is making your "pour over."  

The cast of characters here on a weekday morning was unique and very authentic.  There were hushed conversations and people working with pad and pencil, while I looked around taking photos and listening to Abdul.  The large, "UNWANTED," sign above the barista area makes a strong statement, but I thought it best not to inquire about it yet.  

Trenton Coffee House is the newest piece of the underground arts/music scene in this past its prime capitol city.  There are many urban pioneers about "Renton," that hold hope for the future of this decayed mini-opolis.  If you feel called to be a part of it, stop in for some Java and conversation, and pick up a schedule for the local bands.  

It'll do you good.

UPDATE: DECEMBER 21, 2016 - Winter Soltice.  
Trenton Coffee House made the move downstairs to its new space on the first floor. Corner door lets you right into the main room.
Red & white walls. Gray wooden floor. Roaster behind the counter. 

Same excellent java. Same Coolio vibes. 
Morning light through the glass block windows gives it a soft glow that easily shifts within.

Wish I didn't have to return to DP Auto Body less than a year since my previous visit, but as luck would have it, I had another rear ender.  Ugh! 

Dave Miller has a great way with people.  He is able to make an unpleasant experience as comfortable as possible by his friendly demeanor, clear explanations, excellent shop, and fair prices.  

And, yes.  If I need more work done in the future, I would return without hesitation.

This is the most beautiful and serene space for foot massage I have experienced in the USA. The décor is cool and quiet, despite it being a simple large space without inner separating walls. 20 large reclining chairs in 3 rows.  All visible, yet private. Choice of herbal bath for your feet to soak in, while 20 minutes is spent on solid upper body massage. 

Very restful, except when my foot master dug deep into certain points and looked to see my reaction. He knew the meridians, and was able to push chi.

Green tea leaves sink to the bottom of my cup as I slip away.

When rescheduling a driver's test at the Bensalem facility in Bucks County had a three month wait, I called the number on the scheduling letter, and was able to get a new date at the Norristown, Montgomery County, operation for three weeks later.  What a difference!  

Not only that, but their tester was friendly and actually encouraged my new driver to take her time, and not worry.  He wanted her to succeed.  So different than the attitude in the other place, where it was obvious the man with the digital pad could care less.  

Yes, there was a wait of about an hour until we were reached, but there was only this one guy doing all the testing, and he was as thorough as he was pleasant.  In the end, he gave a passing grade, and congratulated her on a job well done.  He took the time to express his appreciation for how well she had parallel parked (only 2 moves), and that she also needed to always be attentive to all the conditions around her.  Point well taken. 

He escorted us to the right desk inside the center, and from there, a temporary license was issued in a matter of minutes. The permanent license would arrive by mail in about two weeks. 

The rest was all celebration! 

It is not often that a bureaucratic experience like a driving test can be called "humane," but that was the case yesterday in Norristown.  "Lee" was all that and more. He deserves an award and a big raise.

Excellent burgers on South 5th Street, just where Passyunk intersects with the 5. Design your own using the three computer stations, or go to the counter to talk with the people working there. Either way you get a standard double patty complemented any way you choose. If you don't want to think that much about it, the menu offers several great combinations that are bound to make you happy. 

Just the right amount of grease, potato or pretzel roll, natural sugar carbonated beverages, Bassett ice cream based shakes, and fresh fruit smoothies, all surround the ultimate comfort food for your indulgence. 

Prices that won't break the bank just off the hippest street in town. 

If there is something to improve upon, it is that it appears that every burger is finished to well done regardless of how you request it. Still, they are so juicy I almost didn't notice.

When my HVAC system died last year, I called around for estimates to replace the 25 year old dinosaur with a more state of the art apparatus. Not only was Christian less expensive for equivalent mechanicals, but they did not attempt to oversell me on a product that my home really could not benefit from, regardless of rebates or government programs.  Much appreciated.

They got the job done in one day, were neat and quiet, and gave me both a coupon for an additional discount and my first tune-up as part of the deal.  One year financing without interest was also a nice touch.  

With all the heat and humidity this summer, I think of them almost daily as I cool down in my favorite chair with a tall glass of lemonade.  

Thanks, Christian HVAC!

If you look at a map showing the Delaware River boundary between Pennsylvania and New Jersey, you can see where the southbound river makes a sharp turn to the west, creating the 'neck' geographic feature of the Garden State and the elbow of Bucks County, PA. jutting into it's eastern neighbor. This part of the region is dominated by the ancient flood plains of the Delaware. Driving through feels more like the Louisiana bayous than the Northeastern states. There is alot more water than dry land in these parts, with narrow spits of land for roads and a few homes surrounded by lakes, ponds, marshes and of course, the Mighty Delaware. 

The folks around here have resided in this water world for generations. They are a tight community. When they want to socialize, Darby O'Gill's is where they meet to talk, drink, eat, play and inebriate. Yeah. It felt a little strange walking in for the first time with everyone looking up and following my steps to the square bar in search of a stool. But, my Eagles ballcap and 6'4" smile gave me a pass for the moment, so they just stared and waited to see what happened. 

The barkeep, Desiree, yanked me a pint of Yuengling Octoberfest, and asked to run my credit card before taking my food order. The lager was excellent. 

 "I don't know you, honey. Have to be sure you can handle this." 

"No sweat. House rules are fine. Do what you gotta do." 

She returned with a more relaxed countenance and handed my card back to me. The sound of conversation and football games on the TVs returned to the room. I ordered their Paddy Melt and sipped on the dark rusty ambered brew. 

This joint was the diviest of taverns. Operated by Darby since 1998, and housed in a large building considerably older than that, it had been decades since it was cleaned thoroughly. The underflooring was exposed in many places and the knotty pine paneling was grease and beer splattered.

 Almost Heaven. West Virginia. 

The grilled sandwich was pretty good with loads of sauteed onions and crunchy rye holding a half pound of burger and melted swiss. The ketchup was watery, but what the hey? It tasted good and was filling with a shovel of fries for an extra buck. 

I paid with a reasonable tip for Ms. D, and walked out into the cool bright late afternoon sunlight. The parking lot was as torn up as the barroom floor. There was a ragged trailer park out back that appeared to be in the same condition as everything else around there. 

As I found my way out of this strange wet and desolate area, I was amazed that this place was part of contemporary Bucks County, and not a piece of land that time forgot.

This location of Penn Medicine on Township Line Road in Lower Makefield, PA, is close to home, so when I needed a follow up X-ray this was the place to go. There are many Penn doctor offices there, but I was only interested in the Department of Radiology on the first floor. 

Turned out that this office was very well run. I made the appointment online through mypennmed.com for the same afternoon. On arrival I signed in and was seen by the intake person within five minutes. After showing my photo ID and insurance card, I went to the waiting room until I was called for the x-ray. In less then ten minutes the technician walked into the waiting area, called my name, greeted me, escorted me to the changing area and handed me a gown needed for the picture. Once done, we went to the radiology room and took the shot. 

I was dressed and out the door from beginning to end in no more than 25 minutes. 

Everyone I dealt with was friendly, accommodating and totally professional. I love going to Philly for best medicine at Penn, but getting an x-ray at one of their satellites make so much sense, especially with the digital images going directly to my doctor for his review.  Will be talking to him soon.

There is no Stella!

I don't know how to break it to you gently, so I'll just come right out and say it. There is no Stella @ Stella's House Blend Cafe. 

But, there is a Tiki (goddess) running the show, and she has the joint jumping. It was a capacity crowd at 10 am on Labor Day. The old 19th Century corner building in the heart of Sellersville, Pa, is as busy now as it ever was. The first floor occupied by this breakfast/lunch house has been brought back to life with TLC and a vision.  Have a good kitchen and they will come. They do, and they did.

I found a seat at the counter between two big fellas, and felt a moment of guilt being alone and able to skip the queue waiting for tables. It didn't last long. From my perch the kitchen was visible, and I could watch to servers at work. Teamwork!

My French Toast with Strawberries and Blueberries was made from multigrain bread as they were out of Texas Toast by the time I arrived.  No problem.  Done right, FT pleases me in almost any form.  This rendition was very good.  I also asked for the real Maple Syrup, a $1.50 extra, because there is little point to eating great FT with run of the mill pancake syrup.  The Maple enhances, while the sweet corn syrup used by Log Cabin and the like, diminishes the flavor of the dish.  

The plate arrived loaded with bread and berries.  Gorgeous!  The side of Bacon I requested well done, was precisely that.  Firm, crunchy and with a splash of Maple, a delicious complement to the main.  Everything tasted very fresh, and their local sourcing policy seemed to be working well.  Same with the java.  Local roaster makes awesome joe.  Strong. Savory. A touch of milk to take the edge off.  

Stella's House Blend Café would seem to be about the coffee, but that would deny the strength of the menu, and the skill in the kitchen.  Just about everything about this joint is fun and affirming.  

Hey, Tiki!  I really like what you've done with the place.  A wonderful place to end a beautiful September drive in the country.

Trenton, New Jersey, is the last of the state capitals to have a Starbucks.  After 400+ years of history, it has finally arrived.  And, from the look of the place, the Green Mermaid spared little expense in designing this java joint. It is large, bright and original.  Cut in a triangular shape at the corner of Front Street and South Warren Street, on the first floor of a State office building, the two outer walls are all glass, and both are lined with comfortable sitting areas for work and conversation.  The back walls are painted with colorful murals of famous cityscapes - including the famous Trenton Makes Bridge across the Mighty Delaware River to Pennsylvania. 

The coffee is standard Starbucks (not my favorite), but there is something to be said for consistency.  Their reliable snacks are present, and the service is friendly, knowledgeable and efficient. Everyone gets "TO GO" cups, even those hanging out, to save on losses. 

I enjoyed the fact that this beautiful facility was actually in this Sad Sack city, as much as I enjoyed my latte and slice of lemon pound cake.  I watched as people filtered in and out.  No one seemed to be taking the space for granted.  The gold balloons didn't let that happen. 

I allowed myself a moment of pride and gratification for this city that has been down so long that Starbucks is a very big win. Let's hope it is the beginning of a renaissance that has been awaited since Washington surprised the Hessians on a cold Christmas morn.

There is a simple reason almost all the reviews for The Dutch on S. 4th Street are 5 Star. They deserve every star they get! 

I am not a regular part of the weekend breakfast/brunch scene in Philly, but given a reason to be in the Pennsport neighborhood early on a Saturday morning, I willing partake of this lovely cottage industry.  The small corner shop is bright and airy, even on an overcast day.  Pale and deeper blues offset the whitewashed walls, giving the feel of happiness and cleanliness.  There are two levels.  Dining room in the front of the house with around 10 small wood top tables, and a step up in the rear with a traditional counter and semi-open kitchen.  The owners are very hands on, supervising, serving, cashiering and hosting.  The "Double Wilkum" hex suits the personality of this place. 

We walked in around 8:30 to a half full room.  We were shown to one of the small deuces toward the back of the dining area, and had a fresh large cup of java steaming my glasses in less than a minute.  The menu is short and sweet.  But, don't be misled by its list of offerings that look like any other hash house.  Hidden within the deceptively simply names are the creative energies of these "Dutchmen."  

My Huevos Rancheros was not very South of the Border, but certainly tipped their sombrero in homage to the venerable dish.  Rather than tortillas, upon a base of Corn Meal Waffle were placed a shiny Sunny Side Up Egg, melted Cheese,  Fresh Tomato Salsa, Guacamole, Black Beans and well grilled and pressed thick cut Bacon; covered in mild Hollandaise.  Pretty as a picture on the plate, the assemblage had a great taste, if not overwhelmingly Mexi heat.  I never thought of corn and waffles in the same breath, but it worked like a charm.  It held all the component parts together, and sent the meal in an unexpected direction.  

My companion's Ham & Eggs with 3 Over Easys, interestingly delicious Hash Browns, and thick sliced Marble Rye, was devoured with little offered to me to taste.  I did manage a couple of sly bites when she went to the WC, and understood why she was not in a particularly sharing mood.  

This neighborhood is gentrifying, but still maintains its authentic South Philly personality.  On a less muggy day, sitting at the sidewalk tables would be a nice way to watch this part of the world go by.

El Primo Plaza is a Mexican multi store that offers grocery, bakery and taqueria within its walls. Right now, it is the apex for south of the border cuisine in Bensalem, PA. A good indication of its authenticity is the near totally Mexican customers shopping and eating there. Walking around the packed space it was clear that this was a family destination, with cakes and cookies for those with sweet teeth, and a broad menu for the rest of us seeking a more balanced diet. It was truly impressive.

I was seated at a deuce facing the refrigerated display of sliced cakes, all with large strawberries or other fruit and colorful icing. Tempting, but I knew better than to start with dessert. So, I selected a plate of a large cheese stuffed poblano chile with yellow rice and beans, and small watermelon juice. Service was friendly and easily bilingual. 

The meal was made with all fresh ingredients and was delicious. It was covered in a red sauce that tasted like it had been blended and spiced just before pouring. And, the watermelon juice was cool, sweet and so refreshing - like sipping through a straw right out of the melon. 

All the while I watched little kids and their parents looking at all the sweets, buying them, and carrying them out in small boxes and bags for consumption at home, or in house dessert. Not really sure who was going to eat all I saw purchased, but next time I'm going to borrow my neighbor's kids and let them lead me around to those beautiful cakes and buy a few for me. 

Going to El Primo Plaza is crossing the border without need of passport, nor dealing with DHS.

I know Johnny G's Famous Pizza on Brownsville Road, Trevose, PA, is supposed to be all about tomato pie, steak sammies and other Italian goodies, but my first visit ended up being all about their burgers. 

They said they were half pounders made from never frozen Angus beef, with assorted toppings and a side of fries for an extra buck fifty. Brioche style buns held them together and offered sturdy handholds for the heft of the large slider. I realized the risk from bypassing their signature dishes, but why all the menu space for burgers? Why the interesting combinations? 

I had the answers when the large plate with Mighty Mike Burger was placed before me by the pleasant server in training. The roll top shined like it had been polished. The edge of the beef was thick, with a tip of bacon peaking out on top of melted swiss cheese. My request for medium finish was honored precisely. 

And it was a great Burger! Hot, drip juicy, flavorful. Russian dressing adding a sweet creamy note. A joyful surprise first bite to last. Beautiful pink at heart, and true to its credo of never having seen the inside of a freezer.

Better than Guys, Shack, Smash, Robin and many others with catchy names; at about half the price. 

How do they keep this joint a secret?!

Covello's on South Broad Street, Trenton, has been at this location for thirty years. It's been at least twenty since the last time I walked in their front door. Now that I am working downtown again this old joint is back on my lunch rotation. 

It hadn't changed that much. Still a big room with many booths and counter service along a front wall. Still the standard Italian pizzeria with pies, calzones, hot & cold sandwiches, salads, pasta and platters. I ordered an eggplant parmesan sandy and picked my booth to await its preparation and delivery.

It was very, very good. 

Lightly breaded thin slices of nightshade, slightly crisp outside and soft within. Enough melted mozza to promote textural integrity, but not too much to swallow the intended star of the show. Fresh, basil sweet chunky sauce dolloped on top, and all of it housed in a really good Italian roll.  It was a foot long; cut in half. So much for $6.95!  I needed knife and fork to go after the heart of the sandwich, and then ate half the delicious bread toward the end, almost like dessert. Crusty, warm and flavored with everything it had held in its once molten valley. 

So assuring that Covello's hasn't missed a beat in all these years.

This health food and nutrition shop has been located at the same location for decades. Walking into this converted residential bungalow, I was overwhelmed by the floor to ceiling shelving packed with everything from vitamins to dry goods to frozen foods. The store has aged well, and has become as much a cultural museum, as a retail outlet designed to assist in maintaining health. 

We stopped in to purchase more supplements that had run out at home. A clerk who worked there approached with a welcoming smile and showed us where what we sought was resting on the highest shelf in the house. She climbed a stepstool to reach them. They had a sale going on, and the price was very fair. We bought two. 

I loved the old wooden built-ins housing the drygoods, granolas and nut mixes. They would look great in our kitchen (alas). I could see how the claustrophobic might be challenged by the stuffed to the gills nature of this tiny store. But, for me, it was a cozy room that instant relaxed me and captured my curiosity. 

Now that our usual health food shop has closed its doors, The Natural Foods Store may well become our regular stop for nutritional maintenance.

So, what's a "flexitarian?" 

I didn't know either until I sat at the counter in the Silver Diner, and had it explained for me in their elaborate menu. Apparently, when health consciousness is a priority, local sourcing predominates and the offerings change with the seasons, you have created a flexitarian restaurant. So, although its stainless steel & glass shell suggests a traditional Jersey diner experience awaits, in fact nothing could be further from the truth. This is a new age epicurian delight on par with the Turning Points of the world, without the pretense and only some of the accompanying cost. 

My Country Griddle breakfast (scrambled eggs, onion, green pepper, morning sausage, mushroom, potato and 2 tone melted cheddar) in a large bowl with fresh biscuit on top, was delicious and filling. The coffee was hot and strong, with a small pitcher of cold milk provided at my request (may have been from Amish cows). From my perch at the counter I could see into the kitchen where the white hats seemed to be having a good time. 

Even if you don't know anything about flexitarian kitchens, you can find your way to a very pleasurable meal @ Silver Diner. 

Nice going!

If mid 20th Century Archie & Veronica malt shops and Back to the Future big fin American road steel move your imagination, then Jem's Restaurant in East Norristown, PA, may be for you. 

What from the outside looks like another shopping center fast food luncheonette constrained by its surroundings to be a boring food dealer, is in fact a real trip down memory lane. The joint is a museum of cultural artifacts from the early days of television, with large posters of Rebel Without a Cause, James Dean, and Seven Year Itch, Marilyn Monroe. Perhaps that's why the room was full with retirees and people over the age of 70 (except for those of us needing to eat and run). This place is the original greasy spoon, for all the right reasons. 

The double "U" counter separated the kitchen from the dining room. My spinner faced the grill operated by two short order cooks who worked smoothly in tandem. I ordered coffee and Jem's Scramble with feta and rye toast. The full insulated carafe of java set in front of me was a nice touch. I listened to the repartee between customers and servers. It was familiar and entertaining. Most everyone seemed to be a regular. 

I noted the pile of chunk cut red bliss potatoes and metal tray of bacon on the grill. I watched eggs, pancakes, french toast and breakfast sandwiches being cooked and constructed as spatulas flew. I also saw that the grill was not scaped clean between orders, allowing residue from everything grilled there to build up and become part of the next dish. No judgement. Then, my small Scramble arrived, steaming in my face and fogging my glasses. Smelled awesome and looked like a gently beckoning glistening syren. 

It was delicious. The eggs held the sausage, onions, peppers and feta in a wet/warm embrace, allowing each forkful to hang together with all elements dancing on my tongue. There was also a hint of everything else that came before, making for a mysterious, yet very pleasant flavor. 

Maybe that is the house secret to success, or just how it accidentally became an amazing greasy spoon. Intentional or not, Jem's has a full house every morning, and is definitely doing something right.

Love Groucho or not, Duck Soup Cafe is a great place for breakfast and coffee. It is hard to find in Logan Square Shopping Center, but if you drive around back on the eastern side the rear door and sign are visible as the best way in. 

Started 35 years ago by the same family running it now, the place has an easy Americana coziness and knotty pine charm that makes for a relaxing environment. The menu is similarly built on kitchen classics, with one side for morning victuals, and the reverse, lunch. I was the second customer when I walked in around 9:20. I liked the country vibe and took a table in the front corner under the windows and across from the cashier counter and kitchen entrance.

Their french toast was constructed from a thin cut croissant, and included fresh cool sweet butter to melt, real grade A dark maple syrup and two bacon slices. It was all very good, as was the bottomless coffee mug. Service was beautifully provided by Michelle, daughter of the owner/chef of the house. They both seemed to know all their customers, but me, and came out to greet everyone and catch up of the daily New Hope gossip.

One of the benefits of Logan Square is that it is not downtown in tourist centric New Hope. Rather, this is for the locals, with real quality and reasonable prices.

This review is for the Raymour & Flannigan website, where we recently purchased a dining room set of a table and six chairs. The Langhorne store is the closest to home, but we did not shop in any of their warehouse sized facilities. 

The experience was a breeze from start to finish. We saw a wood ensemble that we liked and the price was discounted for the coming Black Friday sales. We ordered it and arranged for delivery two days later. They called ahead in the appointed day, and arrived on time. The two guys were friendly and professional. They set everything up and took away all the packing materials. They were done in about 20 minutes and our dining room looks great. Everything was in perfect condition and makes the room pop. The chairs are wood and leather, quite heavy and surprisingly comfortable. 

We easily qualified for their 12 month payment plan with no interest if paid in full on time, which made it all the more manageable. 

This was my second purchase from R & F, and it won't be the last. They have eliminated the hassle of furniture buying and delivery delay, so that it works smooth as silk.

One Up One Down Coffee is the new urban cafe on Cass Street, Trenton, that took the place of the previous occupant, the Trenton Coffee House. With a little spit and polish they have made the original Polish Falconer Club into an attractive reuse that is bright and comfortable, with lots of handworked wood bars and tables, block glass windows, and large coffee bean roaster where they control the production of excellent java. 

In addition to a broad caffeinated menu, they sell a few pastries - cookies, scones and brownies, as well as carrying bags and sacks with their logo on them. You can tell they are really just getting started, but have a marketing plan in keeping with the hard edged neighborhood where they ply their trade. Trenton State Prison is right down the street, where hard time takes on an altogether new meaning. 

I asked for Chai Latte, and it was handed to me minutes later in a large cup in saucer. It was well done and went down easy. They were kind enough to allow me to eat a bagel I had picked up earlier. I had intended to bring it to my office on South Broad, but when I drove by One Up One Down, I had a change of plans and wanted to take a little time on a chill Friday morning to enjoy a diversion. 

Spontaneity completely made my day, even if I wore my mask in and out to honor Covid Protocol.

There is little doubt that Rocco's is the best restaurant currently in Newtown. This may change as there are new kitchens opening up almost weekly in the community, but right now, this steakhouse has it going on full bore. 

I had dinner there with son and his girlfriend the other night. We sat in the glass enclosed porch that rings the first floor. The space is beautifully appointed in colonial style, and white table cloths and heavy stainless flatware. It is a pleasure to walk through the barroom and dining room to reach the porch. From that perch the Newtown bustle can be witnessed first hand. We were there to celebrate several occasions that had gone  unrecognized over the past 16 months due to Covid. We had much to be thankful for. 

Son o'mine loves his steak, and his N.Y Strip done medium was beyond excellent in texture and robust flavor. He cut me a piece knowing that this was not my normal diet, but that I was open to experiencing superior dishes. Yes, it was amazing, and it was easy to understand his attraction. I had to concentrate to appreciate everything that was going on in my mouth as I chewed and savored. His girlfriend went with a medium filet. It wasn't as juicy as the strip by observation, but she was clearly loving every bite of her medium round thick slab of beef. 

I went with the French Onion Soup and Prime Burger, knowing my diet couldn't handle a platter of solid beef. The soup qualified for possible the best of breed in a lifetime. It was rich, savory, onions, hearty beef stock, topped with french loaf under a thick layer of gruyere, seared to a near-blackened finish either in the oven or by blowtorch. The cheese had to be pierced to access the molten potage below, and to permit the superheated steam to escape. It was epic, and nearly a meal by itself.  Stupendous! 

After all this, the burger was a bit of a disappointment. True, it was a combination of ground beef, short rib and brisket, topped with onion, tomato, lettuce and melted provolone, in a brioche bun. But, flavor-wise it was a situation where more is less. I didn't get off on the mix of beef. It just didn't taste like a high end burger. I like short rib and brisket at BBQ joints, but prefer them separately, where each of their distinct attributes can be appreciated, and not muddled together. So, it was disappointing after the star quality of everything else. The fries were standard crispers. 

So, Rocco gets a less than perfect five stars here. Despite the burger, the rest of the experience was top notch, and the bar/dining area stunning In an understated way. On a less precipitous evening, eating outside would have been a legitimate option, but despite the umbrellas, we would have had to endure wet shoulders from the tropical storm brewing outside. 

No wonder Rocco's is booked solid every night. It is truly a first class night on the town.

Five Guys makes the best grease burgers! 

Grilled on steel that is seldom cleaned during hours of operation, the beef sizzles until well done, when it is lifted off the heat and placed on a bun already prepared with whatever accessories you want. Whatever else they do to the body, they are incredibly tasty and provide excellent lubrication to the alimentary canal. 

In addition, 5 Guys make great fries that far outclass their better known brothers. Their signature move is to toss extra fries in the brown paper bag after putting in the primary load carried in a paper cup. Excessive, but nicely so. Same goes for their shakes, which are also superior to the beef pucks. They are creamy, sweet cool ice cream splurges. Pricey, but the super caloric craving supercedes the doubtful overall nutritional value. 

So, it is an upside down meal if you think about it, but certainly a ton of fun on a bun. 

Unbeknownst to me, I had ordered online from the Five Guys on Lincoln Highway, but not the road running through Bucks County, A/K/A Route 1, but rather the one in Lancaster, PA., over 100 miles away. My bad. I wrongly assumed that their locations were in order of proximity to where I lived. Not so on their app, so the reference to Lincoln Highway led me astray. You know, I saw what I expected to see (Langhorne rather than the actual Lancaster) and impulsively jumped the gun. 

This is where Five Guys superhero Tyler stepped in to save the day. When the shop didn't have my order, he asked to see my phone and immediately knew what had happened. Not for the first time, he explained. He immediately reordered everything on the register and comped the charges, knowing I had already paid their sister store. They could correct this internally. 

Tyler's superpower - being supercool and knowing exactly what to do without making me feel like a bigger smacked ass than I already did. All this coolness made the enjoyment of my "special meal" almost a secondary consideration. 

Almost, but not quite, as it was digestible proof that some classy teenagers are ready to rule the world.

If you enjoy classic Italian cuisine with a touch of something more modern, set in an beautifully renovated house, La Strada is calling your name. 

Its main dining room is a large round room that may have been a solarium in a past life, but has become a space large enough for a dozen or more tables amply spaced and fully windowed to permit the world outside to come in. As this is the older part of town, you can see 18rh and 19th Century buildings that remind of the pre and post revolutionary history of the area. 

The menu has all the traditional dishes, some with a special flare away from what would be expected. For example, we ordered Calamari which came drizzled with a Thai Sweet Chili Sauce and Balsamic drip. All larger rings, it was a delicious surprise treat. Our Chicken Marsala and Francais were more classical, with two large breasts each atop Penne and wonderful reductions in Marsala Wine with fresh mushrooms and lightly dredged flour coat and  Lemon White Wine base, respectively. Tender enough to be cut with our forks. 

Service was a bit slow, but not bad for a romantic Sunday night. We regretted not bringing our own bottle to this BYOB house. 

Aside - All through the meal I had the feeling that this was a Roman room in the fine tradition of Trenton's Chambersburg neighborhood, which at one time had awesome Italian kitchens on every corner. They were classy and always full with locals manging to their hearts' content. Those days have turned to Spanish/Latino pleasures, but it's great to know that that Guilded Age can still be found if we look hard enough. In fact, the owners are from Trenton, and seemed pleasantly surprised to chat briefly about the old world, where I still have an office, and loads of memories.

La Strada is of that fine school.

Vinny G's sits at the corner of 4th & Broad in the lovely Delaware River town of Florence, NJ. For those of you who have never had the good fortune to visit this small burg in Burlington County, checking out its timeless charm is a great reason to make the trip, and Vinny's Bagel & Deli makes it even more worthwhile. This spot is one of the hidden places in the Garden State that will change your mind about the historic romanticism of Jersey. 

Yes. The bagels are very good, too. They are large, fresh, light and covered in your condiment of choice. The skin isn't as crisp as I prefer, but from first bite to last chew, it was a tasty delight.
