This was one of the better burgers I had eaten in the past six months, and after having tried the Rossi Burger just the week before I was surprised how much better this one was - and at a lower price.  The Fries were ample and decent.  

Jester's Café is the best place I have lunched at in Bordentown so far on my rediscovery tour of this historic river town.  While I have enjoyed all my meals there, this one combines ambiance, personality and taste in ways that most please me.  

It took me by surprise.  I became its happy captive, and will return.

A+ for this authentic "Hole In The Wall" Mexican café, The Tropical Rooster.  

Right off South Broad Street at the corner of Park Avenue, El Gallo is a clean shop with about a dozen tables.  Sombreros line the walls, and Mexican soap operas play non-stop on the TV hanging from the ceiling.  The family owners are very friendly and bilingual, although I was the only Gringo having lunch.  I practiced my rusty Spanish, and received a few extra smiles for the effort.  

The menu offers a broad range of lunch and dinner options, and the kitchen is sufficiently visible to be able to see and hear the meals being made complete with the banter and laughter of the gifted husband and wife team.  

The Torta Al Pastor is a fat sandwich full of Grilled Pork, Onion, Pineapple, Cheese, Lettuce and a touch of Mayo, all stuffed into a oversized round roll.  It tasted great!  The Pork was lean with a touch of BBQ flavor, and the Pineapple added a distinct juicy undertone that really set off my taste buds. The mild Cheese hid beneath the two stars of the show, but provided a subtle ending to each bite.  This was large enough to be my dinner. I was not hungry again until morning. 

Jarritos Mandarin, a favorite carbonated beverage, accompanied the feast, and a side of well tanned Fries completed the ensemble.  Apparently, they also concoct some tropical smoothies. I noticed them too late, but next time I will unlock that secret. 

El Gallo Tropical is now on my short list for lunch, and will be a regular stop as one my favorite lunch spots now that I am working in the area.

Horsham Donuts just hit the big time.

It is joining up with Donut Connection, the national round hole franchiser, to take advantage of the marketing clout that name provides.  

From the donut lovers perspective you gotta hope that this in no way interferes with the excellence of the current fare.  Horsham bakes up some high quality dough rings, with a broad variety that has captured the affection of the masses.  

As long as their hard earned reputation for great donuts doesn't suffer, who could complain about a name change?  My last taste of their Glazed babies, Cherry, and Chocolate rounders, left me in a trance-like state.  

Or was that just a wonderful sugar rush?

La Stalla Market on Sycamore Street, Newtown, Pa, does a very good job creating a traditional Italian deli in the heart of this old town. Plenty of cheese wheels, dried sausage, breads, sweets and takeout meals for the asking; all in a small shop that smells as great as it looks. 

I was there to grab a sandwich for lunch. They have a long list of choices that can be wrapped, rolled or sliced-breaded. I went with their turkey BLT on a 12" crusty roll. It was huge. Stuffed with enough ingredients for two meals and smeared with aoili mayo that pulled the various tastes and textures together. The roll was excellent, with hard crusty exterior and well aerated sourdough flavor within. Definitely, best of breed master baker. Chomp and chew required strong jaw and teeth, and boy was it a worthwhile challenge. 

It was a great sandwich experience. 

Ate half, and rewrapped the remainder for later consumption (son devoured it as soon as I got home). $10 for two meals makes the price very reasonable. 

In a land full of mediocre pizza shops, it is so nice to have another vision of Italian cuisine so well represented.

Café Diem on South 8th Street, just north of Washington, may as well be located in Hue, the former royal capital of Vietnam.  Its version of Bun Bo would certainly satisfy the tastebuds of the Emperor and his retinue.  

I admit to limited exposure to this Rice Vermicelli Beef Noodle Soup, but now that I have had it a couple of times, how will I ever go back to regular noodle soup?  It is so vastly superior to American slurp, that it is something of a cultural misnomer to label it "soup" at all.  It is much, much better.  

The Café is a small 8 table house that closes at 7 pm daily.  My first attempt to enter was time barred because I arrived too late.  This time I planned around closing, and arrived at 6:30 to an almost empty room.  As I was solo, the hostess pointed to a deuce in the corner, which was perfect for a full view of the proceedings.  I ordered the small bowl of BBH and a Salty Lemonade to offset the 102F broil on the street.  That was gone in a flash.  The soup arrived two minutes later, so overfull with Thin Sliced Beef, Rice Noodles, Cilantro, Mint and a chunk of Oxtail, that it was difficult to add the fresh Thai Basil, Coriander, Sprouts and Squeeze of Lime.  I snapped off the smaller leaves, a handful of sprouts, and a full lime wedge, and managed to push everything into the hot broth with spoon and chopsticks. I think there was even a Banana Blossom on the plate that I tossed in.  With the room created on the side plate, I extruded copious amounts of Hoisin and Sriracha for dipping the beef.  

The final product was about the best "soup" I had ever eaten.  Its Lemongrass base was dominant and strident.  The undertone of Fermented Shrimp Sauce added a sour note to the spiciness that really played well together.  Although I asked for "mild," that only applied to how much Hot Chili Oil they put in at the end, because the other condiments were already in the pot.  Finally, as I slowed down and reached the bottom of the bowl, the hint of sweetness came through.  Definitely a spoonful of sugar to make this medicine go down.  

This was a great liquid celebration.  It cleared my sinuses and had me envisioning exotic nights in Hoi An and Da Nang. 

I love Pho, but a well crafted Bun Bo is superior to that due to the many more ingredients, and the interplay of the four spice groups.  It is easy to see why this was the sup of the royals.

If you can't get to DiBruno's in South Philly, you should give La Stalla Italian Market a visit for your Italian delicatessen and specialty requirements.  While not packing the huge inventory of cheeses, smoked meats, salads, and bakery goods of its distant cousin to the south, the Newtown store sure is a reasonable facsimile.  This new place looks and smells like 9th Street, and goes overboard when asked to create a sandwich or other takeaway meal.  

Their loaves are about the best Italian bread you can find anywhere in the area.  Certainly as good as Italian Peoples' Bakery and the dearly departed Barbero's in Chambersburg, Trenton, NJ.  It is so excellent that it can easily be enjoyed without anything more, or a little olive oil with black pepper, or a smear of butter.  But, if an incredible lunch is what you desire, just pick a few of your favorite sandwich ingredients, the size roll your want, and let the deli folk go to work.  You will receive an immense tower of wonderful meats, cheeses and accessories that will last at least two meals. If you prefer not to create your own combo, just select one of their house sammies.  You won't be disappointed. 

Newtown has been undergoing a renaissance for the past several years, with improved restaurants and boutiques merchandising everything from designer clothing, great smoothies, to tasty tidbits. La Stalla Italian Market joins the fun and is built to scratch that impossible culinary itch. 

Parking in the rear and on the street nearby.

This will be as much a testimonial as a review.  

Driving out of Bordentown the other morning I heard my tire sensor start to beep.  Checking my maintenance screen I saw that one of my tires had a sudden and severe pressure drop.  Damn!  I had picked up a nail.  

Unfamiliar with the auto shops and gas stations in the area, I was at a loss where to go to do the repair.  A minute later I was passing RW Tire on Rt. 206 northbound.  Serendipity? 

I made it into the crowded parking lot and went inside with my lug lock in hand.  The man behind the counter finished with a customer and turned to me.  I explained the situation.  No sweat.  They'd get to it in a few minutes.  He took down my particulars and I handed over my keys and lug lock.  

About 15 minutes later I watched as one of their mechanics went out to find my wheels and drive it into the shop.  I walked over to watch him work and see what he found.  The guy was fast getting the car up, and even faster getting the offending tire off the car.  He rolled the tire looking closely for the cause of the flat.  He found it in a minute, got his nail extractor, yanked a cotter pin out of the tread and had the hole plugged, sealed and snipped in under 5 minutes.  This dude knew his tire repair!

Twenty five minutes from pulling in, I was pulling out.  Impressive!  And, the cost for this service was under $20.  

I complimented the tire jockey for his excellent work, and after paying the bill, asked the cashier what other work they did.  

They were so unexpectedly good at fixing my flat tire, they had made me a loyal customer in mere minutes.  I was pleased as punch!

Lakernick Health & Wellness is a chiropractic office that also offers massage and other related services in a compact facility in Feasterville, PA. It can be found on East Mrytle Avenue, a side street off Brownsville Road. A converted private residence it has a small parking lot in front, large enough for four cars. 

Walking in, the first impression is that the office is well worn with small treatment rooms to both sides down a central carpeted hall. Front desk staff is friendly and efficient, asking first time patients to fill out a two page questionnaire before seeing the doctor or masseuse. Prices are very reasonable. 

I was there primarily for a deep tissue/sports massage from Marla Solarski, who sees customers at several places around lower Bucks County. I was also curious about Stuart Lakernick, the owner of the business and bone cracker in residence. I had used a few chiros in the past and wanted to see how he worked on my back and neck. Stu is a very communicative guy, who nicely explains what he sees in examination (diagnosis), as well as what he intends to do for treatment. His equipment is excellent, with an adjustment table that allows you to stand up on the vertical inclined padded board, before it is slowly lowered into horizontal position via motorized swivel.  A first time for me. 
His adjustment of my lumbar/sciatic spine was a traditional heavy torque as I lay on my side with legs bent and overlapping my knee, as he both pushed on my upper hip/pelvis and pulled on my upper torso with his body weight. My left hip was "frozen," so that required a double move to get it done. But, done they were, and when finished, both back and neck felt looser and mobilized. 
Thereafter, Marla's massage was great with her excellent stretching and probing style. I could see that doing both an adjustment and massage enhanced the effect of each on my body. They were symbiotic. I always felt wonderful, if a little lightheaded, after her handiwork, but this time it was more intense and the after effects lasted longer than usual. I took a short walk once outside to feel more grounded before driving home. 

Suggestion - The purpose of chiropractic and massage is to lessen a stressed body and mind. I was a little put off seeing a political sign in front of the office, and it actually resulted in a shift in attitude going in. Regardless of affiliation, I prefer a health and wellness center to be apolitical, as I get enough of that everywhere else, all day long. I want to be able to relax in a sanctuary setting, not be reminded of harsh realities.  It is counterproductive to the goal I seek. Maybe others feel similarly.

Big Bear is a small local chain of health food stores in and around Bucks County, Pa., and Mercer County, NJ.  They have grown over the decades due to staying true to their mission of providing quality organics and nutritional supplements at reasonable prices.  Unlike the pharmacies and general merchandise stores than offer some of these things, Big Bear provides expertise along with multiple alternatives for staying on top of your life game.  If you can't find what you are looking for, just ask the people in the aprons, and they will take you to your destination.  If they don't have it, your probably don't need it.

I was in the Morrisville shop on Old Lincoln Highway (the local Rt. 1 and Rt. 13) over the weekend.  Only a few customers were there, along with the 72 year old manager, who was holding down the cashier's position, too.  Couldn't find the lecithin amidst the rows of bottles and cans of pills and powders.  He pointed me in the right direction, and when free, came over to talk about the options.  He inquired about other possible health issues that his products could address, and made intelligent suggestions.  Much appreciated.  

I am not vegan, nor gluten averse, so I did not spend any time looking in their deli cases, fresh produce, nor bakery sections.  Still, good to know they cover those concerns.  

Very glad they carry top quality merchandise, are knowledgeable and take time with their customers to listen and inform.  

This is how Big Bear separates itself from most of the competition.

Bagel Train remains my favorite bagel vendor in the area. 

Always a curiosity why people from Bagel City (born and raised there myself) think they know rounders better than anyone else, or that there is any uniformity among Big Apple bagels. There really isn't. I've had great ones on the Westside, and crappy ones in Soho. I've bitten into rock hard dense losers in Canarsie, and lovely light crunchers in Elmwood. 

So, don't listen to anyone who says they know what's best for anyone but themselves. If you love them, that's all that matters. Even if you never spent a day of your life in the City That Never Sleeps!

Past time for an updated review to reflect all the positive changes that this bagel emporium has gone through over the last few years. 

Biggest visible change was the expansion of their footprint and reorientation of the shop to permit side of building access which greatly enhances the size and feel of the space. Now Keystone is a for real cafe, with table and wall seating all around which gives a spaciousness to the operation.

Most important, they have built a bagel bakery right into the shop, with windows allowing customers to see the bagelmeisters at work. Not having to transport them from a more distant location means that the bagels are apex quality right from the oven to the bins. Nothing is lost in taste nor texture when the overall distance is about 20 feet. The difference in chewability is immediately apparent. Crisp firm outer skin and soft tender inner bagel, and full load of toppings (onion flakes for me), that stay affixed to the rounder, and don't fall off with normal handling. 

Service was excellent all around, with ordering at the counter and delivery to the table when done. Take out seemed just as smooth as I watched people come and go quickly. 

Keystone is planning an expansion into other shops and considering franchising the business. From what I saw and experienced on my last visit, they have a thoughtful plan and the means to execute. They listen to customers and are flexible enough to adapt to changing conditions. Personally, I would love to see them open up a little farther north in Bucks, and look into cross marketing with local coffee roasters where the best local Java and rounders were available in the same places and advertised together. 

The current situation is impressive, I suspect it will only get better from here! 

My candidate for Bucks Bagels of the Year!

Newtown Cleaners has opened a shop in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, right next to Acme. The owners are the same as the good people who operated Top Cleaners on South State Street for many years. Minah continues as the face of the business, daughter of the founders, who help out with dry cleaning moving in and out, and tailoring garments with nimble thimble, needle and thread. The old place was far too small for all their customers, and moving to the commercial center while a risk because of the larger nut carried, is also a great opportunity to increase their hold as the best professional cleaners in Newtown. 

I have been using them to launder my shirts and put cuffs on my pants for close to seven years after trying all the other places in and around town. While not the cheapest, the quality of services is undeniable, and Minah's personality outshines the pleasantries offered by the other store owners. Too, they run occasional specials that bring everything into line and makes them very competitive for the area. 

While it's hard to get too worked up about dry cleaning establishments, I have the feeling that with the extra space and sitting room, Newtown Cleaners could become a center of hot stove conversations in our community. 

Just provide great coffee and they will come.

Don't know about the salon in New York (although born and raised there), nor reputations well earned or not. But, I know what a good cut looks like, and how staff treats people. Most importantly, I know what makes my wife happy and what doesn't. 

After parking the car, I arrived at Room 209 about 20 minutes after she went in for her appointment. There were a row of barber chairs on the right, and a statue of a black horse rearing on its hind legs on the left in front of the high cashier counter. Lao po was in the rear having her hair washed, so I took a seat in the front waiting area.

 Eventually, she moved to her chair, where several assistants had their hands on her head combing and asking questions about her desired results. Sam came over to assess the situation, ran his hands through her hair for a minute or so, seemingly to contemplate the proper approach. He walked away a few times to supervise the other customers, but ultimately returned, shears in hand to put the finishing touches on the cut. 

A bit of blow drying and final shaping and trimming, and they were done. She was clearly happy with her look in the mirror, and I have to admit with her face framed with straight black hair and falling easily on her shoulders, she was a sight to behold. Her classic facial structure, deep eyes and high cheekbones gave her the image of an empress. 

Took my breath away.

Stopped by for breakfast this week, and was treated to excellent service, meal and ambiance all rolled into one sunny, cool autumnal morn. 

I couldn't ask for better weather for sitting at a deuce in the front window and having the sun through the glass warm my shoulders. Even with the diaphanous shades drawn to reduce the glare, the room was bright, white, and clearstory cheery. The dining area walls were all glass, letting in the beautiful bucolic 360 degree panoramas. I was warmly greeted and had hot strong Ellis Coffee on my table when I return from the WC.  

The menu had creative breakfasts on one side, and lunches on the other.  They change their signature quiche and frittata daily as described by my lovely server.  In addition, they offer pancakes, french toast, omelets and Caleb's Breakfast Sandwiches; with each coming in tempting varieties, like French Toast Bananas Foster, and seasonal specialties. I could have gone in any direction with all the sweet temptation, but chose their take on a sandwich made of chicken sage sausage, cheddar and two fried eggs on a soft fresh brioche roll.  It came with home fried potatoes on the side. 

Everything was great!

The sandwich arrived leaking melted cheddar onto the plate that ran into the taters. It was overloaded, and could not be contained in my hands. With each bite one of the split sausage links fell out and had to be replaced.  Ultimately, I gave up on that and used knife and fork to handle what the challenged roll could not.  No problem.  It allowed each element to be savored separately and in combination.  Although the brioche could have been stronger, I have no complaints when the result is a veritable cornucopia of delicious pieces falling to the plate and being forked up in harmony with the home fries.  Those chunky tubers were excellent, too.  Just enough big pieces to hold the spices tossed onto them on the grill, and small enough for well done nibs to provide a tasty crunch. They were super fine, deserving recognition via their own photo. Let's not forget the Ellis brew that was free flowing and a strong wake up/washdown for this superlative breaking of the fast. 

Can't speak for the other meals, but Caleb's does a might fine midweek morning repast.  Maybe a few bucks more cher than non-Lahaska cafes, but so very worth the experience.

More a cafe and less a bakery at the intersection of Holland and Buck Roads in Southampton, PA, this Eastern European house is well decorated with a large dining room and four private rooms for group breakfast and lunch. The menu is very interesting with the use of standard ingredients prepared by hands trained in formerly socialist republics. 

I ordered the Tomato Feta Omelet. It was cooked in a personal sized polished steel pan and served to me still burning hot in that instrument, on an oval wooden insulating plank. The outer egg was almost a souffle texture and the taste was great. It came with two chunks of bread and a small dish of sweet butter. The bread had a crisp crust warm enough to melt the spread. It was also excellent and left me wishing for more. 

The final surprise was the brewing of La Colombe coffee; strong enough to take immediate notice, and a pitcher of milk for mixing to my preferred shade of auburn. It was so good!

Service was efficient and beautifully accented. 

This was a surprising and awesome meal at a very reasonable price. It was good to visit Kiev for a few minutes.

So many of the good Mexican houses are across the Bucks County line in Montco, and Don Chile Mexican Restaurant is yet another of them. 

I called in my order of Chicken Cheese Flautas and Tacos al Pastor, and it was ready 15 minutes later. The space was attractive, and I can see eating in when the Covid coast is clear. The woman handling the front of the house was friendly, efficient and attractive. She made me feel appreciated for giving them my business. 

When I returned home, I found nice sized portions of everything, including bags/containers of chips & salsa, red rice, silky refried beans and crema fresca. The three Flautas were six inches long and overstuffed with chunky semi- ground roast chicken and white cheese wrapped in a large wheat tortilla and fried to a pleasant crisp. I topped that with their gaucamole, lettuce and tomato. A final drizzle of queso fresca over everything, and I was a contented man. 

My beautiful opposite number went after the Al Pastor with the same gusto, and described succulent roast pork surrounded by pieces of grilled pineapple, lettuce, tomato, guac and cheese; crammed into 3 smaller tortillas she could barely pinch and roll closed to get into her boca pequena bonita. She was hungry and didn't give me a chance to take photos before she demolished them. They sure had great aroma. 

Even the rice and beans were exceptional and worthy of mention. The grains were freshly made and not clumpy nor tasting of reheating, and the refried mashed kidney beans surprisingly smooth and delicious. All without the heartburn normally associated with heavy application of lard. No Tums necessary. 

Don Chile isn't in or near my neighborhood, but certainly is worth a drive in the country when the Mexican mood strikes. 

Mucho gusto!

This 230 acre park was given to the people of Montgomery County by the estate of George Horace Lorimer, the editor of the Saturday Evening Post and president of Curtis Publishing Co., both headquartered in Philadelphia from the late 19th Century to the present. His mausoleum is in Laurel Hill Cemetery, so although originally from North Carolina, his true impact was on the cultural life of our city. 

Fairly small, it feels considerably larger due to its connection to Pennypack Park covering a large area in Northeast Philadelphia to the border with Montco. The creek by the same name flows through both parks, tying them together geologically. The watercourse meanders through Lorimer where it has cut a deep ravine over the millennia. There are multiple scenic overlooks worth exploring, even in winter when the absence of foliage allows you to see through the trees to the actual contours of the steep rocky hills across the creek. 

If power walking or family bike riding is your jam, Pennypack Trail runs along the northern boundary of the park and beyond for several miles, and it is flat, wide and dirt/gravel packed for smooth ambulation or cross country biking, allowing excellent views of the topography and creek vale. 

Plenty of parking in a big lot across the road from the main entrance.

Returned today for lunch after an absence of almost a year.  There are so many Mexican or Guatemalan restos in the area now, that it took me 12 months to return with trying a new place several times a month. 

The space is basically as before, although the tables have been moved around and the sombreros have been taken down.  South of the Border music playing a touch too loud, and the Mexican soaps on the HDTV muted, leaving a lot of facial expression without voices. 

My Torta Carnitas (Grilled Pork Sandwich) was stuffed with shredded pork, lettuce, tomato, queso fresca and mayo.  The Roll was for this "small" sandy was larger than a typical Kaiser, with smooth skin and soft, fresh textured body.  It held together well, although it required considerable squeezing to compress it sufficiently to fit in mi boca grande. 
I also saw a fruit drink at another table that looked very tempting.  I inquired about it and discovered that they make fresh fruit smoothies and shakes for a few bucks.  I got the strawberry shake and it was cool smooth sweet berry addicting succulence. 

I skipped dinner tonight because this meal was so satisfying. 

So good to be back.  Turns out the first place visited when I arrived in Hamilton was perhaps the best.

Be Well Bakery & Cafe does it right.

Not only is the house cozy and spacious, the java very good and the bakery products excellent, but it is all wrapped into a business philosophy that promotes community, creativity, healthy living and complete genuineness. 

All very noble, right? But, let's get back to their house goodies for a second. I was tempted by their lemon tart in the display case. I love lemon bars, so I figured, why not? It was awesome! Creamy tart/sweet lemon filling, thin, flakey crust, plump, cool blueberries sitting on top. An orgy in my mouth. 

There are a lot of good bakeries and coffee houses these days; not as many in combination. Be Well is certainly one of the best of the genre in the region. 

All this in a beautiful part of Montgomery County, just down the road from Bryn Athyn Cathedral and Historic District. Worthwhile drive with Be Well as the final destination.

Simply Delicious by Tina is the star of the culinary show on this stretch of York Road, Jamison, PA. Plenty of parking alongside the stand alone building, with a long ramp up to the main door, you walk into a small deli/cashier area. There you can scan some of the home cooked meals offered by Proprietress Tina and her crew, as well as a sampling of her tasty baked goods. 

The dining room is to the left, and bathed in bright sunlight on this Saturday morn. Only one table was occupied by a grandfather/granddaughter team, so I gamboled to the other side near the bar for my seat. Orders are taken at the register, so I returned there after perusing the two sided laminate menu. 

Lots of healthy choices, and I selected the Hungry Person Breakfast Sandwich (3 eggs, 3 small homemade sausages, American cheese, tomato, greens on toasted thick sliced brioche). It was so large upon delivery to me that I asked that it be cut in half so I would have a chance to pick it up and take a bite without it falling apart in my hands. 

Well, it sort of fell to pieces under pressure from the kitchen knife anyway, but it still looked great when it came back to me. It still wasn't possible to secure it by hand with all the slippery ingredients, so I went after it with knife and fork. I combined different elements on the tines of my fork and jammed each into my mouth, my jaws as wide open as possible. 

It was totally worth the effort.

The parts were as good as the whole. 

I took home a square of Tina's Key Lime Strawberry bar for later enjoyment. Just devoured that four hours later. Loved it! From moist graham cracker crust through tart creamy lime/cheese body, and hint of sweet strawberry, it was a pleasure all the way down. Hot coffee chaser to finish my excellent weekend early day repast.

This official arboretum of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and an extension of the University, began as the summer residence of John and Lydia Morris, the children of I. P. Morris, a wealthy Quaker who made his riches in the iron business. It was originally called Compton, a mansion built on the promontory of the 92 areas above Wissahiken Creek. 

The soil was poor when they arrived, but over the years, they improved it until it supported the beautiful landscaping and exemplar botanicals found today. Sadly, the mansion was torn down about 100 years ago upon the death of Lydia, and it was bequeathed to the University in 1932. It is now an integral part of its sustainability efforts for the 21st Century. 

There are 12,000 labeled specimens in the preserve, as well as a Fernery (currently closed due to Covid), Rose Garden, and Horticultural Center within the expanded 167 acres. The walkabout for healthy outdoor folks is about 2 hours, although it can take considerably longer with a slow pace and lots of bench sitting to enjoy the surroundings. The Visitor's Center is closed temporarily, but restrooms are well maintained beneath the building. 

There are courses available throughout the year for all ages and skill levels. It is also a great place for a wedding or other occasion. 

Wear decent walking shoes as there are several miles of trails and significant elevation change from the top near the parking lot, down to the creek and back again. Water for a hot summer day and a hat are also recommended.

Pho Le Lai is a Vietnamese restaurant located on St. Vincent Street in the Mayfair neighborhood of Northeast Philadelphia. It is found in the same building as 1st Asian Supermarket, making it convenient to eat and shop for our Southeast Asian grocery needs. Both are closer to our Bucks County home, saving time compared to either Chinatown (traffic & parking) or Washington Avenue (traffic). 

I was the sole customer when I walked in around 3 P.M. The cordial manager got up from reading the newspaper and seated me at the table next to her and handed me their multi page menu. Another friendly woman came out of the kitchen with a pitcher of cold water, to answer questions and take my order. That was simple - Pho Tai and Roast Pork Banh Mi (This is a pho house, after all.) 

Ten minutes later she was back with the "Small" bowl of steaming beef noodle soup requested, and a side plate of exceptionally fresh standard accoutrement (sprouts, sliced jalapeno, Thai basil sprigs and lime wedge). I took a pair of new wood chopsticks and flat bottomed spoon from the table holder and doctored the pho to my taste, paying attention to pull apart the nest of noodles lying beneath the surface of the dark broth (Northern Vietnamese style). 

The flavor profile displayed some depth and had been simmering in a large pot for a long time. It wasn't quite as rich as Pho 75 or Pho Ha, but it was very good and didn't require help from the Sriracha bottle rocket on the table. It was plenty spicy with the addition of the jalapeno. 

I was content to slurp away and patiently lift noodles out of the caldron and fold them onto the spoon before shoveling them into my mouth. 

The Banh Mi arrived minutes later. It was a full sized sandwich on decent French baguette, cut in half. Like the pho, it was larger than anticipated, especially for $6!  It was loaded with dark roast pork, daikon radish, carrot, aioli and cilantro. I added a long squirt of Hoisin to bring up the savoriness of that combo, and took a bite. From crusty roll through crisp daikon and ultimately tender pork, it was delicious and captivating. It was a complete oral and tactile experience. One of the best sammys I've enjoyed since Ocean Grove, California, the capital of Vietnamese America. 

Along with China Gourmet, the excellent dim sum emporium also in that building, the presence of Pho Le Lai make St. Vincent Street a strong destination for your Asian taste buds and culinary needs.

LUNCH REVIEW - 

Cross Culture is a new Indian restaurant in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center where International Noodles used to be. I was there recently for lunch. 

It was renovated beautifully with new furniture and large fabric wall hangings that remind of Indian rugs. I was the sole customer when I arrived about 1:45 p.m. I was led to a table along a wall by the man working the floor. He handed me a menu and brought me a glass of water when I declined the bottle of Pellegrino sitting there. He promptly removed it. The afternoon menu offered quite a bit from thali combo metal containers/trays, to individual dishes, all of which came with fresh tandoori baked naan and bowl of basmati rice. 

Chicken Cashmere was my choice. It is a milk based curry dish, fairly mild, with almonds and raisins adding  a touch of sweetness. It was excellent. The four quartered naan was hot with oil sheen and the perfect scoop for carrying the extra sauce from bowl to mouth. It was thin and crisp, and baked expertly. The very long grain basmati was a great bed to lay the creamy chicken upon. 

Yes. I really enjoyed my Indian lunch at Cross Culture. Gotta hope that they have a lot more business for dinner, because they certainly deserve to attract a wide audience given the quality of their kitchen.

Ray Nudy is a second generation restauranteur whose 12 comfortable breakfast/lunch locations are perfect for satisfying meals. His Nudy's Cafes have been open and expanding in southeastern PA since 1979. Almost embarrassed to admit that yesterday was my first visit to any of them. I stopped in their Conshohocken Lafayette Street kitchen for a late breakfast. 

They operate in a large high ceiling room with half wall divided spaces for tables, and booths against one outer wall, if that is your preference. The menu has most of the usual suspects, with particular attention to several varieties of french toast. That's where I was heading, and went with their traditional three slice offering, with maple syrup upgrade and fresh brewed coffee. 

It was excellent. It arrived with plenty of caramelization for crisp edges, and a delicious mix of egg, sugar and vanilla extract that enhanced the flavor and texture, and a dusting of powdered sugar/cinnamon. A mini bottle of pure light amber maple syrup accompanied the large white ceramic plate. After spreading the melting butter, followed by the pouring of rich brown syrup, it was ready for sampling.

It was the best french toast I have had in a long time. 

Service was also above expectations. Friendly, interactive and professional, with prompt coffee refills and timely bussing. 

Too bad Nudy's isn't in Bucks County yet, because all locations are worth exploring. Given the quality of their product, it shouldn't be long before they secure kitchens closer to home.

After completing my nuclear stress test this morning, I think it fair to say that the entire staff of Jefferson Cardiology is first rate/5 Star.  I arrived at 7:15 am for a 7:30 appointment, and they had me signed in, consented, and parking validated before I could sit down in the waiting room.  The tech had me prepped and IVed a few minutes later, and I was in the cardio-camera room strapped into my seat by 7:35.  

The entire process went smoothly, and I had ample time to talk with the two doctors participating in the test.  They showed real interest in me as a person, and were willing to offer some insight into themselves.  I appreciated the warmth and openness.  I was told the entire test would take from 3.5 to 4 hours, but I was out on 10th Street in 3.  Not only that, but I was given a cup of coffee on the way out because I said I had not had one this morning, and a gift card to Au Bon Pain for having to wait 5 minutes before they came to get me.  How often has that happened?  

While I won't know the results until I call tomorrow, I can tell you that I was very pleased today.  My continued confidence in the docs and staff here was once again validated, along with my parking stub.  

BTW. Valet parking $12. for the entire time I was there, including my stroll to Au Bon Pain to exercise my gift card.

You know those infinitesimal screws that are used to put eyeglasses together? The ones the size of baby gnats? 

On a few occasions one of those poppy seed screws escaped and I returned to Steve for repair and consolation.  Each time he has graciously taken the pair into his repair shop and emerged a few minutes later with everything back in working order, cleaned and readjusted.  Yesterday, when a nose cushion fell off after about 5 years of wear, he replaced both free of charge and with a smile.  

I have been very happy with the Prodesign frames from Denmark, and most of all with Steve Robbins for continuing to stand behind his product.  

Does it get any better than that in the optometry world?  

I think not.

5 Stars!

Jinrong Li, Master Massage Therapist, LMT, runs this clean, state of the art spa on the north end of State Street in Newtown Borough.  She previously was the massage master at the Newtown Athletic Club.  

Jin does an excellent job relieving neck and back pain in a comfortable setting.  She is also a Skin Care Specialist, although I have never utilized those services.

Operating out of the old 1908 New Hope Eagle Fire Co. building and former Borough Hall on North Main Street, New Hope, PA., The Café @ The Four Crows has created a great space for the things they do best - brew excellent java (Rojo's Roastery, Princeton), and display electric guitars.  In fact, if you love rock music, you could come just for the strings and call this place a museum or guitar gallery. 

The owner, an Australian rocker who can no longer finger the frets, ended up in New Hope and has the entire collection for sale.  Here's hoping he never sells them all, as they are a wonderful attraction to an otherwise well appointed coffee house. It would be way cool if there was an amp and a few speakers hooked up so those with skills can riff on the wide variety of sound created by all of these works of musical art. 

But, back to the café.  

The space is deep and runs the length of the narrow building. It is full of leather couches and easy chairs, as well as several stools and shelves for resting beverages. It is about the most comfortable java joint I have hung out in in the past few years. My latte was decent, but I am not a big fan of Rojo's as a bean outfitter.  Better choices are available locally.  Still, the drink was hot, strong, and warmed my hands on this cooler morn.  

Everything here is made "to go."  The prices are very reasonable given the address.  So, overall, there is no reason not to stop by to service your caffeinated needs. It is a bit north of the center of New Hope, but there is plenty of street parking and a lot around the corner and behind Main Street.  Given the alternatives are the green mermaid and Dunkin, The Four Crows should be your first choice for coffee and comfort.

Who am I kidding?

I just went into Newtown Chocolatier to pick up some Peanut Butter Cups and Pecan Turtles for my son to bring to his grandparents for Easter.  While I was at it I asked the kind woman behind the counter if they had any broken pieces available.  She went into the back room and came out with a box of Milk Chocolate Strips.  I took every last nibble, and just tasted a bit before writing this update.  

Daaaahhhhmmmm!  So good.  Sweet, smooth, instantly addicting. 

5 Aces, and should have been so all along.

I understand why people love Casnova's Kitchen for breakfast. It sure doesn't look like much driving up, but once inside things start to come into focus. The dining room is a tight squeeze with only a handful of booths. But, if you go to the left and look around the back wall, you will find the infamous kitchen and a short luncheonette counter with a half dozen stools. If you enjoy watching the chef do his thing on the grill, and the entertaining talk between him, customers and his staff, then this is the joint for you. 

Grab a spinner, check out the large menu and go for something good. Anything with eggs and coffee is the right idea. I went with a sausage, egg and cheese on kaiser roll, but those omelets being prepared on the hot steel looked real appealing, too. All the while, the second gen Casanova (Tim?) exchanged information with me and had funny dialogues with the guys coming to this backroom man cave grill. They all knew each other well, and the comradery was patent. Even as a stranger I felt I was almost part of their clique. 

And, the sandwich was very good, too. Sausage logs (not links) a little crisp, with folded fried eggs and a couple slices of cheese, all on a  superior fresh roll brought in from a bakery in Jersey. Java refills as needed. 

This was a three ring, holy roller circus. It didn't look like a winner, but much like the other special places around Bucks, the ones that are hardest to find or hidden in plain site, are usually the best.

One of the best breakfasts of the year!

Girard, a breakfast/brunch/lunch house on the avenue by the same name on the southeastern corner with Marlborough Street in Fishtown has a lot of things going for it. 

It uses locally sourced provisions to the greatest extent possible, and it tastes it. They bake their own muffins and coffee cakes, and even their milk and burgers pump and grind from nearby cows. Taste and texture are from the hands of neighbors. 

They have a fair wage policy for all employees. That means everyone earns a reasonable living income ($14./hr now). This encourages long term commitment from workers and ownership, and shows great respect for people. As a result a 20 % tip is included in every check. Nothing more required unless you feel it warranted. Yes, this makes it difficult to express dissatisfaction with service or food quality through tipping, but on balance there is far more good from this approach, than negative. 

Their Elixr Coffee is hot and strong. Cold brew is also available at a small premium. In exchange for their smallish cups, refills are attentively prompt. In truth, the tables are smallish, too, so saving space makes sense. 

The room itself is tight, but brightly yellow. An odd angled ceiling helps with acoustics and gives a slight unreality to the space. Big windows overlook Fishtown, a corner of Philly undergoing a distinct renaissance. 

Finally, our breakfast ( I don't do brunch ) was excellent. The Breakfast Burger was a double patty, thick bacon and sunnyside up egg on brioche bun that was juicy and fun. The side of fries was crisp and plentiful. Their homemade hot sauce, a kick in the pants when poured on generously. We shared a square of their peach/basil coffee cake. Both ingredients were easily palatable, and to our delight, it was not overly sweet, but allowed to make it's own quiet statement. Delicious. 

Girard checked all the boxes that matter, and a few not normally considered. 

Impressive!

If fried chicken is one of your favorite comfort foods, then a visit to Lovebird on East Ashland Avenue, Doylestown, PA, is very worthwhile. At least, I know that was why I was there. 

Brought to us by the folks who created the successful Jules Thin Crust Pizza, Lovebird is the brainchild of that same crew with equal parts great recipe, locally sourced, cage free, vegetarian raised Amish poultry, and simple gray toned shop with one collective table and five sunny bright window stools. As a newbie, I ordered the aptly named "Lovebird Sandwich," which came with a perfectly deep fried battered breast, cole slaw, pickles, lettuce and special sauce mayo, on a freshly baked local bakery brioche roll. 

It was one of those meals where the enjoyment began with the first bite through the thick layers of crisp crusty bird, through the tender sweet roll. It was as textural as it was flavorful. It was delicious and fun to eat. And, if you prefer roasted chicken over fried, go for it! They have that, too, and although I didn't taste it, it looked awesome.

Tasted a few fries, and they were quite good, but I'm trying to be good to myself by some modification of diet, so I passed on getting my own. The Lovebird was so great on its own that I really didn't miss them. Also, begged off the Boylan Soda, one of my past faves. 

Now for the News Extra! Lovebird is coming to Newtown soon, across Sycamore Street from its sibling, Jules. That is something to get excited about! Not just another knock off franchise, but a true original.

There is nothing nasty about this Han house of szechuan cuisine at Second & Chestnut in Philadelphia. This Chinese palace deserves all the praise it receives.  Housed in a former bank from the Golden Age, the high ceiling and neo-classical architecture are a fitting backdrop for the high quality and superior platters conceived and executed in the kitchen woks. 

We had a 15 minute wait for our table to be ready, but the time was well spent at the bar sipping an excellent Malbec and adjusting to the bustle of a busy Friday night. Really liked our table in the back under the dramatic staircase. More private and romantic.

 We ordered four dishes prepared in different styles, and moderately to seriously spiced. Cumin lamb, dry fry beef, dry pepper fish and string beans with minced pork, arrived seven minutes after our excellent server accepted our requests. The quickness surprised us. Yet, each dish was perfectly plated and at their peak flavor. None were overly oily, and each distinct in their texture and taste, despite the use of similar Szechuan red and black peppers. Everything was delicious, and we were glad for over-ordering so we had plenty to bring home. 

The size of the room was unusual for an American Chinese restaurant, and reminded us of the large banquet showrooms popular in China. It added to the authenticity of the overall experience. 

I didn't remember Han D. being such a complete and satisfying night when across the street. Whatever it is, they have it going on now. In spades! 

Five Stars!

Another great night for baseball at Arm & Hammer Park! 

We watched a slow game through five innings, when no one seemed capable of mounting any offense, become a slug fest for the home town Thunder, who scored ten runs in two innings to put the game away.  

All this under pink sunset clouds and Dollar Dog Night!  

The adversary?  The Richmond Flying Squirrels.  Hard to imagine them even wearing pants.

Even with rain delays, Double AA Minor League Baseball as personified by the Trenton Thunder and the multi-named Waterfront Park/Arm&Hammer Park/Samuel Plumeri Park, offers a great all American experience that is great for family, friends, clubs, offices, and just solitary "Field of Dreams" lovers.  

So, it is with a strong sense of having a beautiful and unique cultural experience that we return regularly to this Temple of Timeless Baseball to pay our respect and appreciation for the Great American Pastime. 

It was so much fun to be back again.

October 15, 2015 - Finally ordered their small, personal sized tomato pie as Ingrid had suggested months ago. Boy, was she right! The super thin crisp crust was a firm delight, and the mozza, chunky tomato pieces and spices exactly what was required.
Simply stated, I loved it!

Makhani ("Buttery") is a small, dark, North Indian house on historic S. 3rd Street, Philadelphia, PA. Service is individually prepared, so you receive a large plate with your order and a side of Basmati rice, rather than the bowl approach used by most Indian shops. It is still easy to share with a companion, so it is really no big deal. 

What they do very well, is make sauces/gravies for their dishes that are better than most. Uber creamy (perhaps from all the butter from which it takes its name), such that regardless of the solid part of the meal, the succulent sauce completely overwhelms it. Our paneer and lamb bases were very good, but the Tikka Masala and Muglai suspensions in which they swam were simply stupendous. With a little heat from the curries, and a spoon, not a drop was wasted. The garlic naan made the perfect tool for dipping/scooping as much rich gravy as possible. 

This was really one of the best Indian sups I had enjoyed for a while. Even the Samosa Chaat appetizer was distinct enough with its ground potato/chickpea samosa and smaller crunchies and excellent tamarind flavoring to make us slow down and enjoy every morsel. 

The only disappointment was the supposedly extravagant mango cheesecake. When it arrived, it was far smaller than expected, both in terms of length, width, volume, as well as taste. It was underwhelming to say the least. Maybe our expectations were too New York, but this job was not worth the $10 by half. Makhani does itself no favor by accentuating it as a popular delicious treat. It is not. Save your money for the real deal at better known cheesecake outlets.

1742. 
Old enough for you? 

The Washington House has anchored the heart of Sellersville, PA, since before the Revolution. Now, teamed with the Sellersville Theater next door, it offers a great destination in northern Bucks County to eat, drink, sleep and be entertained. 

We drove up late Friday afternoon to buy tickets for the upcoming Indigenous rock/blues concert. It was a beautiful drive. Parking was right across the street, and the box office was open for business. This will be covered in more detail in a subsequent review. 

The Washington House beckoned next door, so we walked down the street and entered through the bar. It was dim with long bar to the left and dining room to the right. We arrived at the right moment as there were several stools open. We grabbed two and we're immediately greeted by a tender who informed us that they were doing an Octoberfest Beer Tasting event, and we were just in time to join in. 

Yes, we will. Thank you.

We chose Flight One, consisting of three 6 ounce pours of Paulaner Hefe Weissbier, Hardwood Park Pills and River Horse Cherry Berliner Weisse. They all came from freshly opened bottles. They were each distinct and very good. The Hefe was mildly bitter and peppery with a hint of clove and a surprising ripe banana-like end note. The Park Pils tasted of grass and grains and was cloudy like cider. The Cherry Berliner was sour and tart with a soft ruddy red tint. If we had more time we definitely would have saddled up for dinner and a second and third flight. Others had joined us at the bar and the dishes they were served were mighty appealing. 

Our impressions were so positive of Washington House that we decided we would come back for a full night of revelry with music, food, drink and room upstairs so as to extend the celebration to breakfast the next morning. 

If only the theater next door had bruncheon concerts!

Those of us who remember and enjoyed the heyday of the Chambersburg section of Trenton, NJ, with Italian restaurants on practically every corner, felt a special sadness as one after another they began to close or move out of town to the suburbs. Over the last two decades as the neighborhood changed and the original families moved to greener lawns and better schools, they took most of their traditions and cultural institutions with them. When Amici's closed it's doors recently, the Italian era of this capital city was officially over. 

Yet, there is another casa Siciliana still going strong after 30 years at the same location. It might not be in the "Burg," but sure feels like it once you step inside. Enzo's sits almost invisibly on the northern end of Princeton Avenue in Lawrenceville, west of the Brunswick Circle. It is a small, cozy, darkly lit, romantic hideaway, where the Scozzari family has been running a pure Italian kitchen for two generations. I sure hope there is a third.

Park in back and walk past the outdoor dining area, through the front door and then a second one on the right. Step down into the small dining room and be greeted by Anna, daughter of the namesake Enzo, who will seat you at one of only dozen or so tables, and hand you the menu. Moments later, the head waiter approaches with water and description of the available specials. There is a small lunch menu with soups, sandwiches, and pasta plates. 

They didn't have the Italian Hot Dog I desired (being removed from the menu), but the suggested alternative, their "World Famous Meatball Sandwich," sounded about right. 

And, it was. Excellently garlicked, crusty toasty Italian loaf, stuffed with hand-rolled meatballs,  sauteed broccoli rabe, spinach and roasted red peppers, with a side a sweet tater fries, all on a large white round plate. Delicious! I like to deconstruction a sandwich and eat its elements separately to savor each ingredient. I did that for half and had a mouthful of flavor with each bite. It was unforgettable. The second half I attacked​ en masse. Cleaving through it and enjoying the texture and taste of each bite as they melded in my mouth. No red gravy here. Just each part doing its job to make me happy. Quite a total experience for a lunch. 

Got to go back for a romantic dinner soon with the woman of my dreams and a couple bottles of Chianti.

Enzo's is the real thing.

Another great early summer night along the Mighty Delaware watching Trenton Thunder baseball.  

We dined exclusively from Chickie's and Pete's this time.  Italian Sausage with Pepper and Onions, Trenton Hot Dogs (stuffed with Potato, Pepper and Pickle), and Crab Fries. I was surprised at the quality of the Sausage, and how well it was grilled just before being slapped into the fresh Italian Roll.  Even the P & O were sautéed correctly.  The Fries were dosed in Old Bay Seasoning and came with a side of Creamy Cheese Dressing for dipping.  All that for under $23.  

We were all smiles despite a loss by the home team to New Hampshire.

"...'Cause I want to be there
Wanna go back down and get high by the sea there 
With a tin cup for a chalice
Fill it up with good red wine
And I'm a chewin' on a honeysuckle vine..."
(Tin Cup Chalice - Jimmy Buffet - Highway A1A) 

Turns out that you don't have to go all the way to Key West, FLA, to enjoy the benefits of its easy living ways. These days you can detour to Bristol, PA, and stop in to Cindy's Café on old Mill Street, and have breakfast or lunch within its sunny clime. The local family running the show loves both Bristol and Key West, and lives in both. They come by their passion for Trop Rock and old downtowns on the river naturally. 

The former Station Stop has been transformed into a bright, cheerful beachside retreat, where good coffee and delicious meals abide. The walls are covered with their personal artifacts, from post cards to family photos to clothing worn to protect them from the Tropic of Cancer sun. Steve, Patty and Kelly are excited and proud of what they have created out of personal tragedy, and they all work with heart, soul and mind fully invested. 

My sausage, egg and cheddar breakfast sandwich was one of the better renditions I have had the pleasure to devour.  There is a real chef in the kitchen who knows that runny fried eggs are much better than a hard finish, and the use of a fresh, quality roll or bun is the best way to contain the dynamic ingredients, and absorb the drippage for delectable texture and flavor. The side of home fries was a nice extra touch, although I am partial to skin-on red bliss potatoes for my morning fries. The java was hot and strong, too. 

Mill Street is really coming on with many new restaurants and shops. What was once a main drag to avoid, has become a place of entertaining choices, with international cuisine and loads of local talent. Cindy's Café also does its own Key Lime Pie @ $3.50 a slice. Very tempting for later in the day. 

"...Big straw hat, banana drink
I can't remember what it is I think
And my, my, my - Key Lime Pie...
Not too tart, not too sweet
My baby loves to watch me eat
Her Key Lime Pie
Her Key Lime Pie!... 
(Key Lime Pie - Kenny Chesney - Be As You Are; Songs from an Old Blue Chair)

Will be back for that KLP, KLP.

What a great place for a rock concert! 

300 seat theater. All unobstructed views. "Cafe" up front for members who love their music up close, personal and full of sprayed sweat. Even we peons in Row O were just above the heads of the band and had perfect location for the sound and fury. Comfortable seats and room enough to stand and boogie when the proper riffs blew us out of our chairs. 

Indigenous was fantastic! The opening act, Greg Soder Band played bluesy rock for 20 minutes and then gracefully moved aside for Mato Nanji and his mates to take off the roof. This Native American group from North Dakota has been rocking since the late 1990s. The members have changed, but the raw talent and energy has not. Mato is a complete original heavy guitarist. He sounds like a cross between Stevie Ray Vaughn, Jimi Hendrix and Carlos Santana with Warren Haynes thrown in. His own songs are very good, and when he segues into Voodoo Child, Little Wing and I'm a Man instrumental, he amplifies and projects a towering presence that just sends the house into orbit. 

And, when all is sung and done, and they have played their last encore, they come to the lobby for a meet & greet. No rush. Just hanging with their fans, signing autographs and selling their latest CD. Friendly, grateful and totally engaged. 

Sellersville Theater is a gift from the rock and blues gods. How I wish the folks running the old Newtown Theater would take a chance and run some hot music through it's stage.

You can tell that folks in the Newtown, Bucks County, PA, area were hungry for great pizza, because Vince's Pizzeria and Taproom was absolutely jammed at 4:30 on the weekday afternoon I stopped in to check it out. There was hardly an empty parking space to be found. 

And, I understand why. Our region has a load of pizza shops, but extremely few that really know the pizza business (read, none). The people behind Vince's have several generations invested in making superlative dough and sauce, and using quality cheeses to create exceptional pies. Only the sainted DeLorenzo's transplanted from Jersey compares. 

Luckily for me, there was room at one of the large community tables in the back of the house. Everyone was friendly and welcoming. We ended up in extended conversations as we chowed down. There was a couple from Yardley, and another from Trenton, NJ. We were all there to sample the wares, and drink from the fountain of beers along the rear wall. It worked fairly well, although it was obvious that they were still on their shakedown cruise, this being their first week in operation. 

The taproom concept is still new and not readily available. It requires the purchase of a RFID chipped card that attaches above the tap to the beer selected, releasing the brew into 12 oz. glasses which are filled by the customer. The available inventory is pictured above each tap, with brief description to help you choose. The beer card is good for 32 oz., after which you must pay for a reinfusion of funds. It all gets a bit complicated, as it seemed that the staff was repeated asking for a credit card for that, and again at check out. I handed mine over three times - there should be a better system in place. 

Yet, all is forgiven because the tomato pie/pizza is so damn good! The crust is thin, but stays firm from first munch to last. No drooping points here. The taste is like a first rate cracker, with a little saltiness that offsets the mild sweetness of the sauce above. There is just the right ratio of red to white, so there is no excess run off from cheese oils, nor watery tomatoes. From first steaming bite to last cool belly filler, the consistency is constant with crunchy crust and easily distinguishable ingredients. These are high quality pies. 

All  I can say is that the other pizza joints in and around Newtown are in trouble now. The competition just jumped up a few notches. Once word gets out that Vince's is the new sheriff in town, the old boys will find themselves out of luck, and will have to improve their game if they want to stay in business. 

It's about time!  Thank you, Vince's!

Palantes Italian Deli is a first rate small shop loaded to the gills with specialties from the Boot. They offer house made meats and pasta trays, as well as smoked meats from the old country. Think of it as a mini DiBruno's, and you get an idea of what is going on in there. Just too bad it isn't larger so that it could show more delectables. Too, it would be great to have a seating area and mange what they turn out right on the premises. 

We stopped in for lunch earlier in the week. I ordered an eggplant parm sandwich, which was excellent from crusty sesame loaf down to the well double fried nightshade and mildly tart red sauce. My companion ordered a personal size pizza with sausage. That disc left my car with a pleasant aroma for days afterwards. Will be returning for one of those babies. 

Staff was pleasant and very knowledgeable. Prices were fair, but it is hard to walk away with just a sandwich when the shelves are full of interesting and tasty snacks and side dish possibilities. 

Palantes is almost too good for the neighborhood, yet with Richboro Coffee right next door, the opportunity to trade off each other presents several excellent choices for nosh and java combos. Wonder if the coffee vendor would permit someone to enjoy a tasty repast at their small sitting area and make the world a better place for everyone? 

I would definitely sign up for that!

One door closes. Another door opens.  

I drove to Glenside for breakfast at a well known diner close by the Keswick Theater. The doors were locked and lights off on a midweek morning, and no notice posted that it was closed for vacation, or for good? Having come that far, I checked Yelp for an alternative kitchen in the neighborhood. It showed me Welcome Home, a cafe about two miles away in Jenkintown. 

I arrived there and found meter parking around the corner for $.50 for an hour. 

This is a small cubby hole of a breakfast/lunch joint. 8 deuce tables at most. Walking in, I was greeted warmly by a lovely woman, who exclaimed, "Welcome Home." She immediately warmed my heart with her salutation. I sat in the back of the dining room, right in front of the glass partition with the kitchen. I was handed their small menu, followed quickly by a mugga joe. It was hot and brisk. I inquired about the French Toast Casserole. Learning that it was very sweet, and asked that it be less so. She said that could be done, and a few moments later, I had a three inch high stack of Texas Toast that had been well dipped in a egg/sugar/cinnamon/vanilla slurry and pan fried/assembled into one united structure. Strawberries and cream on top. 

Yes. It was delicious from top to bottom, and even the accompanying sausage links played their second fiddle role well. I came in joneszing for sweet fried bread, and was completely satisfied. 

Welcome Home is Black Woman owned and operated by Stephanie, who is the guiding light and creative force. Her personality dominates the proceedings in a great way. The combination of character and kitchen magic makes this place a keeper and highly worthy of your exploration. Be sure to bring hungry taste buds.

But for living in Bucks County, I would make Welcome Home a true and regular stop on my breakfast trail. It is that unique and appealing.

Nonno's (Grandfather's) Bakery on South York Street, Hatboro, PA, is an old school Italian artisanal bake shop where everything you behold is made on site, and generally produces high quality cookies, pastries, donuts, fruit tarts, pies and an extraordinary number of marzipan fruit miniatures. 

I stopped in after lunch down the street at Gallo Tropical, looking for interesting desserts for me and to take home for the fam. Upon entry I quickly realized that I had entered an unexpected time machine that would carry me back to childhood adventures with my parents and grandparents shopping the small ethnic stores in the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where Jewish and Italian delis, butchers, fish mongers and fruit stalls kept us fed and connected to our heritage. 

Nonno's display cases were full of beautiful cakes and the like that required time to explore and difficult choices to be made among the incredible bounty of colorful, luxuriously tempting items. There is a health limit to the quantity of sugar anyone should consume, and this bakery would push that to the max. So, I let my camera do the tempting while I selected only a few things that were turning me on. A slice of carrot cake to cover the pastries, two donut twists to sample their coffee companions, and a marzipan banana to tease on the fruit bowl of choices created by the creative hand of their talented almond paste sculptors. Sure, it wasn't enough, but now I know where these artists are, and can return at will.

The carrot cake was not what I imagined would be a heavy cake base with uber sweet cream cheese icing; but instead a light gingery cake and a mildly sweet layer of butternut-like topping. It was excellent in this format. More subtle taste than the diner version. The donuts were a yeasty twist, still moist and chewy, with a delicious thin layer of icing that was a slow pleasure to eat. Better than anticipated. The marzipan banana (as were all the trayed fruit) was a softly firm almond paste that was best taken in small bites and masticated with attention to the release of that unique and seductive almond flavor that expanded as chewed. Ummm...

It wasn't a complete Roman heaven. I skipped the cookies covered with jimmies, and the cannoli prefilled with vanilla sweet ricotta (I'm not a jimmies guy, and prefer my cannoli filled when ordered). Nonetheless, Nonno's Bakery is a worthy destination to satisfy that part of your sweet tooth that can only be satisfied by high quality old world goodies.

Their Mission Statement: "Using creativity and improvisation to maximize human potential." 

Even sitting in the audience of the Newtown Theater, it was apparent how effective Unscripted Productions in general, and The Teachers' Lounge troupe in particular, was in bringing parts of human personality to the fore and holding everyone involved in the light, both spiritually and klieg. 

Will Dennis and his three companions were a high energy team involving the audience in their skits and even calling them up to the stage to join in the spontaneous merriment. Give them three unusual objects, moments in history or dialogue from Neil Simon plays, and they return with an hilarious sketch called out if their interactive imagination. It was all great! 

Although the evening began as a fundraiser for local candidates a week before the election, it quickly became an exercise in team building and support for the final get out the vote push, while it also showed another side of all of us who were ready for some fun after so many month of all too serious campaigning. Didn't know how funny those guys were! 

So, we raised some money, ate some good food provided by local restaurants and delis, and enjoyed an unexpectedly wonderful evening. 

Thanks so much Unscripted Productions. 

Creative Improv = Creative Improve

Birthday Flowers in the Age of COVID-19 - 

Somethings in life must be celebrated on time regardless of surrounding risks. So it was that a bouquet of fresh cut flowers were required to honor my wife's birthday in the middle of a quarantine stay at home order. Roses didn't feel spontaneous enough, nor as crazy ebullient as the moment needed. No, the creative hand of a true florist and flora lover was the way to go. 

I used the third party online vendor I had worked with before, but to my good fortune they subbed out to Penny's in Glenside for execution. They were on time and on my wavelength. We left the package on the porch for a day out of an abundance of caution to allow any Covid cooties to be rendered inert. When we brought it inside to the kitchen, and unbound its wrapping, we beheld a riot of daisies, sunflowers, zinnias, red carnations, a few gorgeous coral roses and dried sinuatum. They were soft to touch and scented like the dawn of Spring. 

Most importantly, they generated the emotional response I was hoping for from the object of my affections. She kvelled like a purring kitten, and treated me like I was the celebrant, not her. 

Just as it should be. Penny's had it exactly right. I now have a new florist.

Aside from the high price found across the board at Trenton Farmers Market, the baby back ribs offered by Smoke Chef Jeff of Hambone Opera are terrific. Meaty, tender, pull off the bone and barky, this hole in the wall is considered the best Q in New Jersey by those who know. 

The main man himself learned the wood science while in Texas and brought his experience and original notions with him when he came here. The sauce is Kansas City red tart, but the secret lies in the wild cherry wood logs with which the meats are smoked for 12-13 hours in the huge closed steel smoker out back of the market. 

The wood is the thing in the hands of a well trained smoke chef, and Jeff has developed it to the height of culinary arts it was meant to be. You can taste it in the mild sweetness in the heart of each rib before it is overcome by the spicy Kansas City rub and sauce, and yet again by the more tangy squirt squeezed on as the final step before eating. 

This was great BBQ. At $14/lb, it was not cheap, but what you would pay for eat in platters, not takeout. Nonetheless, sometimes the splurge is worthwhile. It certainly was this time. The brisket looked just as good, as did their smoked beans. 

Next time for those.

1/3/2016 - Finally made it here for dinner. The Tomato Pie (w. mushrooms) was excellent.  The Caesar Salad, not so much. Better to stick with what Palermo's does best and leave the greens to a garden master.

It has been awhile since my last visit to V & V Foot Massage because I found a place closer to home on Bustleton Avenue that made the drive to Washington Avenue less necessary. But, today with a sudden opening in my schedule and finding myself already in Philly, I decided on a return stop to get my tootsies, neck, shoulders and back some quality attention. 

The place hasn't changed much. Maybe some new neon out front and new hands on deck, but it looked and felt as remembered. I opted for the 90 minute combo foot and body Chinese style massage. Judy was cleaning up the shop when I arrived and immediately directed me to one of the large recliner chairs and foot rests while she went to fill the wooden bucket with very hot water and herbal bags. 

She dug and squeezed for half an hour, putting me immediately to sleep.  Felt great waking up and walking on air to the massage table in one of the back rooms. She found the knots in my back and shoulders and applied strong pressure to make them relax and allow blood and Qi to flow freely. Nice release and relief. 

When she finished she cleaned the room and brought me a glass of cool water. She was friendly, but quiet as she worked. Very satisfying session. 

Pro Tip - Although the sign says "Cash Only," in fact they do accept some credit cards, but prefer their tips in cash. Makes sense to me and I was happy with that arrangement. 

It was nice to be back @ V&V.

If you are ever curious about what goes on in Roebling, NJ, the former company town owned by the steel company by that name, Kalman Bakery offers another tasty reason to satisfy your history bug. 

The row houses down near the river are interesting, although this burg has definitely seen happier days. But, plan to stop at Kalman's for a sweet treat on your way out of town. This family operation bakes up very good cookies, cakes and donuts at low budget prices to meet the needs of the community. The coffee is decent, too. 

When I visited last week in the late morning, I was the only customer. I was greeted by a woman behind a high refrigeration display case. She explained that everything was made there, and that Tuesday was the start of their week and all was freshly baked. The traditional Old Fashioned donut looked like a blooming flower, while the Glazed was a pillow of sweetness and light. So good with the java washdown. 

Now that I know where it is hidden, I will be back to Kalman's as time and sweet tooth allow.

From the look of the dog eared, battered menus of the "Legendary" Dew Inn Diner @ the corner of 5th & Girard Avenue, Northern Liberties, they had been in use for the more than 50 years this awesome joint had been in business. The low 20th century prices didn't lead me to think differently. Sure, the furnishings were likewise dated, but it all came together to create the perfect environment for a traditional Philadelphia brekkie, sans all the hoopla of the nouveau brunch scene. 

From our perch on two spinners at the counter, we sipped the Bunn java and watched the full house deep in convos and good winter Saturday morning feast-ivities. When our Spanish Omelet and A Hot Mess 'kitchen sink' omelet arrived, we were very ready to chow down with gusto. 

And gusto was what we got. Each was a 3 egger, so full of ingredients that it was surprising that everything got tucked in. The ham, peppers, onions, cheese and salsa in the Spanish melded wonderfully and the taste/texture was great. The home fries were crisp, yet buttery, and all we needed were splashes of Crystal Hot Sauce to complete the excellent profile. The Hot Mess threw everything in the kitchen including the potatoes into the egg shell. How they zipped it up without leakage remained a secret. It was filling and delicious, and the rye toast added a touch of subtle sour savoriness that was good to the last bite. 

Dew Inn is another awesome corner breakfast joint that the City of Brotherly Love is so rightly famous for. Loved every forkful.

Before you get to the excellent restaurant in back, you pass through a small but packed with merchandise mercado general. It is worth the exploration in its own right before sitting down for almuertzo o diner. The collection of chilies alone is a botanist's wet dream. 

It is not every day that you can walk through a museum quality exhibit of colorful peppers, followed by shelves full of Madonna and Child statuary, on the way to a delicious and culturally absorbing meal. 

Although the market/kitchen concept is standard issue in Mexico and their outposts around the world, this one is a typical sample with outstanding chef at the back of the joint.

As soon as we walked in to Greystone it was obvious the new owners put alot of money into renovating the old Lavender Hall. Although mostly black and grey, the front bar/ lounge was beautifully sedate, and the dining room spacious with room between tables and large windows bringing in late afternoon light before the coming of dusk. It was impressive, and on this Tuesday evening, not crowded at all, which enhanced the sense that we had chosen well. 

We were seated at a table mid floor, but asked to be moved near an electric outlet in order to charge a cell phone. They graciously obliged. Our server quickly introduced himself and brought drink and food menus. The wine and beer lists were broad enough without necessitating a trip to the wine cellar. My old friend selected a glass of zinfandel, while my beautiful date picked a light small brewery pilsner, and I a pineapple cider (delicious). We settled in with the drinks and caught up while perusing the menu. 

We kept dinner on the lighter side, with a Chopped Greek Salad, Mushroom Burger and Fig Jam Burger for yours truly. At $15 per slider, the price was high, but still much more in line with our appetites than the entrees which were double the cost. So, we felt that management was smart to offer smaller options that allowed for drinks and/apps and a reasonable bottom line. Besides, we thoroughly enjoyed our meals. The burgers were half pounders with brioche rolls and homemade potato chips or fries. The fig jam added a nice sweet dimension to my burger. My friend asked for grilled scallops added to the salad, but when the kitchen lacked them, they inquired if he would be satisfied with shrimp instead. He was. 

We were happy with our experience at Greystone. It was qualitatively superior to the previous tenants who tried to make a go of it in the old mansion on the road between Newtown and Washington Crossing. The outdoor patio looked appealing, but with the steam heat unrelenting even into the evening, now was not the time to try it out. 

This was an interlude even George himself would enjoy.

When you find street parking with time on the meter located directly across from your destination in Lambertville, you suspect that grace and parking angels are smiling down on you. So, expectations rise and you prepare for more magic moments. 

I chose Tacos Cancun because I desired good Mexican cuisine in a safe space respecting Covid Protocol. Just so happened that the back patio had been recently renovated - replacing beach umbrellas with a large lime green tarpaulin over all the tables and a 6' bamboo screen all around. It made the backyard feel private and someplace more tropical than New Jersey. That I was the only paying customer late Sunday afternoon, certainly helped with the vibe. I took a table along the southern wall about halfway back and had all the attention I could ever want. 

The menu had most of the usual suspects, plus a few house specialties. Although I was considering Flautas, Chili Rellenos, or Torta Milanese, when I arrived, I changed my mind for a walk on the wild side and ordered La Gringa, one of their specials that seemed to cover a lot of bases (sauteed veggies, ham, chorizo, melted cheese and crema drizzle). It was well reviewed, so I rolled with the optimistic sense I came in with. 

Within 10 minutes a large white ceramic plate arrived, with Red Rice & Black Beans and hot Tortillas. It was all delicious, even though I didn't understand why the dish was called "Gringa," (North American Girl). No doubt there was a story there, but the servers didn't seem to know it. Even without the additional local color, it was a fine filling meal. It wasn't overly spicy, but not everything has to be a conflagration for me to be happy. 

While not as intensely authentic as the kitchens found in the Hispanic neighborhoods of Trenton or Norristown, it was plenty good enough for me. No hesitation coming again.
